From: max.smith@trading.com
To: vicente.garcia@shipping.com
Subject: Wheat Cargo Inquiry - Odessa to Barcelona
Timestamp: 2023-08-01 09:15
Body: Morning Vicente,

I have 4,300MT of wheat from Odessa to Barcelona. Could you advise if you can fit this in early August, and what's your standard demurrage clause?

Best regards,
Max

---

From: vicente.garcia@shipping.com
To: max.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Wheat Cargo Inquiry - Odessa to Barcelona
Timestamp: 2023-08-01 10:30
Body: Dear Max,

Yes, we can accommodate this shipment in early August. Regarding demurrage terms, we operate on standard FIOS terms (Free In/Out Stowed). Please note that your demurrage rate should match between buyer and seller. Would you like me to send you a full contract for review?

All the best,
Vicente

---

From: max.smith@trading.com
To: vicente.garcia@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Wheat Cargo Inquiry - Odessa to Barcelona
Timestamp: 2023-08-01 11:45
Body: Dear Vicente,

Thank you. I don't require the full contract, just the demurrage clause would do. We will send you the draft offer in the next two days.

Warm regards,
Max

---

From: vicente.garcia@shipping.com
To: max.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Wheat Cargo Inquiry - Odessa to Barcelona
Timestamp: 2023-08-01 13:20
Body: Dear Max,

Our offer would be based on the FIOS terms. Let me know if you accept and I'll send you the draft offer ASAP.

All the best,
Vicente

To: sarah.kim@vesselbrokers.com
Subject: 12,000 DWT Coaster Availability Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Dear Ms. Kim,

Could you please confirm the availability of a 12,000 DWT coaster, and what's the earliest possible sailing date?

Best regards,
Minh

---

From: sarah.kim@vesselbrokers.com
To: minh.nguyen@tradeco.com
Subject: Re: 12,000 DWT Coaster Availability Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Dear Minh,

I've forwarded your inquiry to our operations team. My colleague James will respond with the vessel availability details shortly.

Best regards,
Sarah Kim

---

From: james.wong@vesselbrokers.com
To: minh.nguyen@tradeco.com
Subject: Re: 12,000 DWT Coaster Availability Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:20
Body: Hi Minh,

Thank you for your inquiry. I can confirm we have a 12,000 DWT coaster available. The earliest possible loading date would be October 10th. However, please note that this slot is no longer available as of your inquiry time. The next available date would be November 10th.

We can discuss loading and discharge ports in more detail once you confirm your interest in the November slot.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Best regards,
James

From: alexander@company.com
To: xingxiao@freightbroker.com
Subject: Re: import from China to US ports
Timestamp: 2022-01-10 09:30
Body: Hi Xingxiao,

We're planning to ship a product of 15,000MT from China to US ports in two loads for a total of 30,000MT. I've attached the commodity profiles for your reference. Can you please provide the following information?

a. available delivery dates for each of the two loads, allowing 15 days for ship procurement
b. vessel sizes and speed
c. estimated price per metric ton, rate schedule, and bunkering options
d. estimated transit time from load port to discharge port
e. maximum permitted soil / soil contamination

---

From: alexander@company.com
To: xingxiao@freightbroker.com
Subject: RE: import from China to US ports
Timestamp: 2022-01-15 14:45
Body: Xingxiao,

Great news, we are fully booked from load port until 2022 for both 15,000MT loads. We've secured the vessel, and we'd like to offer you the low end of the range for the bunkering price.

Could you please provide the revised cost?

Thanks,
Alexander

---

From: xingxiao@freightbroker.com
To: alexander@company.com
Subject: RE: import from China to US ports
Timestamp: 2022-01-17 11:20
Body: Hi Alexander,

Unfortunately, this load is booked to August 2022. We can offer the following rate schedule:

$7.4 per metric ton on stevedore fees
+ 4% over base rate from bunkers
+ 3% load / discharge port fees

We can send the commercial invoice in two weeks

Thank you,
Xingxiao

---

To: xingxiao@freightbroker.com
Subject: RE: import from China to US ports
Timestamp: 2022-01-17 15:45
Body: Xingxiao,

Great! We'll go with the $7.4 flat rate.

Thanks,
Alexander

From: jorge.martinez@acmecorp.com
To: rob.wilson@brooker.com
Subject: Potential Acquisition Discussion
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Rob,

I've heard rumors that you are in talks to merge with Brooker Inc. We at our company have been following your success for a while now, and we're very interested in potentially acquiring your brokerage. I believe you could be an excellent addition to our organization.

Would you be open to discussing this opportunity?

Best regards,
Jorge

---

From: rob.wilson@brooker.com
To: jorge.martinez@acmecorp.com
Subject: Re: Potential Acquisition Discussion
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:45
Body: Jorge,

Thank you for your interest. I'd be happy to explore this possibility. Could you send me more information about your company and what you envision for this potential acquisition?

Regards,
Rob

---

From: jorge.martinez@acmecorp.com
To: rob.wilson@brooker.com
Subject: Re: Potential Acquisition Discussion
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 10:15
Body: Rob,

I will have our brokerage agreement drafted and sent to you within the next 3 days. We haven't discussed compensation yet, but I'm confident we can find terms that work for both parties.

Thanks for your prompt reply.

Best regards,
Jorge

Sent from my iPad

---

From: rob.wilson@brooker.com
To: jorge.martinez@acmecorp.com
Subject: Re: Potential Acquisition Discussion
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 15:30
Body: Jorge,

Regarding compensation, could you give me an idea of what kind of fee structure you're considering? I'd like to ensure we're working toward a mutually beneficial arrangement.

Also, I'm curious about your assessment of the local market conditions. We've been hearing concerns about a potential market correction in the near future.

Best regards,
Rob

---

From: jorge.martinez@acmecorp.com
To: rob.wilson@brooker.com
Subject: Re: Potential Acquisition Discussion
Timestamp: 2024-01-17 11:00
Body: Rob,

I've reviewed the numbers again, and while they're not quite where we'd like them to be, I still see great potential in this deal. As an alternative approach, I could come in as a silent partner initially, with the option to complete a full buyout later.

Could you share more detailed financial data for our first proper evaluation? I'm looking for a structure that ensures mutual benefit, not just increased sales figures.

Thanks again,
Jorge

Hi Mr. Chen,                    Could you advise freight for the following cargo?                    8,000MT of HFO from Dili to Sekondi, payable against B/L (FIO)                    7,500MT of Gasoil from Nosy Be to Tema, payable against B/L (FIO)                    Your kind response would be much appreciated.                    Sincerely,                    George
Email 2:
George:                    1 x CIF, or if direct berthing at the second port, 2 x CIF                    2 x FIO, no guarantee (C/P may be a good way to go?)                    Have a good evening.                    Larry
Email 3:
George:                    Geary Tankers B.V. does not have experience with HFO cargoes, but for comparison and reference, take a look at the following:                    Malange - Pointe Noire:                    1,500 tons HFO from Malange, Angola to Pointe Noire, Congo:                    CIF, double nomination in Porto Amboim.                    Earn $34,000, time charter at $22,000.                    If you want to book cargo at Rotterdam, I have several suggestions:                    HFO Rotterdam 9/24/2012 - 7,000 tons cargo, USD 33.75/MT, delivery Rotterdam.                    1,200 mt HFO, ex-shore Rotterdam, vessel at anchor, USD 34/mt, delivery Rotterdam.                    HFO Rotterdam 9/20/2012 - 4,000 mt HFO
Email 4:
George:                    Geary Tankers B.V. only had two oil contract cases in the past, one was for delivery of oil from Curacao to Pointe-a-Pitre in Guadeloupe. The other was for sale of oil from Fort-de-France in Martinique to Pointe-a-Pitre. According to our records, the former was for the sale of 2,000 mt HFO to the M/S Mayflower Bayside owned by Epsilon Tankers Corporation, T/A Mayflower Shipping Ltd. under terms CIF (with additional provisos, and legal issues) for delivery to a named port of discharge (Port Louis in Guadeloupe), with a named buyer (Epsilon Tankers Corporation). This sale, because of legal and other issues, was apparently not delivered by the vessel's Master (who was not named, but who sailed from Rotterdam on 9
output_text:
From: george.smith@trading.com
To: larry.chen@geary-tankers.com
Subject: Freight Rate Request - HFO and Gasoil Cargoes
Timestamp: 2012-09-18 09:30
Body: Hi Mr. Chen,

Could you please advise freight rates for the following cargo:

1. 8,000MT of HFO from Dili to Sekondi, payable against B/L (FIO)
2. 7,500MT of Gasoil from Nosy Be to Tema, payable against B/L (FIO)

Your kind response would be much appreciated.

Sincerely,
George

---

From: larry.chen@geary-tankers.com
To: george.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Freight Rate Request - HFO and Gasoil Cargoes
Timestamp: 2012-09-18 14:45
Body: Dear George,

For the first cargo: 1 x CIF, or if direct berthing at the second port, 2 x CIF
For the second cargo: 2 x FIO, no guarantee (Charter Party may be a good way to go?)

Have a good evening.

Larry

---

From: larry.chen@geary-tankers.com
To: george.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Freight Rate Request - HFO and Gasoil Cargoes
Timestamp: 2012-09-19 10:15
Body: Dear George,

Geary Tankers B.V. does not have direct experience with HFO cargoes, but for comparison and reference:

Recent comparable trade:
Malange - Pointe Noire
1,500 tons HFO
CIF, double nomination in Porto Amboim
Earnings: $34,000, time charter at $22,000

Current Rotterdam options:
- HFO Rotterdam 9/24/2012: 7,000 tons cargo, USD 33.75/MT
- 1,200 mt HFO, ex-shore Rotterdam, vessel at anchor, USD 34/mt
- HFO Rotterdam 9/20/2012: 4,000 mt HFO

Regards,
Larry

---

From: larry.chen@geary-tankers.com
To: george.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Freight Rate Request - HFO and Gasoil Cargoes
Timestamp: 2012-09-19 10:30
Body: Dear George,

For additional reference, Geary Tankers B.V. has handled only two oil contracts previously:

1. Delivery from Curacao to Pointe-a-Pitre, Guadeloupe
2. Sale from Fort-de-France, Martinique to Pointe-a-Pitre

The first case involved 2,000 mt HFO sold to M/S Mayflower Bayside (owned by Epsilon Tankers Corporation, T/A Mayflower Shipping Ltd.) under CIF terms for delivery to Port Louis, Guadeloupe. Note that this particular case involved some legal complications and was not completed.

Regards,
Larry

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Derek,                    We have received an inquiry for the movement of 15kMT of LPG from Spain to Mombasa in July. I would like to know if there is any availability for this shipment, and what your pricing will be. Could you let me know as soon as possible?                    Regards,                    Ajay
Email 2:
We have a possibility of a medium-term charter (about a month). LPG from Spain to Mombasa and TANZANIA. If you can have it please send all pricing, and detailed information regarding the ship and your management conditions. We are looking forward to your reply. Best regards, Joseph Tensu

**djagiad@gmail.com**
**djomson@hotmail.com**

Barter or similar type of shipping would be another way to get product, basically you are trading something for the shipping, typically a product that the shipper wants. 
I have not used this type of transaction so I don't know about the legalities or security in terms of the recipient. 
There are companies that specialize in these types of transactions so I would not recommend going it alone.
Email 3:
Re: Medium Term Charter in June
Dear Joseph,
We will be able to be ready to proceed with a 45-60 day charter in June for a vessel that can carry 5000mt LPG in cargo tanks. 
We are currently preparing our requirements list for an upcoming voyage with an LPG carrier that can carry 11,000mt LPG. 
Would you kindly send us a draft contract based on your voyage time,  LPG capacity and MT and your prices. 
For purposes of understanding your company and industry, we would like to know:
Are you an oil or chemical trader? How many days would the vessel be anchored prior to the loading port?
I look forward to your response. 
Best regards, Lisa
**taktaks@hotmant.com**

--- 
<Email 4>
taktaks@hotmant.com Re: 45-60 day

Hi Mr. Peter,                    We have a cargo to ship from Mundra to Long Beach. I do not anticipate any berth congestion in either port, but would you still please confirm that?                    Many thanks,                    Michael
Email 2:
Hi Michael,                  Hope you are well.                      As far as Mundra is concerned, there will be no berth congestion (whether it be monthly or weekly) in any month of this year.                 Regarding the port of Long Beach, the container volume is consistently increasing month on month. It will also increase in the coming month. However, we can see that in February 2019, there were 8 ETDs, whereas in January 2019 there were 7 ETDs. The transhipment movement from West Africa & other major US destinations to Long Beach will increase by more than 10% this year. Hence we may see less berth congestion in the months of January, February & March 2019. However, the probability of berth congestion in April and onward months is very high as long as the CBP do not relax any of their existing regulations to reduce the dwell
Email 3:

Email 4:
Hi
Kindly note the following changes in view of the proposed cut off 
· All STS, which were used in the past to eliminate congestion, will cease by end of March 2019. 
· Due to many more factors like larger volume, berth congestion & diversification, the terminal now prefers containers which are loaded on to wagons, trucks, rail heads, special containers (Transponders, Chilled, Refrigerated, etc.) as well as containers which are to be exported via Ocean Terminal, Pier 400, Long Beach Container Terminal (LBCT), ……………… the list goes on. 
· Longer term (year on year), terminal hopes that terminal will be able to achieve more in terms of more Gate out/container return, which is the only way the terminal will be able to handle more volume. 
· With the above changes, the terminal will be able to
output_text:
From: michael.smith@trading.com
To: peter.jones@shipping.com
Subject: Berth Congestion Query - Mundra to Long Beach
Timestamp: 2019-01-15 09:30
Body: Hi Mr. Peter,

We have a cargo to ship from Mundra to Long Beach. I do not anticipate any berth congestion in either port, but would you still please confirm that?

Many thanks,
Michael

---

From: peter.jones@shipping.com
To: michael.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Berth Congestion Query - Mundra to Long Beach
Timestamp: 2019-01-15 14:45
Body: Hi Michael,

Hope you are well.

As far as Mundra is concerned, there will be no berth congestion throughout this year.

Regarding Long Beach, container volume is increasing month on month. We've seen improvement in vessel turnaround with 8 ETDs in February compared to 7 in January 2019. While transhipment movement from West Africa & other major US destinations to Long Beach will increase by >10% this year, we expect minimal congestion in Q1 2019. However, starting April, congestion probability is high unless CBP relaxes current regulations affecting dwell times.

Best regards,
Peter

---

From: peter.jones@shipping.com
To: michael.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Berth Congestion Query - Mundra to Long Beach - Volume Data
Timestamp: 2019-01-16 10:15
Body: Hi Michael,

For your reference, here is the year-over-year volume comparison data for key arrivals:

ID       Type          Volume   Jan 2017   Jan 2018   Difference
TLG327   OFFD ANCHOR   LCL      185        445        +140
TLG062   OFFD ANCHOR   LCL      112        235        +123
TLG188   OFFD ANCHOR   LCL      100        165        +65
CMACTI   OFFD ANCHOR   LCL      151        165        +14

Best regards,
Peter

---

From: peter.jones@shipping.com
To: michael.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Berth Congestion Query - Mundra to Long Beach - Terminal Updates
Timestamp: 2019-01-16 10:30
Body: Hi Michael,

Please note these important terminal changes:

- All Ship-to-Ship (STS) operations will cease by end of March 2019
- Terminal is prioritizing containers for rail/truck transport, special containers (Transponders, Chilled, Refrigerated), and exports via Ocean Terminal, Pier 400, and LBCT
- Long-term focus is on improving gate out/container return efficiency to handle increased volume

Best regards,
Peter

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Jack,                    I’m trying to secure a spot for 20,000 MT of iron ore from Virginia to Turkey. After-hours berthing is an option, but we’re flexible. Could you get back to me with some options for the next week and next month?                    Thanks,                    Susanna
Email 2:
Just to follow up, we're still in need of options from Turkey. What do you suggest for a daily service to Turkey, starting next week? This is urgent.
    Dear Susanna,  
        Our liners operate out of Virginia, Houston and Long Beach, and to Istanbul, İzmir, Kütahya, and Antalya. We also have a weekly direct service to İzmir from Savannah. It’s a fast service, it takes about 14 days from loading in the US to discharging in Turkey. If you’re interested in shipping from Houston, it’s an 11 day trip to Antalya. All of these routes can be served from one of our 3 weekly services. For a monthly schedule, please visit our website. We don’t accept individual bookings, so you would need to find a freight forwarder or consolidator to place your booking.
    Jack

Timestamp: 2024-02-02 11:30
Body: Dear Susanna,

Our liners operate out of Virginia, Houston and Long Beach, and to Istanbul, İzmir, Kütahya, and Antalya. We also have a weekly direct service to İzmir from Savannah. It's a fast service, taking about 14 days from loading in the US to discharging in Turkey. If you're interested in shipping from Houston, it's an 11 day trip to Antalya.

All of these routes can be served from one of our 3 weekly services. For a monthly schedule, please visit our website. We don't accept individual bookings, so you would need to find a freight forwarder or consolidator to place your booking.

Regards,
Jack

- Rates and Pricing: This activity focuses on the exchange of information regarding the rate and pricing for the charter vessel. It involves discussions and proposals from the ship owner regarding the cost of the vessel, including any additional charges or fees.

- Arrival and Delivery: This activity deals with the transportation and delivery of the charter vessel from the ship owner to the designated location. It includes discussions about the schedule, loading and unloading

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Owen,                    Our Australian customer wants to ship some powdered milk from Port Botany in Sydney to Tokyo. The contract says 2,500MT, but they might also require 1,500MT of grain. This order will leave in the first week of July. We need your help.                    How much would shipping 4,000MT of both goods together cost, and do you see any risk of port congestion?                    Many thanks,                    Ivy
Email 2:
Hi Ivy,
Good morning.

The order for 2,500MT should be easy to manage.
Regarding the order for 1,500MT of grain, unfortunately, we do not see any vessel available to fit both cargoes in the same vessel. As we are still in June, there are still some free slots available on July, but as the order size is so big, we have limited choices.
That being said, we can manage to fit 1,000MT of milk powder and 1,500MT of grain in the same vessel with the owner of a 10,000dwt M/V which is due to discharge the previous cargo in July. All details about the vessel are as follows:

M/V T1
Type    General Cargo
Flag    Liberia
Call    MOYO
Deadweight    8,600MT
Built    1996
Hold No
Email 3:
Regarding the risk of port congestion in Australia, I'm afraid the situation is getting worse and that it may be difficult to find a slot for such a big order. Also, the railway terminals are overloaded as well.
I know the situation seems very bad. I can only offer you the best available. If you are willing to wait till October, I can offer you a better slot with more space. This way, you will be able to fit more products, or reduce the price.
What do you think?
Email 4:
Thank you for your help. The information you provided is very useful to us. 
We want to ship the 4,000MT cargo in early July. We do not have enough storage capacity, so if we delay the delivery, it may lead to the depreciation of our goods, so I'm afraid we can only choose the original plan.
Also, we will have more orders to deliver in July. Can you please help us?
Waiting for your reply!
Regards,
Ivy
Best regards,
Martin
Email 5:
Hi Ivy,

I understand that you have to deliver the order at the earliest opportunity, and that you can't wait till October. I'll look for a slot in September for you.

Please find attached a quotation for 3,000MT and 4,000MT. We can ship 1,000MT in July and 2,000MT or 3,000MT in August. I can fit 2,000MT on a 6,000dwt M/V which is due to discharge in September and 3,000MT on a 6,500dwt M/V which is due to discharge in September as well.

Do you have a choice of milk powder or grain as the cargo to be shipped in August?
Thank you.

Regards,
Martin

Our Australian customer wants to ship some powdered milk from Port Botany in Sydney to Tokyo. The contract says 2,500MT, but they might also require 1,500MT of grain. This order will need to leave in the first week of July.

The order for 2,500MT should be manageable. However, regarding the combined shipment with 1,500MT of grain, we cannot find a vessel available to accommodate both cargoes together. While there are still some free slots in July, the total order size limits our options.

We can offer to fit 1,000MT of milk powder and 1,500MT of grain on a 10,000dwt vessel that will complete its previous cargo discharge in July. The vessel details are:

M/V T1

Flag: Liberia
Call Sign: MOYO
Deadweight: 8,600MT
Built: 1996

Best regards,
Owen

---

From: owen.martin@shipbroker.com
To: ivy.chen@tradeco.com
Subject: Re: Shipping Query - Milk Powder & Grain from Sydney to Tokyo
Timestamp: 2023-06-25 14:45
Body: Ivy,

I should add that port congestion in Australia is worsening, and securing a slot for such a large order may be challenging. The railway terminals are also experiencing overload.

If you can wait until October, I can offer a better slot with more space, which would allow for more cargo capacity or a reduced price.

Please let me know your thoughts.

Best regards,
Owen

---

From: ivy.chen@tradeco.com
To: owen.martin@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: Shipping Query - Milk Powder & Grain from Sydney to Tokyo

Thank you for the detailed information. We need to proceed with shipping the 4,000MT cargo in early July as we don't have sufficient storage capacity. Delaying the delivery could lead to product depreciation, so we'll need to stick with the original timeline.

Additionally, we will have more orders to deliver in July. Can you please assist with those as well?

Looking forward to your reply.

Best regards,
Ivy

---

From: owen.martin@shipbroker.com
To: ivy.chen@tradeco.com
Subject: Re: Shipping Query - Milk Powder & Grain from Sydney to Tokyo

I understand your urgency and inability to wait until October. I can propose the following solution:

- Ship 1,000MT in July
- Ship either 2,000MT or 3,000MT in August

Could you specify whether you prefer to ship the milk powder or grain portion in August?

Regards,
Owen

To: steve.wilson@trading.com
Subject: Charles proposal
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Dear Steve,

I'd like to discuss your shipping requirements and provide a quote. Could you please provide details on:

- Carrier and Charterer requirements
- Ship type preferences
- Feeder line specifications
- Nominated vessel details
- Berth and draft requirements
- Cargo quantity
- Destination port
- Expected arrival time
- Delivery terms
- Payment terms
- Laytime specifications
- Harbor and L/D charges
- Line speed requirements
- Chargeable weight
- Discharge delivery details

As an economist with extensive industry connections, I can ensure you get the best possible arrangements. Looking forward to assisting you with this business.

Best regards,
Charles

---

To: charles.broker@maritime-services.com
Subject: Re: Charles proposal
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45

1. Insurance coverage scope for this shipment
2. Final pricing and terms

Rob

---

The pricing terms are as discussed. Regarding insurance, please note that our policy does not include cargo loss coverage. You can review the full policy here: https://uploads-ssl.webflow.com/5f0f50a4d746a5642fe1f64a/5f4f66f7d957cd00018cd78e_Ship_the_box_Insurance_Policy.pdf

2. Submit details to my agents for processing

Best regards,
Charles

input_text:
Email 1:
<BEGIN EMAIL C>                    Ms. Stevens:                    I will be at your office tomorrow for 30 minutes. Please let me know if you're free or if you want to meet elsewhere.                    Sincerely,                    Nastya
Email 2:
<BEGIN EMAIL C>                    I'm totally free tomorrow. See you tomorrow!                    Sincerely,                    Nastya

One of my workmates asked me how to answer this email. I am not sure myself. I've answered questions like these one here, but they were much more easy:

1)  Say good night to Mommy!
2)  Well, take your time!
3)  Of course I'll help you. When and where?
4)  That sounds great! I'll bring the umbrella.
5)  I know. It is not important.

What is the correct way to answer to Nastya in this email?

There is a pattern for this type of 2-part email that I've observed in some specific contexts:

1. The first part is like a sign-off: "Sincerely, Nastya". 2. The second part is the
Email 3:
<My name here> looks forward to your response.
<Email 4>:
<My name here> looks forward to speaking with you further.
<Email 5>:
<My name here> looks forward to meeting with you.
<Email 6>:
<My name here> looks forward to your call.
<Email 7>:
<My name here> looks forward to learning more about your situation.


This usage appears to be common in the auto industry, with online car reviews.

Here is a blog post on this, which cites a data-driven analysis from a company called Radian6:

https://hbr.org/2013/01/the-secret-language-of-email

If we take that at face value, then one possible answer to the email in the question is:

[EMAIL 8]
Please let me know if you're free or if you want to meet elsewhere.
[EMAIL 9]
Email 4:
<My name here> looks forward to speaking with you further.
<Email 5>:
<My name here> looks forward to meeting with you.
<Email 6>:
<My name here> looks forward to your call.
<Email 7>:
<My name here> looks forward to learning more about your situation.

https://hbr.org/2013/01/the-secret-language-of-email

If we take that at face value, then one possible answer to the email in the question is:

[EMAIL 8]
Please let me know if you're free or if you want to meet elsewhere.
[EMAIL 9]

<Email 4>:
 We look forward to learning more about your situation.

Dear <CLIENT>:

Thank you for your interest in our firm. We are a small law firm, with a strong emphasis on the practice of probate law. Although we have limited practice areas, we pride ourselves on our ability to represent our clients in all of those areas. The focus of our practice is probate law, but because probate is only part of an estate administration, we take special care in involving other attorneys or accountants if a client requires assistance outside of our areas of expertise.

As the firm continues to grow, our practice areas have grown as well. My colleague, <NAME> , specializes in all aspects of estate planning, including wills, trusts, and financial planning. Please feel free to contact <NAME> directly if you have any questions regarding estate planning.

Email 2:
We need to ship 2,200MT of palm oil from Lagos to Cape Town. 
---
## First email
Let's see if I can summarize this in plain English:
We want to ship 2,200 metric tons of palm oil from Lagos, Nigeria to Cape Town, South Africa.
It looks like we've got a problem with Friday loadings, though.
So we should make sure we let the office in Lagos know ASAP. 
We'll keep you posted. 

## Second email
We are writing in response to your email asking about the 2,200 metric tons of palm oil shipment from Lagos to Cape Town. 
We are still waiting to hear back from the Lagos office. 
As soon as we do, we will let you know ASAP. 
We will also let you know about the loading schedule and the potential fees for Friday loadings. 
We want to make

input_text:
Email 1:
We're considering a very large cargo of 1,000,000MT of coal from Barry to Alexandria. Can you advise any open charters that would be suitable for this cargo?                                        Sincerely,                    George
Email 2:
Hello, George
I have received your e-mail. Thanks for asking us for this enquiry.
This is my first reply to you.

First of all, can you give me the type of coal you plan to ship (NSC, ARA, etc.) and also the port of loading at Barry (BPT, UKCOAL, etc.)

The best way is to proceed with time charter.
Most of shipping companies are hard to find the right vessel because of a lack of high specification open cargo handlings. However, I can check and suggest you to you.
I will try to provide you the following details:
1. The vessel that is available in market
2. The cost estimate

Please feel free to contact me anytime and I will be delighted to be of assistance.
Thank you very much.
Kind regards,

Noah

Cape Shipping Ltd.
Email 3:
Thanks, Noah. Barry Port (BPT) handle mainly ARA coal.            I look forward to your reply.                    George
<Email 4>:
Hello George,
Thank you for your reply.

Currently, there is a lot of vessels available in the market. But most of them are low specification and the area of coverage can't fit with your requirement.
However, we may be able to find a vessel that suits your requirement.

If it is no problem, can you give me the delivery port of discharge (namely, the name of the country of discharge).

And also, can you specify the size of the vessel you are looking for?

Waiting for your reply.                            Noah
<Email 5>:
Hi, Noah.
I can do both.
A port of discharge is Alexandria. I need a vessel of 80,000MT DWT, plus 10,000

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Ms. Morris,                    We have an enquiry for 13,000MT of rice from Colombo to Matadi. Can you give us a berth congestion forecast and how does your laytime allowance work in case of port delays?                    Many thanks,                    Robert
Email 2:
Matadi is a very busy port with cargoes often backed up at berth. There is no guaranteed transit time to discharge ships. It is typical for ships to be waiting in line from 2-4 days to get to berth and there is not a predictable number of ships in line to discharge as ships can come at any time without warning.
                
                It is typical to run back up and sometimes 2 berths simultaneously. When two berths are available, the berthing order is typically handled by the Terminal based on when the ship can reach the berth. In the event that your vessel can reach the berth on the day that is scheduled for your vessel, your berth time will likely be honored. If you are late due to port congestion and cannot reach the berth that is reserved for you, your berth may be given to another ship and you will have to wait in line for the next
output_text:
From: robert.smith@tradingco.com
To: morris.sarah@portops.com
Subject: Rice Shipment to Matadi - Berth Congestion Query
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 09:23
Body: Hi Ms. Morris,

We have an enquiry for 13,000MT of rice from Colombo to Matadi. Can you give us a berth congestion forecast and how does your laytime allowance work in case of port delays?

Many thanks,
Robert

---

From: morris.sarah@portops.com
To: robert.smith@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Rice Shipment to Matadi - Berth Congestion Query
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 11:45
Body: Dear Robert,

Matadi is currently experiencing high congestion levels. Please note the following:

- Typical waiting time for berth is 2-4 days
- No guaranteed transit time to discharge
- Berth queue is unpredictable as vessels can arrive without prior notice
- Terminal operates up to 2 berths simultaneously
- Berthing priority is assigned by the Terminal based on vessel readiness
- Reserved berth slots may be reassigned if vessel arrival is delayed due to congestion

I recommend factoring these conditions into your laytime calculations.

Best regards,
Sarah Morris

Mr.

Hi Jeremy,                   Thank you for the detailed information. The Port of Elizabeth is basically a bit “rustic”. Most of the coal is stored at berths which are up the hill or out of the water in a kind of side-loading facility. The coal berths are essentially ash ponds that are filled from barges, loaded from stockpiles, or loaded by rail. In any case, the coal must be transported in some way and the loading will depend on the coal berth. The average loading rate is between 600-800 mt/h, and with no draft restrictions or berthing limitations, we are expected to load at an average rate of 1500 mt/h. We can also do up to 2,000 mt/h if the coal can be delivered to the berth quickly and easily.

Be advised that in March, the water in the port will be very low. Because of

Subject: Coal Cargo Inquiry - Port Elizabeth to Venice
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 09:30
Body: Hey Jeremy,

I have a 5,000MT cargo of coal from Port Elizabeth to Venice. The cargo is ready to load in the first week of March, and I don't have any preference on the vessel. If you happen to have an opening next month, I'd like to do it with you!

Please keep in mind that the vessel's turnaround time in Venice is only 3 days.

Regards,
Brian

From: jeremy.wilson@shipowner.com
To: brian.smith@trader.com
Subject: Re: Coal Cargo Inquiry - Port Elizabeth to Venice
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 11:45
Body: Hi Brian,

No issues, I can make it by mid-March. The vessel will arrive at Port Elizabeth on the 9th, load the cargo on the 10th, and sail immediately. How is your schedule? We can meet on the water on March 9th and the vessel will be anchored outside the port for your cargo.

Can you give me the terminal requirements?

Thanks,
Jeremy

From: brian.smith@trader.com
To: jeremy.wilson@shipowner.com
Subject: Re: Coal Cargo Inquiry - Port Elizabeth to Venice

Brian

From: jeremy.wilson@shipowner.com

Timestamp: 2024-02-15 14:45
Body: Hi Brian,

Here are the vessel details:
MV WIDE BEAM 01 (Built 2013)

Jeremy

---

From: brian.smith@trader.com
To: jeremy.wilson@shipowner.com
Subject: Re: Coal Cargo Inquiry - Port Elizabeth to Venice
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 16:30
Body: Hi Jeremy,

Thank you for the details. Regarding Port Elizabeth terminal requirements: The port is quite basic, with coal stored at berths up the hill or in side-loading facilities. Loading is done via ash ponds filled from barges, stockpiles, or rail. Average loading rate is 600-800 mt/h, but we can achieve up to 1,500 mt/h under optimal conditions, potentially reaching 2,000 mt/h if coal delivery to berth is efficient.

Please note that March will have low water levels in the port.

Best regards,
Brian

Email 1:
Hi Yasmina,                    We have 7.4kMT of base oil ready in Malta and is it ready for a shipment to Yemen? How long would it take to prepare the necessary documents and can you accept delivery within 48 hours?                    Yours sincerely,                    Mabena
Email 2:
Hi Mabena,                    Thank you for your email.                    Unfortunately, the Yemen Embassy in Malta does not accept any application. For a visa application, you must go through the company you are working for or a company that will sponsor your trip.                    Yours sincerely,                    Yasmina
Email 3:
```Hi,             

Thanks for the info about the company but there are only two people in Malta and they are both married. For the company, what if I am not working for it? But the company can be the sponsor for me to get the Yemen visa. Can you tell me who to get in contact with? Do you know any sponsor company that I can contact?                    Yours sincerely,                    Mabena
```
Email 4:
Thanks for the info, I’ll go there today and I will also go to the embassy to make some enquiries.                        Regards,                    Mabena
```
Email 5:
```Hi Yasmina,                        

I was in Malta yesterday. I went to the embassy and the people there are kind. They have informed me that I don’t need any sponsor. But to get a visa it costs 118 USD.                            Hope this information helps you.                            Yours sincerely,                        

                            Mabena
```
output_text:
From: mabena.trading@company.com
To: yasmina.shipping@company.com
Subject: Base Oil Shipment to Yemen - Documentation Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Hi Yasmina,

We have 7.4kMT of base oil ready in Malta and looking to arrange shipment to Yemen. How long would it take to prepare the necessary documents and can you accept delivery within 48 hours?

Yours sincerely,
Mabena

---

From: yasmina.shipping@company.com
To: mabena.trading@company.com
Subject: Re: Base Oil Shipment to Yemen - Documentation Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Hi Mabena,

Thank you for your email.

Unfortunately, the Yemen Embassy in Malta does not accept direct applications. For the required documentation, you must process this through your employing company or a sponsoring company.

Yours sincerely,
Yasmina

---

From: mabena.trading@company.com
To: yasmina.shipping@company.com
Subject: Re: Base Oil Shipment to Yemen - Documentation Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:20
Body: Hi Yasmina,

Thanks for the information. There are only two company representatives in Malta and they're both unavailable. What if I'm not employed directly by the company? Can a sponsor company assist with the Yemen documentation? Do you know any sponsor companies I could contact?

Yours sincerely,
Mabena

---

From: mabena.trading@company.com
To: yasmina.shipping@company.com
Subject: Re: Base Oil Shipment to Yemen - Documentation Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 08:15
Body: Thanks for the info, I'll visit both the company office and embassy today to make some enquiries.

Regards,
Mabena

---

From: mabena.trading@company.com
To: yasmina.shipping@company.com
Subject: Re: Base Oil Shipment to Yemen - Documentation Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-17 09:00
Body: Hi Yasmina,

I visited the embassy in Malta yesterday. The staff were very helpful and informed me that no sponsor is actually needed. The visa cost is 118 USD.

Hope this information helps you.

Yours sincerely,
Mabena

Subject: Quote Request - Apparel Shipment Manchester to Brussels

Body: Armin,

I'm looking for a quote to ship 11,400MT of high-end apparel from Manchester to Brussels in early August. The cut off for payment is August 3.

Are you able to accept payment?

Let me know if you need anything else.

All the best,
Clark

---

From: clark.wilson@freightbroker.com
To: armin.mueller@logistics.com
Subject: Re: Quote Request - Insurance Requirements
Timestamp: 2023-07-25 11:30
Body: Armin,

The client would like the following insurance coverage:

a) Public Liability – not applicable
b) Cargo – cover for theft and damage, cover for transshipment risks and moisture damages. Cover for a wider risk (negligence of carriers, transport etc.) - Paying shipper
c) Marine – cover for theft and damage. Cover for a wider risk (negligence of carriers, transport etc.) - Shipper is not paying

Your advice?

Thanks,
Clark

---

Clark

All the best,
Clark

Dear Ms. Bennett,                    As a stevedore, you have access to ample cranes and loading equipment, but most shipping companies prefer to hire their own personnel for discharge. For example, we have a reputation for working fast at berthing and cargo operations, ensuring both your berthing rights and a successful shipment.                    What’s your experience with crane capacity at your ports, and can you give an estimate on service time for ships 2,600 meters and 6,500m³ cargo capacity?                    Thank you,                    Edward
Email 2:
From: Edward Subject: Length and Capacity Date: Friday, October 14, 2022 at 10:59 AM To: Ms. Bennett Dear Ms. Bennett,                    Thanks for your reply. It looks like neither your terminal nor mine has cranes strong enough to handle such large ships. But we do have a lot of common interests with the island of Grande Comore. For example, we can both benefit from using a reputable port with quality equipment and speedy service, as well as avoiding overloading.                    The solution is to find a company that can efficiently load the cargo. Most shipping companies prefer to hire their own personnel for discharge because their ships require a high level of attention. The only problem is that many stevedoring companies are not experienced in unloading large ships. And that’s why we need your help.                    Would you be interested in becoming a member of our team and

From: Ms. Bennett
Hi Edward,

They are also one of the fastest ports in the world and have an average unloading time of 15 minutes per ship.

Cory

From: edward.smith@logisticspro.com
To: cory.bennett@portservices.com
Subject: Port Equipment and Service Time Inquiry
Timestamp: 2022-10-14 09:30
Body: Dear Ms. Bennett,

As a stevedore, you have access to ample cranes and loading equipment, but I understand most shipping companies prefer to hire their own personnel for discharge. We have a reputation for working fast at berthing and cargo operations, ensuring both berthing rights and successful shipments.

What's your experience with crane capacity at your ports, and can you give an estimate on service time for ships 2,600 meters and 6,500m³ cargo capacity?

Thank you,
Edward

---

From: edward.smith@logisticspro.com
To: cory.bennett@portservices.com
Subject: Re: Length and Capacity
Timestamp: 2022-10-14 10:59
Body: Dear Ms. Bennett,

Thanks for your reply. It appears neither your terminal nor mine has cranes strong enough to handle such large ships. However, we share common interests regarding Grande Comore operations. We both prioritize using reputable ports with quality equipment and speedy service while avoiding overloading.

We need to find a company that can efficiently handle the cargo, as most shipping companies prefer their own discharge personnel due to specialized requirements. Would you be interested in collaborating with our team to find a solution?

Best regards,
Edward

---

From: cory.bennett@portservices.com
To: edward.smith@logisticspro.com
Subject: Re: Length and Capacity
Timestamp: 2022-10-14 12:38
Body: Hi Edward,

What about using a multi-purpose dock, such as Port Natal? They have the most advanced docking equipment and their crews are very experienced. They are also one of the fastest ports in the world with an average unloading time of 15 minutes per ship.

Alternatively, we could consider a third-party port. I know a company called 'Aloha Stevedoring' who can handle your requirements. They have an excellent reputation with top-tier facilities.

All the best,
Cory

---

From: edward.smith@logisticspro.com
To: cory.bennett@portservices.com
Subject: Re: Third-party option
Timestamp: 2022-10-14 15:58
Body: Hi Cory,

I've been discussing this with a contact near our terminal. They've just opened a new facility in the Philippines that can handle vessels of 2,600 meters and 6,500m³ cargo capacity. They're looking to expand operations and are seeking quality partnerships.

I believe they would be interested in working with you. If you'd like to speak with them directly, please let me know.

Best regards,
Edward

---

From: cory.bennett@portservices.com
To: edward.smith@logisticspro.com
Subject: Re: Third-party option
Timestamp: 2022-10-15 09:00
Body: Hi Edward,

I'm actually in the Philippines myself, which is quite fortunate. My company can offer competitive rates and premium service for your cargo handling needs. We should discuss specific loading rates and service terms.

Looking forward to your reply.

Best regards,
Cory

Email 1:
Good day,                    Would you be able to handle a 2,000MT cargo of oil from Singapore to Hamburg next month?                    Thanks,                    Anthony
Email 2:
Good day Anthony,                    Below are some prelim. info for your consideration.                    We are in need of a shipment of Fuel Oil (0.5% Sulphur) with 180day Bunker credit at Hamburg.                    Time charter please for the above.                    Let me have a TEU count please, we may be able to fix a further vessel for containers to follow.                    We would also need following documentation sent by DHL express on the morning the vessel is due to berth:                    a) Invoices for cargo                    b) B/L’s (Blanket basis)                    c) Inspection Certificate                    d) Agency Copy of manifest                    e) Charter Party                    Let me know what you suggest.                    I can be contacted as follows:                    Email:address@hidden                    Or direct by Tel No: +852 2869 2131 (Direct).                    Thanks,                    Anthony
Email 3:
Good day,                    Would you be able to handle a 2,000MT cargo of oil from Singapore to Hamburg next month?                    Thanks,                    Anthony

Came from:                    Anne Dear                  Received by:                    William Lee

Response 1:
Okay..                     2000 MT Fuel Oil @0.5% sulphur for charter to Hamburg with 180 days bunkers credit can be arranged.                     Let me know your detailed charterparty conditions and details.                     For the charterparty conditions, I propose the usual terms and conditions.                     Your vessel must be compliant to the MARPOL 73/78 with equipment for the separation of oily waste and to dispose of waste at sea, alternatively, a system capable of containing, recovering, and subsequently processing the oily residue on board.                     Vessel must be certified as per MARPOL 73/78.                     Your vessel shall be sea worthy

Dear Mr Steffes,                      Our Hamburg South America Line was approached by your agents E  \& T             Group to transport iron ore from Indonesia to South America.                 You are hereby invited to send your offers for the transport of 20,000mt of iron ore, with a laycan from 1st August to the beginning of September.                 The main characteristics are as follows:                      - the load will be from the Sumatra region                      - the cargo will be iron ore of Fe 62%                      - the discharge port is to be selected and confirmed by the buyer                 Please send all offers on a non-negotiable basis (ex works) in USD based on the FOB Hamburg price of iron ore (ie, US$78/mt). Sorry for the delay in getting back to you. We’ve been dealing with an issue concerning the vessels’ bills of lading. 
I understand your cargo will be subject to an inspection at the port of discharge.  Since this is out of our control, you should contact your 
broker or agent to determine the inspection’s requirements, including duration and time of day for the inspection.  The bill of lading, while you 
were out, contained a statement stating we were responsible for the inspection's duration.  We subsequently deleted that paragraph.
We understand your client will be taking full responsibility for their merchandise at the port of discharge. Therefore, they should assume responsibility 
for ensuring that their merchandise clears customs.  We understand that you are working with our agent at the port of discharge to file the necessary documents 
to clear the cargo.  However, if you encounter any problems, please feel
Email 4:
I hope you’re well.
                 The client has changed the discharge port from Hamburg to Antwerp, Belgium.  Unfortunately, we had to sign a bill of lading without 
notifying you because the cargo was already on board and sailing.  We will now follow your advice and contact our agent at the port of 
discharge to make sure all of the necessary documents are filed in order to clear the cargo.
                 As requested, I will also forward a copy of the bill of lading to you and hope to have a firm confirmation of the inspection schedule 
for the cargo.
                 Regards,

Hi Stanley,

---

From: jake.mueller@hamburgsa.com
To: stanley.chen@etgroup.com
Subject: Re: Iron Ore Shipment Inquiry - Sumatra to Suez
Timestamp: 2023-07-15 14:45
Body: Dear Mr. Chen,

Thank you for your inquiry through E&T Group regarding iron ore transport from Indonesia.

We can offer transport for 20,000mt of iron ore (Fe 62%) with a laycan from 1st August to 1st September. Loading will be from the Sumatra region.

Please note that all offers should be made on a non-negotiable basis (ex works) in USD, based on the FOB Hamburg price of iron ore (US$78/mt).

Kindly let us know if you would like to proceed with freight and sailing cost details.

Best regards,
Jake Mueller

---

From: jake.mueller@hamburgsa.com
To: stanley.chen@etgroup.com
Subject: Re: Iron Ore Shipment Inquiry - Inspection Requirements
Timestamp: 2023-07-20 11:20
Body: Dear Stanley,

Apologies for the delay. We've been addressing issues with bills of lading.

Regarding the cargo inspection at discharge port, this will need to be arranged through your broker or agent. We've removed the clause making us responsible for inspection duration from the bill of lading.

Please note that your client will be responsible for customs clearance at the discharge port. We understand you're working with our port agent on documentation, but please let us know if you need any assistance.

Best regards,
Jake

---

To: jake.mueller@hamburgsa.com
Subject: Re: Discharge Port Change - Antwerp
Timestamp: 2023-07-25 16:15

Please send us a copy of the bill of lading when possible, and we await confirmation of the inspection schedule.

Regards,
Stanley

---

Subject: Re: Cargo Clearance Confirmation

Body: Hi Stanley,

Our agent in Antwerp has confirmed that all necessary documents have been filed and the cargo is cleared.

The inspection is scheduled for tomorrow morning at 9 AM.

I will forward the bill of lading copy shortly.

Regards,
Jake

Email 1:
Hello Sir,                    Do you think a big container ship will be built in China? Is it better to own a small ship or to own an interest in a large container ship?                    Thank you,                    Andre
Email 2:
Dear Sir,
Since my last letter, I have been reading a
book on Containership Business and i have a
lot of ideas.
Here is one of them. Will a large container
ship be built in China? Is it a good
investment to own a small container ship or
to own an interest in a large ship? I
believe that the container shipping industry
will get better and better. At this time, the
shipping market is very strong.
Here is the conclusion:
It is better to own a small container ship
than to own an interest in a large container
ship. We should stick to our belief.
Thank you,
Andre
Email 3:
Dear Sir,
Since my last letter, I have been reading a
book on the Container Business and
understanding the idea. After a lot of
thinking, I found a logical solution.
It is better to own a small container ship
than to own an interest in a large container
ship. That is the truth. We can be more
stable in the long run.
Please do not forget what I have said. I am
waiting for your reply.
Thank you,
Andre

Andre

---

From: juan.dupreez@umschlagskontor.de
To: john.doe@trading.com
Subject: Re: Fresh Fruit Shipment Inquiry - South Africa to Antwerp
Timestamp: 2005-11-15 14:45
Body: Dear John,

As you are aware, we regularly ship fresh produce from South Africa to Antwerp. We currently have two vessels loading with scheduled departures next week. Should your preferred vessel not be available, we can offer alternatives.

I have attached a charter summary for your reference, including our standard rates as requested.

Additionally, we understand the time-sensitive nature of your cargo. Our office maintains a well-equipped laboratory for testing, and we can arrange for one of our freight inspectors to verify cargo condition in cooperation with our certified biological agency.

Best regards,

Umschlagskontor

---

From: nicol.kohn@schiffahrtkontor.de
To: john.doe@trading.com
Subject: Re: Fresh Fruit Shipment Inquiry - South Africa to Antwerp
Timestamp: 2005-12-01 10:15
Body: Dear John,

We confirm receipt of your inquiry regarding vessel availability for December 1st loading. While we are currently at full capacity, the voyage duration is only 21 days, and we expect our southbound vessel to return promptly for potential charter.

Please contact either Mr. Du Preez or myself to discuss this further.

Best regards,
Nicol Kohn
Schiffahrtkontor

---

Subject: Re: Fresh Fruit Shipment Inquiry - South Africa to Antwerp
Timestamp: 2005-12-02 16:30
Body: Dear John,

We regret to inform you that the vessel 'Daanen de Jong' has been detained by USCG in New York. Given the current congestion in Antwerp, we recommend considering an earlier departure.

Unfortunately, our southbound vessel 'Baedeker' has been chartered by our German branch for a US-bound voyage.

The vessel 'Winkelhuis' is loaded and scheduled to depart on December 5th. Our dispatch department is actively seeking temporary alternatives given the urgency. I have attached a chart for your reference.

Please advise on your intentions at your earliest convenience.

Regards,
Nicol Kohn

Our company can offer competitive shipping costs and services for transporting Ethanol to Montevideo, Uruguay. We are happy to provide more information and a detailed quote upon request.

input_text:
Email 1:
We’re thinking of shipping 9,000MT of crude oil from Jingtang to Spain. What’s your earliest availability, and how’s your rate?                    Thanks,                    Tim
Email 2:
Our rate is USD35 per MT, cargo shall load at Jingtang Oil Terminal on 12/15 Dec, ETA Spain on 17/25 Dec, you could confirm the charter today or not later than tomorrow.  Please email back your interest, thanks!

The timer I chose was 5 minutes. And the prompt was:

How did you come up with the shipping contract?

You can use PNP to shorten the time for expression. For example, to say

"we are thinking of shipping X amount of crude oil from A to B", "We'd like to buy X amount of crude oil from A to B", etc.

The PNP here is the “thinking of shipping”, “wanting to buy”, and the rest of the action words.

Since we were looking for clues on who had expressed interest in the cargo (Tim or Spain), this definitely should give you some

Q&A What’s the best time to use balticdirties?
When to use balticdirties ? Use balticdirties only if no other time charter data is available (e.g. in freight rate calculations). Typically, the day and time you check are important (e.g. if there is a tidal window). Do not use balticdirties in company charter party clauses if you have a term charter party clause. From: elio.martinez@company.com
To: transport.services@logistics.com
Subject: RoRo Transport Request Turkey to Germany
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:23
Body: Hey! I'd like to book a RoRo truck, 26 meters with 4 axles, for transport from Turkey to Germany. Could you please provide more information about availability and requirements? Thanks, Elio

---

From: transport.services@logistics.com
To: elio.martinez@company.com
Subject: Re: RoRo Transport Request Turkey to Germany
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 10:45
Body: Hello Elio, We currently have different truck options available, but not exactly what you're requesting. We have RoRo trucks from Holland to South Africa (3 axles), and 16-meter trucks with 3 axles serving Holland-Morocco and Holland-Romania routes. Could you please provide the dimensions of your cargo? This will help us determine if we can accommodate your transport needs.

---

From: elio.martinez@company.com
To: transport.services@logistics.com
Subject: Re: RoRo Transport Request Turkey to Germany
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:30
Body: Thanks! The cargo dimensions are: 9.56m length x 2.5m width x 3.8m height, with an empty weight of 2800 kg. We need to transport a centrifuge system that's too long for a standard 20-foot container. Thank you for your help. Elio

---

From: transport.services@logistics.com
To: elio.martinez@company.com
Subject: Re: RoRo Transport Request Turkey to Germany
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 13:15
Body: Dear Elio, Unfortunately, we cannot accommodate this transport request. The centrifuge system's total weight of 35,000 kg exceeds our equipment capabilities. Our 3-axle trucks have a maximum capacity of 28 tons, and while a 4-axle truck would be needed for your 36-ton load, we don't currently have 40-ton capacity vehicles in our fleet. I apologize we couldn't be of more assistance. Please let us know if you need any other information.

Dear Zara,                    Hello. We can load the gasoline at Jubail April 15th. What can you do about voyage charter terms?                    Regards,                    James                    NOTE: A typical voyage charter (demurrage) contract has 24 hours as the benchmark for demurrage/laytime (load time to commence). Beyond this point the charterer becomes liable for demurrage for each day over the 24 hour benchmark.                    Now reply to Email C in the same style.                    Email D:                    Dear Captain Ford,                    I have noted your early availability and am trying to find if any interest at this time for gasoline from Jubail. What’s your freight?                    Regards,                    Mona                    NOTE: Fuel oil is 100% payment by letter of credit, so the freight clause has no significance.                    In the next step, you’ll learn about the typical documentation
Email 2:
Email 2
We can deliver the gasoline on a 35 day FOB basis but can supply a voyage charter at 35 days’ notice for what we can supply. Our freight is 3,000 to 3,200 free on board Rotterdam.                    I await your response.                    NOTE: The 3,200 FOB figure is a way of saying they can load the fuel oil at Jubail April 15th (35 days’ notice from your date) for a freight of 3,200 free on board Rotterdam (3,200 $per metric ton from Jubail to Rotterdam), provided they are given a voyage charter (time charter for fuel oil). The 35-day notice FOB is your way of saying they cannot get a voyage charter or that it takes 35 days to get a voyage charter. 3,200$ fob Rotterdam would only be a loading
Email 3:
Email 3
We would like to confirm the price of the gasoline of 80,000 metric tons CIF Rotterdam at 7,000$per metric ton. What is your availability for the gasoline? Regarding the freight and voyage charter, we can arrange this later, if you accept the price. Please advise, my colleague wants to confirm your price and he expects to hear from you soon. NOTE: You want to confirm the price of the gasoline, which you did by saying “80,000 metric tons CIF Rotterdam at 7,000$ per metric ton.” By offering “What is your availability for the gasoline?” you are showing that you are serious about the gasoline. You are also giving the impression that it is the principal who is asking, and thus playing into the principal’s ego, which you did by saying, “My colleague wants to confirm your price and he expects to hear from
Email 4:
Dear Mona, We are sorry to learn that you cannot arrange our gasoline supply via FOB Rotterdam. We understand your position and are willing to load the gasoline in 35 days and on a voyage charter for what we can supply. However, to meet your request, our principal would like to buy the gasoline on a 25 day FOB basis, but we would like to know that you will accept the price of 7,000$per metric ton. You may offer CIF Rotterdam in place of FOB Rotterdam at no increase in freight. Our principal expects to hear from you soon and prefers payment by letter of credit. We have noted your availability for April 15th. NOTE: At the start, you’re again trying to show that you’re serious about the gasoline by saying “We are sorry to learn that you cannot arrange our gasoline supply via FOB Rotterdam,” “We have noted your

Email 1:
Afternoon Mr. Saeed,                    We have a 5,000MT parcel of equipment to move from Montevideo to Isla Margarita, could you send a freight quote for me?                    Regards,                    Lacey
Email 2:
Hi Lacey!                                A good afternoon to you,                            As you see, we have received the message from
Peter regarding this move.                            We are now working on this.                           As soon as the details are ready we will send you the quotation.
                            Sorry for the delay, we are in the middle of a short holiday.
                            We will be happy to offer you the best solution for your cargo.
                            Best regards
                            Joseline
Email 3:
Hi Lacey!
I attach the quotation for your review.
Best regards.
You will remember that I sent you a quotation some days ago for
the shipment from Montevideo to the Vargas Free Zone (Isla Margarita,
Venezuela). I attach it for your review.
As I explained to you, your freight forwarder is using the
transportation of a passenger vessel for which they charge you a huge
amount of money (of course with a very high margin of profit for them).
However, we could suggest an alternative which could be very convenient
for you. The following is the technical background:
As you probably know, a number of passenger ships go from South America
to the Caribbean; among them is the MS Francy, which normally operates
between Brazil and Venezuela. This ship was specially chartered by a
tour operator from Dubai who asked us for help
Email 4:
Hi Lacey,
As a follow up of the quotation sent to you yesterday, I attach
here the quotation we did for the voyage from Montevideo to Isla Margarita
for your consideration. This voyage is scheduled to leave on 22 July with
estimated time of arrival 25 July in Isla Margarita, and there is a high
probability that it will be chartered. This vessel was used by a tour
operator from Dubai, who asked us to help them with the organisation of the
operation. I will ask them to contact you to give you all the details. This
operator was looking for containers, but we have done the calculation and
we see that there is no need to use containers, because the cost would be
too high in relation to the volume. So the only way would be by 20' pallets,
using the forkl
Email 5:
Hi Lacey,
the voyage scheduled from Montevideo to Isla Margarita (arrival 27 June) is
sold out and another vessel will be used for this operation. We have arranged
with a very good cargo vessel which will be leaving from the port of Valparaiso
on 24 July and arriving in Isla Margarita on 27 July. This cargo vessel will be
chartered by the tour operator for this voyage. We suggest the option by 20' flat
racks (pallets) to be loaded on the decks of the vessel and also by trucks to
be driven aboard and carried in the hold of the vessel. This will be the cheapest
way to move your cargo. Please let me know if you would like us to quote on this
proposal. The itinerary of the ship is as follows:
*Dep. Montevideo

Best regards,
Joseline

Email 2:
Greetings!                   My name is Mary Wells. As a financial advisor to the Wilson family, I am pleased to introduce this matter to you, especially since you have proven your ability to carry out your operations without much delay.   I wish to inform you that the personal effects of my clients, Mrs.Glenda Wilson and Mr. Michael Wilson were loaded on to your vessel named MT “” and shipped from Southampton to Monrovia, Liberia, dated 10th May 2008.  I wish to inform you that the goods which comprises of one piece of one Rolls Royce and four pieces of Household goods have been detained by the Librerian authorities for the past three years as they claim that the customs documents were not properly filled.  This has forced Mrs. Glenda and Mr. Michael Wilson to incur huge demurrage and storage fees which they cannot afford to pay now. It
Email 3:
Thanks for your email and apologies for my delay in replying. I don’t think that there is an issue with the cargo in Liberia, it is no longer onboard the vessel but I have sent you a scan of a document from the shipping line saying that they can assist with releasing the cargo. It’s my feeling that there is a bureaucratic delay in Liberia and you might have to employ a solicitor to assist, do you have any ideas about that? Best regards, Scott
Email 4:
Ah yes, that explains a lot. We’ve not got any vessels at present. Sorry.
Regards
Steve

<Email 5>:
I have some information for you regarding what I’m sure will be your next job. You need to visit Liberia. I’ve made an arrangement with the Liberia international trade and transportation secretariat to assist you with the release of the cargo.
I’ll send you a document of authority signed by the director of the importation department at the customs department of Liberia. Do you have a representative there who will be able to pick it up on your behalf? If not, let me know and I’ll contact the Liberian secretary.
Don’t worry about the rest, I’ll handle it.
Regards,
Steve

Email 1:
Hello Mr. Bluth,                    We have 100 tons of LPG to ship from Bahrain to Cairo, Egypt. We are interested in your available 25,000DWT vessel and would like to discuss laycan and ETA.                    We would also like to know whether the goods are dirty or clean.                    Thank you,                    Sophie
Email 2:
Mr. Bluth,
Thank you for your reply. Can you please send an estimated FOB price and any additional information you might have about laycan, ETA, and IFO price? We would like to discuss this shipment, although we might not need it as soon as you mentioned. But we could also be interested in the earlier date, so please send more details. Thank you,                     Sophie

You: Hello Sophie, can you please share the material specification? The general rule is to ask for all the details required to take an offer. This way, you will reduce the time spent on exchanges, and you will know whether you will be interested in that opportunity.

<Email 3>:
Ms. Sophie,
Thank you for your reply. We have the following specification: C3+ Headings 2711, 2712, 2903, 2905, 290
Email 3:
Ms. Sophie,
Thank you for your reply. We have the following specification: C3+ Headings 2711, 2712, 2903, 2905, 290

<Email 3>:
 It’s a basic requirement for the buyer to share the material specification. The email should include your final offer if possible. The material specification is one of the major documents you will need when preparing a freight quotation.
<Email 3>:
Ms. Sophie,
Thank you for your reply. We have the following specification: C3+ Headings 2711, 2712, 2903, 2905, 290

Email 5:
Thank you for your offer. Please, add the insurance amount, insurance rates, and freight charges. Thank you,                     Sophie
Email 6:
We would like to offer you a price of $100,000 as 5% deposit and$95,000 as 95% L/C at sight, plus $3,000 as insurance. Please note that we do not include the freight charge in our offer because the shipper is
Email 4:
If you are in direct contact with the buyer, please try to get the material specification. In this case, you need to be direct and say that you cannot send a freight quotation without that document. If they ask about the freight quotation first, share a rough estimate with a mention that it will be updated when you have the material specification. The buyer should realize that this is the only way for you to take an offer. It is your first line of defense against waste of time. Other brokers might not understand that they need to ask for the material specification because they do not have a "ship" yet, so they can only discuss price and laycan. This is very wrong, but I am sure it happens.  If you are an agent, you should receive the material specification from the buyer. If you don't have it, call your counterpart to discuss this. The situation I describe below
Email 5:
Thank you for your offer. Please, add the insurance amount, insurance rates, and freight charges. Thank you,                    Sophie
<Email 5>:
Thank you for your offer. Please, add the insurance amount, insurance rates, and freight charges. Thank you,                     Sophie

Email 1:
Dear Geraldine,                    We’d like to cargo 300MT of caprolactum from Cotonou to Dover. Could you suggest if after-hours berthing is available and if we could load on a vessel berthed at a berth located in the South Container Terminal?                    Regards,                    Pauline
Email 2:
Thanks Pauline,

I checked the schedules and I think you mean the Commodore. This is our weekly spot cargo service, loading containers for France.

The Commodore berths at the South Container Terminal but we can't berth there this week. There are no slots available and the berths have to be occupied in a particular order.

South Container Terminal berths are occupied in this order:
5, 1, 2, 4, 7, 3, 6

This week we have the Commodore coming in from Kingston on Wednesday. This is the first available berth for that vessel so we are expecting her to be berthed at 6 South. The ship is due to sail to Cherbourg on Friday night.

I hope this helps.

Regards,

Geraldine

Email 1:
Could you give us the best rates for 150MT shipment of steam coal to Tocopilla, Chile? Please send us a complete quotation including all freight, brokerage, storage and other relevant charges.                                        Jon
Email 2:
My name is Duglas Brown, director of Romco Mining Ltd. Romco is involved in the mining and export of several types of coal from different regions of the world. Our requirements for steam coal are as follows:
Coal – Sulphur 1.5% max
Calorific Value – 6,000 kcal/kg min
Ash Content – 15% max
Moisture Content – 5% max
Volatile Matter – 23% max
Other Minerals – 18% max
Fines – 5% max
With quality standards like this, I can assure you that you will have no problem in selling the coal from your mine at any market in the world, providing the price is competitive. You can send us the price for your coal per ton CIF to the port of Antofagasta. We will review it and get back to you.
Email 3:
We look forward to seeing your offers at any time. In the meantime, we’d like to invite you to have a look at our website. You can find many details there about our company, our subsidiaries and our staff. You can also take a virtual tour to view the place where we work, the machines and plants we use to mine and to process coal. In fact, our website has been recently updated and optimized to look very nice on mobile phones.
Regards,
Ron Skye
Email 4:

Dear Mr. Ernest,
                    The "Coastline" is currently berthed at Kakinada on Indian coast and I expect to receive her draft survey report on or about the 25th. Her charterers are currently assessing the bunkers required by the vessel for Singapore, however, we may be able to depart the previous fixture for Singapore as early as the 26th March.
                    As far as ballast conditions are concerned, your charterers could also try "Coastline's" current charterers (i.e. "Sambalino" of the same owners) as they will be arriving from a short haul fixture at the moment and may be in a position to proceed immediately to the loading port in ballast. Subject: Re: Cement Transport                    Hey Matt,                    We can do 100,000 tonnes a year for you, if you agree on an annual contract. The best rate for you will be $60 per tonne + $5 in extra charges. The extra charges is because the port authority in Israel gives us that discount if we ship at least 100,000 tonnes per year.                      I also have a discount if you take shipping insurance. The extra charge for the insurance is$3 per tonne. You also need to deposit $20,000 into our account before we start shipping cement to you. Yours truly,
Ha

Email 2:

<Email 3>:
Hey Maria,                    Hey Maria, the way I'd suggest it, we keep our chat about our fixed laycans and then forward it onto our IT guys. They would then be able to add this into the system for us, so that we both have fixed dates in place. Let me know if that’s ok?                    Cheers,                    Mark

 Hey Maria,                    Hey Maria, you know we always say we should make an effort to start the sentences with Hi or something similar, and avoid starting with Hey?                    Cheers,                    Mark

- Start emails with "Hey", "Hi", "Hey Maria", "Hello Maria", or any similar greeting.
- End emails with "Cheers"

                    Dear Mr. Bush,
                    Thank you for your inquiry.

                    In order to make an offer we would need to know the date of shipment, vessel, and cargo type. If the vessel is not chartered we can suggest the estimated rates.

                    If the vessel is already on charter and the vessel type is known then we can suggest the freight rate.

                    In the above two cases, an offer is being provided but it is not a fixed rate.

                    If the vessel has already been loaded, then a time charter rate must be negotiated.

                    In the case of a time charter, the vessel owner may expect at least 2 voyages to break even.

A booking reference number is a unique number that is given to a customer when they make a booking for a product or service. The number is used to identify the customer's booking and to keep track of it. The number may be given to the customer in a confirmation email or letter, or it may be printed on the customer's booking form. The booking reference number is typically used to look up the customer's booking when they call or email to ask a question or make a change to their booking.

To: annabelle.chen@example.com
Subject: Re: Waste Plastic Film Shipment - Fuzhou to Tianjin
Timestamp: 2023-07-21 14:30
Body: Dear Ms. Annabelle,

Thank you for your email. We have storage tanks and packing equipment available to accept your 5,000MT shipment of waste plastic film starting July 28. The lead time will be approximately four days for completing the tanking process.

We can handle the loading, stuffing, and lashing, while you will be responsible for fixing and sealing the hatch. Please confirm if the cargo will be using hatch cover or double-containerization so we can prepare accordingly.

Scarlett

Best regards,
Scarlett

To: annabelle.chen@example.com
Subject: Re: Waste Plastic Film Shipment - Fuzhou to Tianjin

Email 1:
Dear Mr. Cullen,                    I am sorry that we didn’t find a solution for the cargoes on the DFRA vessels.                    I understand that if my offer of $5.25 is not satisfactory, then a freight should be negotiated at the price of an alternative vessel. I look forward to hear your proposal.                    Many thanks,                    Ed
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Ed;                       We regret that DFRA was not able to fulfill the commitment given to you by the master of the sea-going DFRA and express our sympathy at the difficulties this must have caused for your company.               If you would like to enter into discussions for a future contract, we will gladly take this up with you.                If you need some payment for the cargoes already on board, this may be possible.                    We regret this will not be possible at a higher rate than the rate quoted for the passage itself, i.e. $5.25.              We await your instructions.                   With best wishes,                  Ed

The question is: Has the email chain finished? Or will the one who sent the second email, follow up and send a third email?
This is a case where the reader will probably be misled by the formality of the emails. I would advise
Email 3:
I know this will not be possible at a higher rate than the rate quoted for the passage itself, i.e. $5.25. But I thought I would ask anyways. We just found out that we are in serious financial trouble. We will be lucky to make payroll next week. I am hoping that you will be able to find it in your heart to show some mercy. We know you have so much money. You see, you need to trust us. We can do this. We will find a way. Please let us use your ship. We’ll pay back the money once we have time to figure it out. But you need to help us out. Thank you for your time. We know you will be able to make the best decision possible. Ed

By asking about the formal register, you will not be able to have an understanding of the situation. Once you reach the
Email 4:
I’m sorry to hear that you’re in trouble. However, I’m not able to help you. The rules are strict and this is what is written in the contract. I hope you will be able to make payroll somehow. 
-Ed

Ed

---

From: cullen.freight@dfra.com
To: ed.smith@shipping.com
Subject: Re: DFRA Vessel Freight Rate Discussion
Timestamp: 2024-02-10 14:30
Body: Dear Mr. Ed,

We regret that DFRA was not able to fulfill the commitment given to you regarding the sea-going vessel and express our sympathy for the difficulties this must have caused your company.

If you would like to enter into discussions for a future contract, we will gladly take this up with you. Regarding payment for the cargoes already on board, this may be possible, though not at a rate higher than $5.25 as previously quoted.

We await your instructions.

With best wishes,
Cullen

---

From: ed.smith@shipping.com
To: cullen.freight@dfra.com
Subject: Re: DFRA Vessel Freight Rate Discussion
Timestamp: 2024-02-11 08:45
Body: Dear Mr. Cullen,

I understand the rate cannot exceed $5.25, but I must make an urgent appeal. We have just discovered we are in serious financial difficulty and may struggle to make payroll next week. Given your company's position, I'm hoping you might show some flexibility. We are reliable partners and will ensure full payment once we overcome this temporary setback.

Please consider allowing us use of your vessel under adjusted terms.

Best regards,
Ed

---

From: cullen.freight@dfra.com
To: ed.smith@shipping.com
Subject: Re: DFRA Vessel Freight Rate Discussion
Timestamp: 2024-02-11 11:20
Body: Dear Mr. Ed,

I'm sorry to hear about your financial difficulties. However, I must maintain our position as per the contract terms. We cannot adjust the rate of $5.25. I hope you understand this business decision and are able to find alternative solutions for your immediate challenges.

Regards,
Cullen
