From: adam.smith@company.com
To: helberg.shipping@sealand.com
Subject: Rate Request - Chemical Shipment Westport to Long Beach
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 09:15
Body: Ms. Helberg,

We've got a 5,000MT of chemicals requiring transport from Westport, LA to Long Beach, CA. Could you please provide your rate quote for this shipment? Also, could you advise on any current dock congestion situations at Long Beach?

Thank you,
Adam

---

From: helberg.shipping@sealand.com
To: adam.smith@company.com
Subject: RE: Rate Request - Chemical Shipment Westport to Long Beach
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 11:30
Body: Hi Adam,

Good day! Thank you for your inquiry. I must inform you that we currently don't have local agents at Westport. We only operate shipments from LA, Long Beach, or Hueneme ports.

This means we cannot arrange local delivery pickups or handle port activities at Westport. These would need to be arranged by the shipment owner or a third-party company.

For reference, our current rates for similar shipments from our operating ports to Long Beach are:
- Ocean Freight: USD 1,862
- Port Charges: USD 1,858

We're currently offering a 6% discount on our services, which would result in savings of approximately USD 362.

Please let me know if you would like to discuss alternative arrangements through our operating ports.

Best regards,
Ms. Helberg

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Mr. Thomas,                    We’re looking to move   some dry bulk cargo from Apapa to Durban on short notice. Could you share your earliest loading window?                    Regards,                    Janelle
Email 2:
Dear Colleagues,      Our kind team is invited to London for IMO/SGS market hearing. Looking for your meeting schedule or collective guidance from DCS. What is your opinion for SGH support project?                            Regards,                    Ria

Answering both of these emails at the same time is often not possible. Even with the help of tools, like Changelog.io , can save time. 
Typically, you would need to spend some time each day, looking through the emails you’ve gotten, and only answer the ones you can actually answer, saving the others for later. 

A chat bot can also do that. With a Machine Learning and NLP model, the bot can answer the questions that it has answers to, or store them to answer later, and reply to your other colleagues later, with their questions still in place. 

If the first question above is related to
Email 3:

<...>

the bot would reply back with the appropriate answers, and then be able to answer similar questions in the future, as it trains its model.

                <Name>

Dear Ting
Shipment terms and conditions
From
Guangzhou, China
Destination
Manila, Philippines
Quantity
2,000MT (approximately 28,000 boxes, Gross 1000@1.2Tons)
Payment Terms
The exporter shall arrange a Bank Letter of Credit to the order of Kimono Inc. (Korean Export Company).  Cash / Bank Cashier Check in US Dollar at 60% of value in the Letter of Credit.  The balance shall be paid in cash upon confirmation of inspection results at origin.
Export License
Appropriate customs and commercial licenses
Delivery Time

    1.  Your company shall provide a Letter of Credit in favor of Hapag-Lloyd (Shipping line)

                    Best regards,                   
                    Ting

P.S.  1000 Box is 2500.00 per tonne
    28,000 Box = 70,000

input_text:
Email 1:
Mr. Silver,                    We’re looking for a 500 ton cargo of corn from Quebec to Tokyo. Could you provide a freight quote under CFR terms, and can your vessel sail before the 20th?                    Best regards,                    Gordon
Email 2:
Silver Shipping
Mr. Silver,
Thank you for your reply. We have already loaded on a vessel and made the transportation contract. However, the transportation company asks for the following documents: a set of bills of lading, a certificate of insurance and a set of commercial invoices. I would appreciate your advice.
Yours sincerely,
Tom

The problem of Cargo Document is tricky because it involves the dispute on whether the transportation company should be considered as the agent of the seller.

Business background:
The first email shows that the buyers have agreed on an acceptance to offer (letter of acceptance, cf. § 1384, Italian Code of Commercial law (Codice Commerciale)) and made a transportation contract for the 500 ton cargo of corn with a third party. As for the Seller, the second email shows that the Seller still thinks that the transportation company is his agent and the Buyers are not
Email 3:
Dear Gordon,
Silver Shipping, Inc. is currently arranging the shipping for you. It will be more convenient if you could tell us the name of the third party or the transportation company to deal with the shipping contract. We are looking forward to getting your email. Thank you very much.
Yours sincerely,
Michael Silver, President Silver Shipping, Inc.
</Email 3>

The main issue:
For the transaction to be a sale with CIF clause, at the moment of conclusion of the contract of sale, the Seller and the Buyers have to agree on the destination port and the Seller have to insure the goods for the Buyers. If the Buyers do not have a transportation contract, the Seller must comply with this CIF clause to fulfill the contract. Otherwise, the Seller should not promise the contract with the Buyers at all, which is the same as Article 6 § 1 (c) of the ICC
Email 4:
Gordon,
Mr. Silver would like to know where you have got the buyers of the corn. We have already got buyers but you asked for the freight and insurance costs. We do not understand why. As we agreed, you are responsible for the sale, insurance and transportation of the corn. We expect to see a written transportation contract from you within the next 3 days. Please forward to Mr. Silver a copy of the transportation contract.
Yours sincerely,
Bill
</Email 4>
The point is that the Seller has not decided what destination port the Buyers are going to choose yet. It seems that the Sellers have fulfilled all the CIF obligations in this case. Thus, it is unnecessary to involve any transportation company. If there is no such transportation company that the Seller and the Buyers both use, the contract of sale cannot be considered as a CIF contract. Therefore, the Sellers should not

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Kathy,                    Has the grounding of the Seablue had any impact on your crude fixing level for the short term?                    Thanks,                    Blayney
Email 2:
Hi Blayney,                    Not at all.                    Seablue is a crude vessel and almost all crude cargoes have been fixed by the other time-chartered tankers coming out of  Chinese yards.
As I mentioned previously, if Seablue did not come out in China, other tankers would come out of the dock and China would be fixed.                    These tankers would operate at a price level set by the most competitive time charter tanker which is the drydocked Seablue and therefore the price level at which China is fixed would not be different even if Seablue was out of the drydock.
LPG cargoes are different since we can not use LPG in the crude tankers and crude cargoes are not as easy to fix as LPG, since many producers are contracted and certain prices are set.
The next drydocked Seablue is in
Email 3:
1. Sent 6:45PM
2. Sent 7:03PM

3. Dear Mr. Mann, We are starting to use one of our new internal chat systems and will not have emails automatically sent to our inbox. I am not using my email for this chat system and would appreciate you sending a copy to my email for my records. This particular email is simply copying one of the other texts I have received. Best Regards, Daniel
output_text:
From: blayney.mann@company.com
To: kathy.chen@company.com
Subject: Seablue Grounding Impact Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 18:45
Body: Hi Kathy,

Has the grounding of the Seablue had any impact on your crude fixing level for the short term?

Thanks,
Blayney

---

From: kathy.chen@company.com
To: blayney.mann@company.com
Subject: Re: Seablue Grounding Impact Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 19:03
Body: Hi Blayney,

Not at all. Seablue is a crude vessel and almost all crude cargoes have been fixed by the other time-chartered tankers coming out of Chinese yards.

As I mentioned previously, if Seablue did not come out in China, other tankers would come out of the dock and China would be fixed. These tankers would operate at a price level set by the most competitive time charter tanker which is the drydocked Seablue, and therefore the price level at which China is fixed would not be different even if Seablue was out of the drydock.

LPG cargoes are different since we cannot use LPG in the crude tankers, and crude cargoes are not as easy to fix as LPG, since many producers are contracted and certain prices are set.

Regards,
Kathy

---

From: daniel.smith@company.com
To: blayney.mann@company.com
Subject: Re: Seablue Grounding Impact Query

We are starting to use one of our new internal chat systems and will not have emails automatically sent to our inbox. I am not using my email for this chat system and would appreciate you sending a copy to my email for my records. This particular email is simply copying one of the other texts I have received.

Best Regards,
Daniel

Hello Ms. Scott,                    Can you look at the market rate for 2 x 50foot containers of crude oil from Balikpapan to Jakarta, 22nd to 23rd of the month?                    Regards,                    Emma
Email 2:
Hi,                    We bought 2 x 50foot containers of crude oil from Balikpapan to Jakarta for 700 USD.                    All the best,                    Emma

After investigating 82 oil container rates in Balikpapan from February to May 2016, Emma wrote email 1 to request advice on market rates for the 22nd to 23rd of the month. When the suggested rate was below market rate, she accepted the offer via email 2.

Solution:
The correct answer is a2, and the explanation is as follows:
The business communication has the characteristic of taking the buyer's interest into consideration. The buyer is assumed to be the focus in business communication.
Email 3:
Dear Ms. Scott,                   We would like to purchase some crude oil. We have a request for a load of cargo delivered to China on or around the 22nd to 23rd of this month. What is the market rate for this?                    Regards,                    Emma

Answer Options:
a1. Email 3 asked the oil supplier for the market rate of oil containers and the price, which shows great concern for the buyer's interest.
a2. The oil supplier provides a quotation below the market rate in email 4, showing concern for the buyer's interest.
a3. The oil supplier provided a quotation that was on par with the market rate in email 4, showing no concern for the buyer's interest.
a4. The oil supplier provided a quotation that was much higher than the market rate in email 4, showing great concern for the buyer's interest.
a5

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Lyle,                    We’re considering shipping 35,000 metric tons of lumber from Vancouver to Inverness. Can you advise us about the import restrictions for pine?                    Warmly,                    Logan
Email 2:
Hi Logan.                    Thanks for your email.                    Unfortunately, the shipping of pine from Vancouver to Inverness is banned by law. I’m afraid we’re going to have to pass on your shipment.                    Lyle

### ID or OID for the Importer?

Actually, there’s an alternative – the business needn’t try to find out whether the lumber is in compliance with U.S. law, but simply can certify to that effect. A problem arises in distinguishing between logs and lumber, and lumber that has been cut and sawn and lumber that is not sawn. And even a commitment to pay for a formal inspection would not be sufficient to get past U.S. Customs’ questions. So, when the importing country wishes to assure itself that U.S. law is being complied with, the issuing country may provide an assurance in the form of an import certificate, an export certificate,
output_text:
From: logan.matthews@timberco.com
To: lyle.peterson@importcontrol.uk
Subject: Pine Lumber Import Query - Vancouver to Inverness
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 09:15
Body: Hi Lyle,

We're considering shipping 35,000 metric tons of lumber from Vancouver to Inverness. Can you advise us about the import restrictions for pine?

Warmly,
Logan

---

From: lyle.peterson@importcontrol.uk
To: logan.matthews@timberco.com
Subject: Re: Pine Lumber Import Query - Vancouver to Inverness
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 14:30
Body: Hi Logan,

Thanks for your email.

Unfortunately, the shipping of pine from Vancouver to Inverness is currently banned under import regulations. I'm afraid we won't be able to process your shipment request.

Regards,
Lyle

Hi Jack,                    I would be happy to book a 7,000MT VLGC cargo for August from Fujairah to Rotterdam. We would like to arrange 3-5 vessels as soon as possible. Could you send the broking team details and further information?                    Thanks,                    Vanessa
Email 2:
Jack,                      As mentioned earlier, please see attached our company's terms and conditions which we would like you to sign in return. We will also send you the same request as we sent to LME.                    Regarding our booking requirements, as discussed earlier, we are willing to book 5-7 vessels on a voyage charter basis for 1,000-10,000MT with the following cargo requirements:                    Commodity - JP54                    Origin - Asia                    Destination - West Africa                    1 or 2 vessels with DAP or CIF for each cargo.                    We would also like to charter other vessels on a shorter route for 1-2 weeks each and the same freight terms should apply as above.                    If you can please arrange these chartered vessels on a regular basis. We would like to make these bookings in June and July.                      Look forward to receiving your response.                    Best
Email 3:
Jack,                I just wanted to check that you had received and signed the attached.                We have now received the signed copies from all your brokers which will be sent to you soon.                Regarding the other chartered vessels, as you can see from the attached schedules, there is a lot of uncertainty in both Asia and West Africa and it may be difficult to charter vessels. We will try to provide you with options if we can.                We have also prepared a list of the cargoes that we would like to book for each vessel in the 1st week of August. Please see the attached.                We look forward to receiving your comments.                Best,
Jack,            There was no response to email 3. We sent two follow up emails with no response.

From: vanessa.smith@trading.com
To: jack.wilson@generalproducts.com
Subject: VLGC Cargo Booking Request - Fujairah to Rotterdam
Timestamp: 2023-07-01 09:30
Body: Hi Jack,

I would be happy to book a 7,000MT VLGC cargo for August from Fujairah to Rotterdam. We would like to arrange 3-5 vessels as soon as possible. Could you send the broking team details and further information?

Thanks,
Vanessa

---

From: vanessa.smith@trading.com
To: jack.wilson@generalproducts.com
Subject: Re: Vessel Charter Requirements and T&Cs
Timestamp: 2023-07-05 14:15
Body: Jack,

As mentioned earlier, please see attached our company's terms and conditions for signature. We will send you the same request as sent to LME.

Regarding our booking requirements, we are willing to book 5-7 vessels on a voyage charter basis for 1,000-10,000MT with the following specifications:

Commodity: JP54
Origin: Asia
Destination: West Africa
1 or 2 vessels with DAP or CIF for each cargo

We would also like to charter additional vessels on shorter routes for 1-2 weeks each under the same freight terms.

Please arrange these chartered vessels for June and July bookings.

Best regards

---

From: vanessa.smith@trading.com
To: jack.wilson@generalproducts.com
Subject: Re: Documentation Follow-up and August Bookings
Timestamp: 2023-07-15 11:20
Body: Jack,

Just checking if you've received and signed the attached documents. We have received signed copies from all your brokers which will be forwarded to you.

Regarding the additional chartered vessels, there is significant uncertainty in both Asia and West Africa markets, which may impact vessel availability. We will provide options where possible.

We've prepared a list of cargoes for booking in the first week of August. Please see attached.

Look forward to your comments.

Best regards

---

From: vanessa.smith@trading.com
To: jack.wilson@generalproducts.com
Subject: Re: Urgent - Asia Cargo Options Required
Timestamp: 2023-08-12 16:45
Body: Jack,

It has been over 4 weeks since our last email. We urgently need options on the Asia cargo. We have requested this from your broker LME, but have received no response.

Regards

---

From: vanessa.smith@trading.com
To: jack.wilson@generalproducts.com
Subject: Final Notice - Vessel Options Required
Timestamp: 2023-08-25 10:30
Body: Jack,

I am writing to you as the owner of General Products. We have sent multiple requests regarding chartered vessels without response. We need you to provide options for these cargoes urgently.

We have attached the charter vessels and cargoes under consideration again. Please review and respond with available options so we can proceed with arrangements.

Best regards

---

From: vanessa.smith@trading.com
To: jack.wilson@generalproducts.com
Subject: Termination of Business Relationship
Timestamp: 2023-09-01 15:00
Body: Jack,

It is with disappointment that I must inform you we have chosen to work with another company to secure our vessels. The lack of timely response has made it impossible to proceed with our booking requirements.

Regards

    the quality and cleanliness of the cargo,

output_text:

From: james.wilson@shipbroker.com
To: mona.smith@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - PKO Port Klang to Male
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 10:30
Body: Hi Mona,

Thanks for the enquiry. So you are looking for a freight quote to move 5,000MT of palm kernel oil from Port Klang to Male?

I'll need more details about the cargo before I can give you a quote. Could you please let me know:
- The quality and cleanliness of the cargo
- The minimum temperature the cargo must be kept at on board

Looking forward to hearing from you.

Best regards,
James

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi John,                    Our Singapore client would like to transport 2,800MT of naphtha from Baltimore to Dahej, but we don’t have enough funds on hand for the margin fee. Could you spot us?                    Hope you can help.                    Kim
Email 2:
From: John G                 Sent: 23 February 2012 18:00                 To: Kim T                 Subject: Spot us?                 Not a chance! Hope you can spot my answer.                 John

Problem

A recent widespread email spam campaign targeted the energy and commodities trading industry with messages claiming that their customers wanted to use their services to buy crude oil and related products from reputable traders in the market. Some traders were approached in a very business-like manner, allegedly by major oil firms. The email subject line would indicate that the email was from a trusted business partner, such as a large energy firm or similar corporate client.

The email requests are easy to read but hard to understand. A foreign sounding person claiming to be an executive from a respectable company in a similar industry wants to “spot” some “margin fee” – what? An explanation for what these terms mean may have come attached
Email 3:
Dear John,                    Thank you for your reply.                    Our Singapore client is Singapore Energy, one of the leading trading and logistics companies in Asia Pacific. They represent a major Japanese refiner, Osaka Gas.                    It’s true that this is a complicated trading project and we have to pay a relatively high margin fee of USD 1,000.000.                    If you don’t mind, I can arrange to send you the contract and payment procedure, so that you can fully understand the situation.                    Have a good day.                    Kim

When a business receives a large unsolicited order they often feel obligated to make the sale. In this instance, we can probably deduce that our client is confused as to what the client actually wants and also may be uncomfortable with all the business jargon. In both situations, the client should take a step back and evaluate the order. First, the client should
Email 4:
Dear John,                    Thank you for your reply.                    I am really sorry to trouble you. My name is Alihac, Assistant to the CEO of Singapore Energy.                    I’d like to discuss with you about the details of the project.                    Please let me know when you are free.                    Best regards,                    Kim

As the requests are unsolicited and we have not received any communication with our buyer in the past, it would be a good idea to contact them directly to confirm their intent. We could ask the buyer for more information and maybe arrange to speak with the buyer directly. When speaking with the buyer, it would be important to ask them to provide more information about the deal. The buyer may have a reasonable explanation for their request. However, it is important to keep in mind that a reasonable explanation does not necessarily mean the request is legitimate.

Conclusion

This type of email scam

Many thanks,
Precious

---

From: tamir.shipping@vesselco.com
To: katty.broker@fal.com
Subject: Re: Gasoil Vessel Inquiry - Durban to Walvis Bay
Timestamp: 2023-06-01 10:30
Body: Hi Katty,

Please check the attached draft agreement for review.

Regards,
Tamir

---

From: tamir.shipping@vesselco.com
To: katty.broker@fal.com
Subject: Re: Gasoil Vessel Inquiry - Chartering Costs
Timestamp: 2023-06-01 14:20
Body: Hi Katty,

As discussed on the phone, here is our chartering costs breakdown:

- Estimated freight (S/D: CIF-MRC 91.00 USD/pmt): 70,000 USD
- Estimated bunkers consumption @ 160 pmt/day: 16,000 USD
- Port dues: 1,400 USD (Durban) & 500 USD (Walvis Bay): 1,900 USD
- Estimated freight commission (2%): 1,400 USD

Total: 90,500 USD

With the exception of port dues, these are estimates. Bunker consumption will be updated in our contract based on your data.

We will submit a draft chartering contract for your reference in the next few days.

Thanks,
Tamir

Regards,
Katty
FAL

Email 1: Dear Ms. Mohamed, It’s been almost a month since we last communicated. I was hoping you might be able to help me secure a tanker for a methanol shipment from S Korea to New Zealand. The tonnage required is 8,000 dwt, and can be loaded from mid to late May. Let me know if you need further details and I can send across some more info. Regards, Brad Email 2: Dear Mr. Thompson, Thank you for your email. We are an organization with a network of trading companies. We are willing to supply fuel to New Zealand for the time being. If there are no conflicting interests, would you consider us a partner in this? Please let me know if I can provide you with any other details or other information. Regards, Khadija ============================================ Note: No response from Ms. Mohamed. Email 3: Dear Khadija, We are interested in offering you our services, but we do have some questions first. Have you sent this email to anyone else? If yes, can you please share the number of receivers? Also, please note that it has come to our notice that you might be engaged in illegal activities. We have zero tolerance for such dealings, and are now trying to verify this information. If it turns out to be true, we will block your email account, and take the necessary action against you. Best regards, Alice

**Note: The responses given by email were not of a friendly nature and in some cases were unprofessional, and came across as unappreciative. So, we used the support department to get a second opinion and see what we can learn from this.**

Hi Reza,                    I’d like to schedule 40,000MT of molasses from Santos to Jawahar Nagar. We’re open to spot charterers, but this cargo may require some creativity in terms of planning. Could you please let me know if you are open to this size charter?                    Thank you,                    Rosalind
Email 2:
Hi Rosalind                    Just sent you a revised LSA with the same details.                    Best regards                    Reza

Thanks, Reza

Below is Rosalind's reaction to Reza's invitation.
Email 3:
You are good, its working perfect :)

All the best,
Rosalind

So she already appreciated the role of Reza’s proposing concrete example as shown in the second email above.

For general reference, a LSA is a LOI (letter of intent) document.

Introduction

The use of “Email 1” as an example is taken from a popular LinkedIn post of Sam Nara on the subject of using a working example when making a proposal (source: Linkedin).

I have learned a lot from Sam’s post, and I think the post helps provide an excellent practical starting point. In this post, I will provide further explanations to highlight more subtle points not included in Sam’s original post, and also discuss how these points are implemented in our Lean Email.

Email 1 is a typical email. Its objective is to propose a working example to a recipient.

In practice, Rosalind
Email 4:
Thank you so much!
<...>
I do need your help here to review and submit the revised LSA to admin for approvals!

In this example, Rosalind first thanked Reza for sending her a revised LSA, then reminded Reza that she required his help to proceed with the transaction.

Based on this email, Reza needs to do two things to support Rosalind in closing this transaction:

• Review the LSA before submitting the LSA to Rosalind’s admin for approvals.
• Submit the LSA to Rosalind’s admin for approvals.

Reza can do these two tasks simply by using Lean Email by clicking the buttons as shown below. Clicking on the Review button will pop-up a Review/Submit page, which contains a Review tab, and a Submit tab.

Clicking on the Review tab, Reza can simply enter a quick review note, and

Mr. Parkin,                    Can you please provide a freight estimate for 6,000MT of LNG from Mopan in the US Gulf to Antwerp in July. Is port rotation compulsory for this service?                    Kind Regards,                    Cassie
Email 2:
Dear Ms. Manwell,                    Thank you for your enquiry. We have provided you with a proposal for the movement of 6,000MT of LNG from the US Gulf to Antwerp in July. The price for the cargo at the level mentioned in the proposal is on the basis of a fixed FOB rate. We can also offer this cargo with a FCN, however, this is calculated on the basis of a CBM charge of 1.20 per CBM based on the CBM declared on the cargo. In both scenarios the CIF rate is fixed, and cargo would be delivered to the discharge port on the same day. In regards to a port rotation, this would be at the shipper's request, subject to prior agreement between all parties.                    We would ask that you review the proposal and send back a copy of the commercial terms (either C/P or C&F
Email 3:
```Dear Mr. Dalschaert,                    With reference to our recent e-mail communication, I am writing to inform you that our chartering division has raised an enquiry with London regarding our agreement with their provisions in terms of the GCM/Voyage charterparty (as drafted by BIMCO).                    This charterparty refers to a CBM charge of $1.20 per CBM as the basis of calculation for a FCN charter. This rate was introduced to reflect the charterer's ability to make a simple and accurate calculation based on the CBM's stated on their cargo. Our customer, Shell, has explained to us that they will not proceed with this arrangement for their LNG shipments unless the CBM charge is less than 90 cbm.                    We are also asking that BIMCO changes the wording of the applicable provision of the GCM/Voyage Charterparty to ensure
Email 4:
```Dear Mr. Dalschaert,                    In line with our previous e-mail communication, please find attached a proposed amendment to the current GCM/Voyage charterparty draft that BIMCO has produced for consideration.                    The proposed amendment is as follows:                    \................/                    18.30.1 Freight shall be calculated at 1.20/ cbm based on the CBM declared by the cargo \................/                    This would be effective for cargoes delivered after 1st January 2003.                    Please let us know if you would be agreeable to this amendment, and, if so, we will pursue this with BIMCO.                    With many thanks,                    Best Regards,                    David ```
output_text:
From: cassie.manwell@trading.com
To: j.parkin@shipping.com
Subject: LNG Freight Enquiry - US Gulf to Antwerp
Timestamp: 2023-07-01 09:30
Body: Mr. Parkin,

Can you please provide a freight estimate for 6,000MT of LNG from Mopan in the US Gulf to Antwerp in July. Is port rotation compulsory for this service?

Kind Regards,
Cassie

---

From: j.parkin@shipping.com
To: cassie.manwell@trading.com
Subject: Re: LNG Freight Enquiry - US Gulf to Antwerp
Timestamp: 2023-07-01 11:45
Body: Dear Ms. Manwell,

Thank you for your enquiry. We have prepared a proposal for the movement of 6,000MT of LNG from the US Gulf to Antwerp in July. The price can be structured in two ways:

1. Fixed FOB rate as detailed in the proposal
2. FCN basis with a CBM charge of $1.20 per CBM based on the cargo declaration

In both scenarios, the CIF rate would be fixed, with cargo delivery to the discharge port on the same day. Regarding port rotation, this would be at the shipper's request and subject to prior agreement between all parties.

Please review the proposal and return a copy of the commercial terms (either C/P or C&F).

Best regards,
James Parkin

---

From: d.smith@shipping.com
To: m.dalschaert@bimco.org
Subject: GCM/Voyage Charterparty - CBM Rate Discussion
Timestamp: 2023-07-02 14:20
Body: Dear Mr. Dalschaert,

Regarding our recent communications, our chartering division has consulted with London about the GCM/Voyage charterparty provisions (as drafted by BIMCO).

The current charterparty specifies a CBM charge of $1.20 per CBM for FCN charters. However, our client Shell has indicated they cannot proceed with this arrangement for LNG shipments unless the CBM charge is reduced to below 90 cents per CBM.

We therefore request BIMCO to consider revising the relevant provision in the GCM/Voyage Charterparty accordingly.

Best regards,
David Smith

---

From: d.smith@shipping.com
To: m.dalschaert@bimco.org
Subject: Re: GCM/Voyage Charterparty - Proposed Amendment
Timestamp: 2023-07-03 10:15
Body: Dear Mr. Dalschaert,

Following our previous communication, please find below our proposed amendment to the current GCM/Voyage charterparty draft:

18.30.1 Freight shall be calculated at 1.20/cbm based on the CBM declared by the cargo

This amendment would be effective for cargoes delivered after January 1st, 2023.

Please advise if this amendment is acceptable, and we will proceed with BIMCO accordingly.

Best regards,
David Smith

Dear Ms. Armitage,                    Want to discuss options for a scheduled bulk chartered from Singapore to Jakarta, loading 15,000 MT of rice.                    Thanks,                    Sally
Email 2:
Ms. Armitage                    Hi Sally,                In reference to your email, we may consider to organize a chartered out of Singapore with loading to be completed by around 20 to 22 Nov, with delivery ETA expected to be around 10 to 12 Dec. For your reference, I have attached the chartered info and telex release copy.                If you are interested, I will keep you posted when we have further update.                Regards,                Tony

</Email 2>

# Word Problem

### Solution 1

From the email the relevant facts are:

• The farmer wants to charter a ship to transport 15000 mt of rice to Jakarta.
• According to Ms. Armitage, the loading can be completed by around 20–22 November with delivery ETA around 10–12 December.

We know the ship will depart Singapore to Jakarta but
Email 3:
Hi Sally,                There will be another chartered starting from Singapore to Jakarta, departing on 18 Nov.                If you are interested, please advise latest by 15 Nov.                Regards,                Tony

</Email 3>

The sender mentions in Email 3 that the ship will leave Singapore to Jakarta on 18 November. That means there will be a time difference between 18 November and 20 November. So this information is not consistent with the information given in Email 2, which is the main source of information.

One reason for inconsistency could be the mistake in Email 2, when Ms. Armitage wrote 22 November instead of 20 November. Or one may assume that when Ms. Armitage sent Email 2, she didn't know about the departure date on 18 November.

Let us consider the following situation:
Email 4:
Hi Sally,                There will be a chartered departing on 18 Nov, with delivery ETA expected to be around 10 to 12 Dec.                Please advise if you are interested by 15 Nov.                Regards,                Tony

</Email 4>

In Email 4, we assumed that Ms. Armitage may have made a mistake in Email 2, and corrected it in Email 4. So let us analyze this situation.

Assume the ship leaves Singapore on 18 November and arrives at Jakarta on 10 December. This means the ship will take 22 days to reach Jakarta.

So, if loading is completed on 20 November, it will take a minimum of 2 days to complete the loading. It may take longer.

• So the loading will take place between 18 and 20 November.

I am writing because I am concerned about the current state of my company.                     As you may know, our CEO, Mr. Smith is leaving, and is rumored to be heading for JPS. The news had a significant impact on the market cap. Our stock was down 8 percent on the day of the announcement.                     The plan is to name an interim replacement while a search is conducted to find a successor. output_text:
From: dana.mitchell@company.com
To: jorge.rodriguez@company.com
Subject: Potential Organizational Changes
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:15
Body: Hello Jorge,

I hope you and your family are doing well.

I've enjoyed working with you over the last couple of years, and I'm sure I'm not the only one who feels this way.

Although our current business outlook is positive, I feel I should inform you that there may be some changes ahead due to merger and alignment discussions happening in the background. This might affect our working relationship moving forward.

Best wishes,
Dana

---

From: jeff.anderson@company.com
To: munoz.richard@jps.com
Subject: Seeking Advice - Company Leadership Transition
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:30
Body: Dear Mr. Munoz,

I hope you are doing well. We met briefly at the last GM Conference, though we haven't had the opportunity to speak since then.

I'm writing because I'm concerned about our company's current situation. As you may have heard, our CEO, Mr. Smith, is departing and is reportedly joining JPS. This news has significantly impacted our market performance, with our stock dropping 8 percent on the day of the announcement.

The board plans to appoint an interim CEO while conducting a search for a permanent successor. While the timing is less than ideal, the transition appears unavoidable.

I would greatly appreciate your insights on how we might best navigate this situation.

Best regards,
Jeff

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Mr. Woo,                    Could you please provide a 7-day freight estimate for 25,000MT of oil from Copenhagen to Lagos.                    Thanks,                    Felipe
Email 2:
Dear Felipe,                 25,000 tons of oil from Copenhagen to Lagos in a seven-day freight?                    That's quite a bit of oil, Felipe. I assume you need to ship it by sea.                    You see, the oil trade operates on a just-in-time inventory management model, whereby oil is shipped to tankers as needed. This provides a stable supply and demand, eliminates inventory storage costs and prevents oil from degrading over time.                    Since your request involves shipping 25,000 tons of oil in seven days, my freight quote estimate would exceed what is available.                    Please confirm that your request is for 25,000 tons of oil in a seven-day freight and I can provide a quote to the maximum that is available to my company.                    Thanks,                    Perry

<Email 3>:
Dear Perry,                 Yes, my request is for 25,000 tons
Email 3:
Dear Perry,                 Yes, my request is for 25,000 tons

<Email 3>:
 For shipping in seven days to Lagos in the Nigeria.                 Could you please provide a quote?                    Thanks,                    Felipe
<Email 4>:
Dear Felipe,                 Again, shipping 25,000 tons in seven days is an unusual request.                    If you are shipping this amount of oil in an outbound tanker, then the only companies capable of doing so are Shell, Chevron and Exxon. I don't have contacts with these companies.                    If you're shipping by sea, then you'll need a port in Copenhagen to load onto a tanker. I've emailed my contacts in the seaport of Copenhagen. They'll be in touch with me in the morning.                    If you're shipping by road, then the quantity would need to be in 45 liter plastic oil drums. The storage space and legal limitations of this option would be impossible to organize in such a short time frame.
Email 4:

From: felipe.martinez@tradeco.com
To: perry.woo@freightservices.com
Subject: Freight Quote Request - Copenhagen to Lagos
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:15
Body: Dear Mr. Woo,

Could you please provide a 7-day freight estimate for 25,000MT of oil from Copenhagen to Lagos?

Thanks,
Felipe

---

From: perry.woo@freightservices.com
To: felipe.martinez@tradeco.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Copenhagen to Lagos
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 10:30
Body: Dear Felipe,

25,000 tons of oil from Copenhagen to Lagos in a seven-day freight? That's quite a bit of oil. I assume you need to ship it by sea.

You see, the oil trade operates on a just-in-time inventory management model, whereby oil is shipped to tankers as needed. This provides a stable supply and demand, eliminates inventory storage costs and prevents oil from degrading over time.

Since your request involves shipping 25,000 tons of oil in seven days, my freight quote estimate would exceed what is available.

Please confirm that your request is for 25,000 tons of oil in a seven-day freight and I can provide a quote to the maximum that is available to my company.

Thanks,
Perry

---

From: felipe.martinez@tradeco.com
To: perry.woo@freightservices.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Copenhagen to Lagos
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 11:45
Body: Dear Perry,

Yes, my request is for 25,000 tons for shipping in seven days to Lagos in Nigeria. Could you please provide a quote?

Thanks,
Felipe

---

From: perry.woo@freightservices.com
To: felipe.martinez@tradeco.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Copenhagen to Lagos
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:20
Body: Dear Felipe,

Again, shipping 25,000 tons in seven days is an unusual request. If you are shipping this amount of oil in an outbound tanker, then the only companies capable of doing so are Shell, Chevron and Exxon. I don't have contacts with these companies.

If you're shipping by sea, then you'll need a port in Copenhagen to load onto a tanker. I've emailed my contacts in the seaport of Copenhagen. They'll be in touch with me in the morning.

If you're shipping by road, then the quantity would need to be in 45 liter plastic oil drums. The storage space and legal limitations of this option would be impossible to organize in such a short time frame.

I'm sorry, but I simply don't have the resources to fill your request. I recommend you submit your request to one of the three large oil companies I mentioned before.

Regards,
Perry

---

From: felipe.martinez@tradeco.com
To: perry.woo@freightservices.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Copenhagen to Lagos
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 15:10
Body: Dear Perry,

I am absolutely okay with you contacting the seaport in Copenhagen. I understand that you don't have the resources to fulfill my request. I will be submitting my request to an oil company.

Thank you for your assistance,
Felipe

- Setup
- Train Data
- Test Data
- Algorithm (XGBoost)
- Evaluation
- Conclusion


1. Setup


- Jupyter Notebooks (blog repository) 
- [Python docs](https://docs.python.org/3/)

2. Train Data


- Table: 11

| Index | company_name | last_name | email | case | product | claim_value | status |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 0 | Clean Energy Future | Armaud | ruby@ciean-energy-future.com | 1 | Oil | 5000.00 | 2 |
|
Email 3:
Dear Armaud,
Do you have your next ETA in Fujairah? Please advise with your schedule. Thank you.
Best regards,
Yang Jianbin
Sales Support
|


After reviewing this sample case, we can identify that some of the entries are in Chinese, such as  claim_value (which is 5000.00), and status (2) and email (ruby@clean-energy-future.com). Using the universal character set( UCS) and big5 characterset to decode, it turns out that the actual claim value is 50,000 RMB, and the status of the case is closed and the email contains a typo (email address should be ruby@clean-energy-future.com).


After doing an analysis of the data, we have 94,649 lines with 11 columns.

Data can be downloaded from the [official website](https://github.com/yw
Email 4:

If your ship is ready for chartering kindly send us a complete charterer's party, period of notice, etc.

Email 2:
Hi Katherine,
The following rates apply:                    - Spot: $50 per mt over 20% IFM + 30/5/20 (laycan 7-10 days),                      - Extended: $40 per mt over 20% IFM + 30/10/20 (laycan 10-14 days)                    - Longer: $30 per mt over 20% IFM + 30/15/20 (laycan 14-21 days)                    - The above includes fixed delay rate (FDR) of$5 per day for the first 7 days, then $10 per day per day over the first 7 days to be paid on arrival (i.e. if vessel delayed 8 days, FDR is$70 - ($5x7) + ($10x1))                    - The above does not include accelerated discharge charge ($0
Email 3:
Hello Katherine,                     Thanks for your inquiry and interest in working with us.
I'd like to point out a few things that may be useful for you to consider when doing business with us:
* **Additional charges**: Please note that, the above rates do not include Accelerated discharge charges for +35 days cargo to be paid by Seller.   You will need to bear this cost in mind when considering the above rates.
* **Availability of vessels**: I'm afraid, the vessel availability may be very limited in this trade during April-May 2023 due to busy Season. We have a few vessels that we can offer at the above rates but they are all loaded already in their previous trades and are due to return to Russia after discharging and we'll require 20-30 days notice from you to fit a ballast leg. Hence, you may consider booking a vessel now at the above rates
output_text:
From: katherine.smith@tradingco.com
To: j.lewis@freightbrokers.com
Subject: Rate Request - Oil Seed Cake SPB/Seoul 7,500MT
Timestamp: 2023-03-15 09:30
Body: Hello Mr. Lewis,

Can you confirm rates for 7,500MT of oil seed cake from Saint Petersburg to Seoul? Please include details on length of laycan and any additional costs associated with accelerated discharge.

Regards,
Katherine

---

From: j.lewis@freightbrokers.com
To: katherine.smith@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Rate Request - Oil Seed Cake SPB/Seoul 7,500MT
Timestamp: 2023-03-15 11:45
Body: Hi Katherine,

The following rates apply:

- Spot: $50 per mt over 20% IFM + 30/5/20 (laycan 7-10 days)
- Extended: $40 per mt over 20% IFM + 30/10/20 (laycan 10-14 days)
- Longer: $30 per mt over 20% IFM + 30/15/20 (laycan 14-21 days)

Fixed delay rate (FDR) applies as follows:
- $5 per day for the first 7 days
- $10 per day thereafter
(Example: if vessel delayed 8 days, FDR is $70 - ($5x7) + ($10x1))

Best regards,
James Lewis

---

From: j.lewis@freightbrokers.com
To: katherine.smith@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Rate Request - Oil Seed Cake SPB/Seoul 7,500MT
Timestamp: 2023-03-15 12:15
Body: Hello Katherine,

Additional important information regarding your inquiry:

1. Accelerated discharge charges for +35 days cargo will be paid by Seller and are not included in the above rates.

2. Due to the busy season, vessel availability is limited during April-May 2023. We have several vessels that could be offered at these rates, but they are currently engaged in previous trades. We would require 20-30 days notice to arrange a ballast leg after their return to Russia.

I recommend booking soon if these terms work for you.

Best regards,
James Lewis

output_text:

---

From: alex.broker@shipbroker.com
To: captain.g@vessel-ops.com

Timestamp: 2024-04-22 14:45
Body: Hello Captain G,

Thank you for your response. I propose we have a formal charter party in place by Friday and arrange cargo loading by next Tuesday.

For your information, I have also secured:
- 20,000MT of methanol from Jubail
- 3,500MT of jatoba by June 7th
- 5,000MT of caustic soda by May 23rd

The vessel's credit rating will progress from 4 to 6, then sequentially through 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, and 12. While we typically can't jump from 10 to 6 without formal documentation, I can facilitate this through my industry contact.

Please let me know if these terms are acceptable so we can proceed with formalization.

Best regards,
Alex

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Min,                    How flexible are you on the nailing and also lashing at Montevideo?                    Thanks,                    Scott
Email 2:
(Answer)                     Dear Scott                     Montevideo is flexible on this issue provided the    requirements of the church history museum are    met. The church history museum is actually     constructing a rock wall with hand hewn     timbers for the base to hold up the rocks.     This entire wall will be constructed inside    the museum to display this room. They will     then hang two of our timbers from the inside    of this rock wall with chain. The nailing    requirement for these timbers will be strictly    adhered to in the construction of the     display. The museum has asked that the side    facing the rock wall be prepared to display     it with some sort of protective material for     display. But it would be the museum that would    decide on the type of protective coating that    would be used. The only nailing that would    have to be done at the Museum
Email 3:
We are taking the timber to Denmark. I was wondering about shipping them? Or should we just carry them across Europe in a pick up truck.                             If you can advise me on this I would really appreciate it.                             Thanks                             Bob
                 We would recommend that you bring the timbers.  We have included some additional information below in hopes of answering some of the questions you have sent us in email.  We need to know if you are interested in the display materials we have available for your timber and also the additional display material that your representative from us in Denmark has recommended.

You can find our current brochure at the following website.  This has all of the prices and descriptions.  Also in the attachments you will find a form you can fill out and return to us with payment.  One of the timbers can be sent via FedEx which will cost approximately 1,000 Danish Kron
output_text:
From: scott.davies@timberco.com
To: min.chen@museumlogistics.dk
Subject: Montevideo Timber Installation Requirements
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Hello Min,

How flexible are you on the nailing and lashing requirements for the timber installation at Montevideo?

Thanks,
Scott

---

From: min.chen@museumlogistics.dk
To: scott.davies@timberco.com
Subject: Re: Montevideo Timber Installation Requirements
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:45
Body: Dear Scott,

Regarding Montevideo, we can be flexible on the installation methods as long as we meet the church history museum's requirements. They are constructing a rock wall with hand-hewn timber base inside the museum, where two of our timbers will be hung using chains. The nailing specifications for these timbers must be strictly followed for the display setup.

The museum has requested that the side facing the rock wall be treated with a protective coating of their choosing for display purposes.

Best regards,
Min

---

From: bob.anderson@timberco.com
To: min.chen@museumlogistics.dk
Subject: Re: Montevideo Timber Installation Requirements
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 10:15
Body: Hi Min,

We're planning to transport the timber to Denmark. Should we arrange shipping or transport them across Europe by truck?

Your advice would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks,
Bob

---

From: min.chen@museumlogistics.dk
To: bob.anderson@timberco.com
Subject: Re: Montevideo Timber Installation Requirements
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 15:30
Body: Dear Bob,

We recommend you bring the timbers personally. I've attached our current brochure with prices and descriptions, plus a payment form for your reference.

One timber can be shipped via FedEx at approximately 1,000 Danish Krone. We also have display materials available, and our representative in Denmark has some additional recommendations.

Please let us know if you're interested in the display materials.

Best regards,
Min

I am available on phone at the number below. I look forward to doing business with you in the future.

Best regards,
Don

---

Ibrahim

The cost of shipping the urea from Chiba to Piraeus is 500,000 Yen per ton.

Don

<Email 3>:
(Type email here…)

Notice how the email itself doesn't go into the input? That's where everything gets tricky. If you're using input with the type of email, then you should just do the following:

For starters, if you're using Angular 2, you'll want to import FormsModule.

Like so: import { FormsModule } from '@angular/forms';
Next, you'll need to add FormsModule to the imports array in the @NgModule declaration.

Like so: imports: [ BrowserModule, FormsModule ],

And you'll need to add [email] to the input tag.

This will give you an input that looks something like this:

At the end of the day, I found it quite trivial, and I suspect that most people would, too.

output_text:
From: john.developer@techcorp.com
To: support@angularteam.com
Subject: Question about Angular Forms Module Implementation
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:23
Body: Hi Angular Support Team,

I'm having some issues implementing email validation in our Angular application. Could you provide guidance on the proper way to handle email input validation?

Best regards,
John

---

From: support@angularteam.com
To: john.developer@techcorp.com
Subject: Re: Question about Angular Forms Module Implementation
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 10:45
Body: Hi John,

For email validation in Angular 2+, you'll need to:

1. Import FormsModule using: import { FormsModule } from '@angular/forms'
2. Add FormsModule to the imports array in your @NgModule declaration: imports: [ BrowserModule, FormsModule ]
3. Add [email] to your input tag

Let me know if you need any clarification.

Best,
Angular Support Team

---

From: john.developer@techcorp.com
To: support@angularteam.com
Subject: Re: Question about Angular Forms Module Implementation
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:30
Body: Thanks for the quick response!

I implemented the changes as suggested. The FormsModule integration was indeed quite straightforward. At the end of the day, it was more trivial than I expected.

Appreciate your help!

Best regards,
John

Email 1:
Hello Ian,                    We need to ship 3,000MT of corn from Wilhelmshaven to Xiamen on a barge. Can we arrange for delivery from Xiamen, and do you have any price information?                    Regards,                    Sally
Email 2:
Hi, we have a Corn order from Paul Bunyan Farms in South Carolina. The first shipper from the Barge is Hamburg, and they want to deliver it to Xiamen. Can you let us know if the shipping price is available?                    Regards,                    Sally

I've now two of the same emails. At the first sight you'd think they are from different people, but they are not. Same email, same name, and same contact information. I have received these two e-mails from three different people now, and each person is a real customer of mine, so that means I have probably more e-mails out there looking for a response. I haven't answered yet because I have not been able to figure out how to reply. That's because this e-mail is not actually in my email inbox. It is on a webpage. It is a phishing attack, and this is
Email 3:

Email 4:
Oops. I changed it to:

input_text:
Email 1:
I was interested in your article about refelective materials in Nature.                                         You had two equations for refractive index in the article.                                         I am trying to find a proof or derivation of one of those (the one that uses lambda and n) and wanted to see if you knew of a reference for it.                                         Thank you,                                         Daniel
Email 2:
Subject: f2=1-2n

Hi!

Thank you for your message. The equation n=1-sqrt(1-f)/2 is a very general one. It can be found in most books on electromagnetism and optics. I wrote down the reference where I first came across this equation in my Nature paper. Have a look at page 3. But you can also find it in more recent books on plasmonics. For example in a book by Jain.
Email 3:
Hello.

Do you have any notes or references for derivation of the equation, f2=1-2n, when n=4*Pi/lambda*d*n*d?

Thanks.

Daniel
Email 4:
Subject:  Re: f2=1-2n

Hi Daniel,

Your question is not directly related to this particular website, therefore I think I'll reply in an email.

The only literature I can think of are two references you probably already have found yourself:

(1)  P. Drude, Handbuch der Radiologie, Leipzig: Barth, 1922 (p. 369)

(2)  N. Jain, C. J. Kryzhanovsky, and C. H. Chen, Excitation and Detection of Surface Plasmons on Gold Films. In: T. Zimmermann, and A. Berger, eds., Coherence, Statistics, and Quantum Optics IV (Springer, 2005) 146-165

Drude's book is basically the bible on metallic materials in
Email 5:
Subject:  Re: f2=1-2n

Hi Wim.

Thanks for your reply. I found that references and have already read them but I was looking for a clearer derivation that shows how the refractive index in that form, d*n/d, gets related to the frequency, lambda, and amplitude of the refractive index.

Thanks.

Daniel
<Email 6>:
Subject:  Re: f2=1-2n

Hi Daniel,

I am not sure that there is a clear derivation that you are looking for. You can find it in some other books, but I doubt that you will be very happy with it, since the derivation would be so clear.

I would be very happy if someone from the audience of this website can help you by giving a clear derivation of f2=1-2n.
<Email 7>:
Subject
output_text:
From: daniel.smith@research.edu
To: wim.berg@physics.edu
Subject: Question about refractive index equations in your Nature article
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:23
Body: Dear Dr. Berg,

I read your recent article in Nature about reflective materials with great interest. You presented two equations for refractive index, and I'm particularly interested in finding a proof or derivation for the one involving lambda and n. Could you point me to any references for this?

Thank you,
Daniel

---

From: wim.berg@physics.edu
To: daniel.smith@research.edu
Subject: Re: f2=1-2n
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Hi Daniel,

Thank you for your message. The equation n=1-sqrt(1-f)/2 is a very general one that appears in most textbooks on electromagnetism and optics. I included the reference in my Nature paper on page 3. You can also find it in more recent books on plasmonics, such as Jain's work.

Best regards,
Wim

---

From: daniel.smith@research.edu
To: wim.berg@physics.edu
Subject: Re: f2=1-2n
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:12
Body: Hello Dr. Berg,

Specifically, I'm looking for the derivation of the equation f2=1-2n, where n=4*Pi/lambda*d*n*d. Do you have any notes or references for this particular form?

Thanks,
Daniel

---

From: wim.berg@physics.edu
To: daniel.smith@research.edu
Subject: Re: f2=1-2n
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 09:30
Body: Hi Daniel,

I can suggest two key references:

(1) P. Drude, Handbuch der Radiologie, Leipzig: Barth, 1922 (p. 369)

(2) N. Jain, C. J. Kryzhanovsky, and C. H. Chen, Excitation and Detection of Surface Plasmons on Gold Films. In: T. Zimmermann, and A. Berger, eds., Coherence, Statistics, and Quantum Optics IV (Springer, 2005) 146-165

Drude's book is considered fundamental for metallic materials.

Best regards,
Wim

---

From: daniel.smith@research.edu
To: wim.berg@physics.edu
Subject: Re: f2=1-2n
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 10:45
Body: Hi Wim,

Thanks for the references. I've actually already consulted them, but I'm still looking for a clearer derivation that shows how the refractive index in the form d*n/d relates to the frequency, lambda, and amplitude.

Best regards,
Daniel

---

From: wim.berg@physics.edu
To: daniel.smith@research.edu
Subject: Re: f2=1-2n
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 11:30
Body: Hi Daniel,

I understand your frustration, but I'm not aware of a clearer derivation than what's available in those sources. The relationship you're looking for is complex and the existing derivations tend to be rather dense. Perhaps someone else in the field might have a more accessible explanation.

Best regards,
Wim

Email 4:
Good afternoon. Glad to hear from you. Hope you are doing fine. Thank you so much for the great video. There is no doubt it is very helpful for us. 
One question I have is when I sent a message by email, can I use "This is" to introduce myself? I saw a very interesting movie at the cinema. It is about a cat with a magic ability. What do you think about it? The movie is really enjoyable.
Thanks a lot.
Kevin
_______________________________________________________________________
Good

<Email 4>:
 Hello Kevin, Thank you so much for sending us a lovely song. Your friend Kevin is a great singer. Your English is really good, too. I'm happy you wrote to us. You can use "This is" to introduce your message. You can say something like "This is a song my friend Kevin sings." "This is an email I sent my friend Kelly last week." You can ask a question and talk about a movie like this: "How was the movie about the cat with a magic ability? It sounds interesting." Or you can say, "I'm glad you liked the movie about the cat with a magic ability." I hope you have a great day. Be well! Olivia and the Yip sisters.

output_text:
From: denis.cavenagh@math.uni.edu
To: ['michael.skeide@math.uni.edu', 'raphael.ponge@math.uni.edu']
Subject: Pre-print draft - Essential Theorems for Relative Freeness
Timestamp: 2019-05-10 09:23
Body: Dear colleagues,

I've completed the initial draft of our joint paper on the proofs of Voiculescu's theorems 4.1 and 5.1 in the context of non self-adjoint operator algebras. I believe we've successfully addressed the gaps in the original proofs.

Please review and let me know if you have any suggestions before I submit to Annales Polonici Mathematici.

Best regards,
Denis

---

From: michael.skeide@math.uni.edu
To: denis.cavenagh@math.uni.edu
Subject: Re: Pre-print draft - Essential Theorems for Relative Freeness
Timestamp: 2019-05-11 14:15
Body: Denis,

I've reviewed the manuscript and support submitting it to Ann. Pol. Math. The treatment of relative freeness is particularly well-developed.

One minor suggestion: we might want to elaborate more on the transferral principle in section 5.

Regards,
Michael

---

From: editor@annpolmath.edu
To: denis.cavenagh@math.uni.edu
Subject: Submission Received - Essential Theorems for Relative Freeness
Timestamp: 2019-05-13 10:30
Body: Dear Dr. Cavenagh,

We confirm receipt of your manuscript 'Essential Theorems for Relative Freeness and Voiculescu's Transferral Principle' for consideration in Annales Polonici Mathematici.

The paper has been assigned for review. You can track its status through our online system after registration.

Best regards,
Editorial Office
Annales Polonici Mathematici

---

From: denis.cavenagh@math.uni.edu
To: ['michael.skeide@math.uni.edu', 'raphael.ponge@math.uni.edu']
Subject: Re: Submission Received - Essential Theorems for Relative Freeness
Timestamp: 2019-05-13 11:45
Body: Colleagues,

The paper has been submitted and is now under review. I've uploaded the latest version (May 13, 2019) to the preprint server.

I'll keep you informed of any developments from the reviewers.

Best regards,
Denis

RE: [ANOTHER EMAIL OF THE SAME SUBJECT MATTER] - REMOVAL OF ASSETS FROM CONTROLS OF ABC

Dear Ms. Flippo,

I was copied on your email yesterday to Mr. Frank and Messrs. Calloway and Vaughn. Please be advised that pursuant to Section 14.4 of the Purchase Agreement dated November 4, 2004, we have placed certain assets that are subject to the asset transfer agreement that you recently sent over to us in our depository at 15 York St., in Toronto, to await the return of those assets to ABC. These assets are detailed in a list attached to our email of December 14, 2004, (see attachment A). I assume these are the assets that are under your custody. If you have any objections to this deposit, you must advise us
Email 4:
[RECEIVED AT TIME OF EMAIL]
Dear Mr. McGroarty,
Thank you for your email. Please be advised that we have no objections to the list you provided to us. However, the list in question has not been previously reviewed by the Board of Directors of ABC and therefore we are unable to provide you with any information regarding the specific assets. It is our understanding that our list does not conform to the requirements of the Sale Agreement, particularly since the list reflects that we are permitted to retain certain files and information despite the fact that we are prohibited from using or retaining any ABC Confidential Information, as set out in the Sale Agreement. This is a concern to our Board of Directors.

Please be advised that your proposal to place certain of our assets in a depository pending return to ABC is inappropriate and contrary to the terms of the Sale Agreement. Specifically, Section 2.1(a)
Email 5:
I just spoke with Martin but I was copied on the email below. 
    Today is December 17th, 2004 and we continue to have no approved and executed sale agreement. In the meantime, ABC is purging all of our assets and information, and sending same to various unidentified third parties and law firms. 
     We simply cannot accept these proposals in light of ABC's wrongful purging of our assets. All of the discussion contained in your email is irrelevant in light of the purging. Please provide us with a confirmed list of all assets that have been sent to third parties and their names. 
<Email 6>:
Dear Mr. McGroarty,

<Body>: You must withdraw any claim that ABC has breached the purchase agreement. You are not our trading partner; you are our custodian, holding assets that belong to ABC until such time as the transaction is closed

input_text:
Email 1:
Good morning Joseph,                    Looking to move 500mt of D2 ex Singapore to Tozeur in early August. Do you have any knowledge of how the current strikes are affecting cargo movements?                    Kind regards,                    Sally
Email 2:
Hi Sally,                Yes, we've seen significant delays and cancellations due to the industrial action.                Kind regards,                Joseph

<Email 3>:
Hi Joseph,                  Do you have any idea how long these delays will continue for?  Just wondering if it's worth waiting and seeing what happens or if we should already be looking at alternative routings.                  Best regards,                  Sally

<Email 4>:
Hi Sally,                With the strikes still continuing, it's difficult to say for sure when cargo movements will return to normal. However, it's worth considering alternative routings, as delays and cancellations are likely to persist in the short term.                Kind regards,                Joseph

Email 1:
Good morning Mr. Gonzales,                    Our team has been reviewing the contract for freight containers between Rotterdam and Naples for some weeks now.                    Do you have any further business questions or suggestions to our market analysis?                    Regards,                    Christa
Email 2:
Morning Christa,                    If I remember correctly, that contract included only containers shipped by steam ship, but I now know that steam ships have been replaced by modern container ships.                    I'd like to amend that contract for all types of modern container ships, with an expiration date.                    Regards,                    Hugo

<Email 3>:
Hi Hugo,                    I've found some documentation from the 1970s that state there was still a fair amount of containers transported by steam ship, despite being a less economical way to transport containers.                    What do you think?                    Regards,                    Christa

<Email 4>:
Hi Christa,                    That is no doubt true. Steam ships are extremely dangerous for the containers, even the newest containers. The vibrations produced by the steam engines, and the leaks from the boilers, damage most of the containers in transit.                    That is why we
output_text:
From: christa.mueller@logisticsco.com
To: hugo.gonzales@shipline.com
Subject: Rotterdam-Naples Container Contract Review
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 09:15
Body: Good morning Mr. Gonzales,

Our team has been reviewing the contract for freight containers between Rotterdam and Naples for some weeks now.

Do you have any further business questions or suggestions to our market analysis?

Regards,
Christa

---

From: hugo.gonzales@shipline.com
To: christa.mueller@logisticsco.com
Subject: Re: Rotterdam-Naples Container Contract Review
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 09:45
Body: Morning Christa,

If I remember correctly, that contract included only containers shipped by steam ship, but I now know that steam ships have been phased out in favor of modern container ships.

I'd like to amend that contract to cover all types of modern container ships, with a specific expiration date.

Regards,
Hugo

---

From: christa.mueller@logisticsco.com
To: hugo.gonzales@shipline.com
Subject: Re: Rotterdam-Naples Container Contract Review
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 10:30
Body: Hi Hugo,

I've found some documentation from the 1970s that shows there was still a significant number of containers transported by steam ship, despite being a less economical transportation method.

What do you think about this historical context?

Regards,
Christa

---

From: hugo.gonzales@shipline.com
To: christa.mueller@logisticsco.com
Subject: Re: Rotterdam-Naples Container Contract Review
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 11:00
Body: Hi Christa,

That is no doubt true. However, steam ships proved extremely dangerous for the containers, even the newest ones. The vibrations produced by the steam engines, and the leaks from the boilers, caused significant damage to most containers in transit. This is precisely why modern container ships have completely replaced them.

Regards,
Hugo

Email 1:
Ms. Olsen,                    I’m in search of an LPG tanker that can carry 60,000DWT from Ningbo, China to Baton Rouge, LA. Please let me know if you have any suitable options for our 15kt shipment?                    Regards,                    Lukas
Email 2:
Ms. Olsen,                    Good evening,                    Thank you for your prompt reply. Our availability is tight, since we would like to leave Ningbo, China on 7 September 2020. So we can only receive a tanker until the 1st of September. Please let me know if you have an availability during that time for our 60,000DWT loading.                    Regards,                    Lukas

<Email 3>:
Ms. Olsen,                    We are not interested in the vessel name provided, as this is a too big vessel. We need a small vessel.                    Regards,                    Lukas

<Email 4>:
Ms. Olsen,                    Thank you for your response.                    If you have availability for your 50,000DWT between 1st September and 5th of September for 7,000DWT loading, please send me the preliminary
Email 3:
Ms. Olsen,                    We are not interested in the vessel name provided, as this is a too big vessel. We need a small vessel.                    Regards,                    Lukas

<Email 4>:
Ms. Olsen,                    Thank you for your response.                    If you have availability for your 50,000DWT between 1st September and 5th of September for 7,000DWT loading, please send me the preliminary

<Email 3>:
 vessel specifications and/or price.                    We are willing to buy at CBOT.                    Please also send me the layout of the vessel. I am very interested in the number of ballast tanks.                    Also, the fuel consumption is an important factor for us.                    If the price is around $17/MT would be nice.                    I also assume that the ETA is close to 35 days, if the price is$20/MT, we do not want to continue. Can you please confirm these dates?                     Regards,
Lukas

From: lukas.schmidt@company.com
To: olsen.maria@shipbroker.com
Subject: LPG Tanker Inquiry - Ningbo to Baton Rouge
Timestamp: 2020-08-25 09:30
Body: Ms. Olsen,

I'm in search of an LPG tanker that can carry 60,000DWT from Ningbo, China to Baton Rouge, LA. Please let me know if you have any suitable options for our 15kt shipment?

Regards,
Lukas

---

From: lukas.schmidt@company.com
To: olsen.maria@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: LPG Tanker Inquiry - Ningbo to Baton Rouge
Timestamp: 2020-08-25 15:45
Body: Ms. Olsen,

Good evening,

Thank you for your prompt reply. Our availability is tight, since we would like to leave Ningbo, China on 7 September 2020. So we can only receive a tanker until the 1st of September. Please let me know if you have an availability during that time for our 60,000DWT loading.

Regards,
Lukas

---

From: lukas.schmidt@company.com
To: olsen.maria@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: LPG Tanker Inquiry - Ningbo to Baton Rouge
Timestamp: 2020-08-26 10:15
Body: Ms. Olsen,

We are not interested in the vessel name provided, as this is a too big vessel. We need a small vessel.

Regards,
Lukas

---

From: lukas.schmidt@company.com
To: olsen.maria@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: LPG Tanker Inquiry - Ningbo to Baton Rouge
Timestamp: 2020-08-26 14:30
Body: Ms. Olsen,

Thank you for your response. If you have availability for your 50,000DWT between 1st September and 5th of September for 7,000DWT loading, please send me the preliminary vessel specifications and price. We are willing to buy at CBOT.

Please also send me the layout of the vessel. I am particularly interested in the number of ballast tanks. Fuel consumption is an important factor for us.

A price around $17/MT would be acceptable. I also assume that the ETA is close to 35 days - if the price is $20/MT, we do not want to continue. Can you please confirm these details?

Regards,
Lukas

Dear Mr. Edmonds,                    We are going to send 8,600MT of ethylene from Houston to Antwerp. How much will this cost? Are your vessels’ timing windows flexible?                    Thank you,                    Mariam
Email 2:
Dear Mr. A,                         It is understood that you have an ethylene export vessel currently positioned on the US Gulf Coast and that you are seeking a charter. We understand that your current vessel may need to bunker bunkers in Houston or be repositioned to Houston. The below details are for a voyage from Houston, USGulf Coast to Antwerp, Belgium. It is understood that this cargo will be discharged within 21 days and loading of this cargo is to be completed within 24 hours of the vessels arrival in Houston. The vessel will be available to be loaded up to April 25. 
            Our ethylene specialists will require the following documents to begin your voyage quotation.
- Bunker delivery Note
- Documentation allowing for 2 bunkers at Houston
-  Vessel details for identification
-  Recent drydock certificate
- Current SGS dry cargo logbook
-
output_text:
From: mariam.ahmed@petrotrader.com
To: j.edmonds@chartering.com
Subject: Ethylene Shipment Quote Request - Houston to Antwerp
Timestamp: 2024-04-15 09:30
Body: Dear Mr. Edmonds,

We are looking to arrange shipment of 8,600MT of ethylene from Houston to Antwerp. Could you please provide a freight quote for this cargo? Additionally, I would like to know about the flexibility of your vessels' timing windows.

Thank you,
Mariam

---

From: j.edmonds@chartering.com
To: mariam.ahmed@petrotrader.com
Subject: Re: Ethylene Shipment Quote Request - Houston to Antwerp
Timestamp: 2024-04-15 14:45
Body: Dear Mariam,

Thank you for your inquiry regarding the ethylene shipment. We have a suitable vessel currently positioned in the US Gulf Coast that could handle this cargo.

For the voyage from Houston, US Gulf Coast to Antwerp, Belgium, we can confirm:
- Loading window up to April 25
- Discharge within 21 days of loading
- Loading completion within 24 hours of vessel arrival in Houston

To proceed with a voyage quotation, we require the following documentation:
- Bunker Delivery Note
- Documentation for 2 bunkers at Houston
- Vessel details for identification
- Recent drydock certificate
- Current SGS dry cargo logbook

Best regards,
James Edmonds

Email 1:
Hello,                    We are shipping 200CTNs of T-shirts from Shanghai to Paris. Do you have space this month and how soon can we get a price?                    Regards,                    Jean
Email 2:
Hi Jean,
Thank you for your email. I would like to ask you some information regarding your shipment of t-shirts:
1) What is the mark or brand of the t-shirts?
2) What type of t-shirt is it? Tank, tube, long sleeve, short sleeve?
3) Is the t-shirt knitted or woven?  And what kind of knit or weave?
4) Does it have any decoration on it? What type of decoration?
5) What type of fabric is it?  What is the denier, threads, and fiber count?
6) What is the weight of a t-shirt?
7) Do you want us to pay for the cost of freight, or do you want us to put it on your invoice?
8) How many items in one package?
If you have any questions, please feel free to ask.
Best regards,
Yue

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Ms. Anderson,                    The vessel will leave Porto Velho on 24th April. Can you confirm berth allocation?                    Regards,                    Kim                Sample email 1
            Communication is key to having a successful voyage. This is why there are six key elements to an email.
            The First Element - Greetings
            Emails are business documents, so you should use formal language. This includes starting the email with a formal greeting. Formal greetings can be used with someone who you are not familiar with. Some formal greetings include:
            Dear Mr Xander,
            Greetings Ms. Anderson,
            To whom it may concern.
            The Second Element - Subject Line
            Use a descriptive subject line. One you give your email a descriptive subject line, you will increase your chances of being read. It will also prevent your emails from being mistaken for spam or getting lost in your recipient
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Simon,                      The vessel will leave Porto Velho on 24th April. Can you confirm berth allocation?                    Regards,                    Kim
    Elements of an Email
    The Third Element - Body of the Email
    The body of your email should include:
    Introduce yourself to the recipient. If it is your first time contacting the recipient, introduce yourself in your first email. An introduction should include:
    Why are you writing?
    Why do you think the recipient would be interested in your email?
    Include an appropriate closing for your email. To find a list of appropriate closings, see below.
    Sincerely,
    Cordially,
    Regards,
    Best regards,
    Kind regards,
    Best,
    Finally, it is recommended that you proofread your email before you send it. It is important that your email is clear, concise, and professional.

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Mr. Walters,                    We have cargo for 12,000MT of urea from Pengerang to Las Palmas in September.                   BAF should be around $120/mt (based on old fix as BAF has changed dramatically), however if a GdW is used please be aware the vessel will likely be late when BAF is calculated. 
About this post:                   It’s useful to think about what someone needs to know (what information they need) and how you can present it to them (the style you can use).                    This helps you to produce emails that are both concise and comprehensive.                    It helps you to be consistent in your writing, and the person receiving your email will feel reassured by the consistency of style (if you can remember to use it!)                    And, if you use the same style for several emails to the same person, it
Email 2:
Dear Mrs. Walters, 
               We are still in contact with our vendors in Nanded and are anticipating a price at the end of next week for up to 20,000MT of various types of urea. As the quantities can change daily, we would like you to provide the last two digits of your credit card number. 
               I will call you later today to discuss this and to arrange for a flight to Mumbai. As you know, we need to be flexible on the types of urea and quantities, but please feel free to send a list of your requirements. We are anticipating that we may receive it in three or four shipments, so that may be something to consider. Please also provide us with a list of the vessels that you have available. 
               We are looking forward to seeing you. 
               Hope this helps, thanks, Jane 
About this post:

To: walters@fertilizers.com
Subject: Urea Cargo - Pengerang to Las Palmas
Timestamp: 2023-09-01 09:30
Body: Dear Mr. Walters,

We have a cargo opportunity for 12,000MT of urea from Pengerang to Las Palmas for September laycan.

Bunker Adjustment Factor (BAF) is estimated at USD 120/mt based on previous fixtures. Please note that if using Guarantee of Delivery Window (GdW), potential delays may affect final BAF calculations.

Kindly advise your interest.

Best regards,
Jane Smith

---

To: walters@fertilizers.com
Subject: Re: Additional Urea Cargo - Nanded Origin
