Following our earlier correspondence, we are currently in discussions with our vendors in Nanded regarding up to 20,000MT of various urea grades. Price indications are expected by end of next week.

As quantities may fluctuate, we anticipate potential split shipments (3-4 parcels). Please share your vessel availability and specific grade requirements at your earliest convenience.

I will call you later today to discuss further details.

Best regards,
Jane

input_text:
Email 1: Hi James, Looking to move 5,8kmt of palm kernel oil from Port Klang to Male. Can you advise how the refrigeration is done in the holds. Cheers, Mona Email 2: Dear Mona, The refrigeration is done by ventilation - the holds are ventilated by system that draws air through ice cold seawater. The air is then used to keep the goods at right temperature. There is no refrigeration in the holds of our ships. In between, there are rooms for packages of bulk goods. We could load the PKE in these rooms. It should fit in one or two such rooms. The loading rate would be 7-8t per hour. The max weight per carcase is 1.500kg. The container could not handle heavier carcases. To prevent damage of the PKE during loading, we have made special arrangements for the loading. The shell of the PKE must be closed after being loaded and we suggest using special sealing material for this purpose. A sample of this material can be sent if you wish. Should you Email 3: Hi James, That sounds good. I can arrange the product to arrive in 20 ft containers. The dimensions are as follows: The biggest one is 140cm x 75cm x 37cm and the heaviest is 1270kgs. We need 5 containers. I can arrange the sealing material, do you have the dimensions of the rooms you have in mind? Thanks again. Mona Email 4: Dear Mona, The rooms are about 8,5m by 2,9m, 2,8m high. That should be sufficient. A container is the best to move it. We have also made arrangements for transporting the PKE in ISO containers. If you have difficulties to do so, we could also load the goods at our port in Port Klang, moving the goods in our own trucks from there. Should you have further questions, please let me know. Best regards, James Kleine
Managing Director, Kleine Business Consultancy
Maritima Massey Building
41 Massey Road
Sandton
2196
Johannesburg
+27 (11) 684-3387
+27 (83) 322-5294 (mobile)
kleine@net
output_text:
From: mona.trading@gmail.com
To: james.kleine@kleineconsult.com
Subject: Palm Kernel Oil Shipment Inquiry - Port Klang to Male
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:15
Body: Hi James,

Looking to move 5.8KMT of palm kernel oil from Port Klang to Male. Can you advise how the refrigeration is done in the holds?

Cheers,
Mona

---

From: james.kleine@kleineconsult.com
To: mona.trading@gmail.com
Subject: Re: Palm Kernel Oil Shipment Inquiry - Port Klang to Male
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 11:30
Body: Dear Mona,

The refrigeration is done by ventilation - the holds are ventilated by a system that draws air through ice-cold seawater. This air maintains the cargo at the required temperature. We don't have traditional refrigeration in our vessel holds, but we do have specialized rooms for bulk goods packaging.

We could accommodate the PKE in these rooms, likely requiring one or two compartments. The loading rate would be 7-8t per hour, with a maximum weight limit of 1,500kg per unit.

To protect the PKE during loading, we've implemented special handling procedures. The product must be properly sealed after loading, and we recommend specific sealing materials for this purpose. We can provide samples if needed.

Best regards,
James

---

From: mona.trading@gmail.com
To: james.kleine@kleineconsult.com
Subject: Re: Palm Kernel Oil Shipment Inquiry - Port Klang to Male
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:45
Body: Hi James,

That sounds good. I can arrange the product to arrive in 20ft containers. The dimensions are as follows:

Largest unit: 140cm x 75cm x 37cm
Maximum weight: 1,270kgs
Total requirement: 5 containers

I can arrange the sealing material, but could you please confirm the dimensions of the rooms you have in mind?

Thanks again,
Mona

---

From: james.kleine@kleineconsult.com
To: mona.trading@gmail.com
Subject: Re: Palm Kernel Oil Shipment Inquiry - Port Klang to Male
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 16:20
Body: Dear Mona,

The rooms measure 8.5m x 2.9m with 2.8m height, which should be sufficient for your needs. Container transport is indeed the optimal solution, and we're equipped to handle ISO containers.

We can also offer trucking services from Port Klang if needed, using our own vehicles.

Please let me know if you have any further questions.

Best regards,
James Kleine
Managing Director
Kleine Business Consultancy
Maritima Massey Building
41 Massey Road
Sandton 2196
Johannesburg
Tel: +27 (11) 684-3387
Mobile: +27 (83) 322-5294
Email: kleine@net

output_text:
From: noa.smith@shipping-ops.com
To: operations@eurotug.com
Subject: Vessel Pilotage and Port Call Query - Gdynia to Liverpool
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Dear EUROTUG Operations,

I would like to inquire about the possibility of a same-day port call between Gdynia and Liverpool for an upcoming vessel operation. Additionally, could you please clarify the pilotage requirements and rates?

Regards,
Noa

---

From: operations@eurotug.com
To: noa.smith@shipping-ops.com
Subject: Re: Vessel Pilotage and Port Call Query - Gdynia to Liverpool
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Dear Noa,

Thank you for your inquiry. Please note the following pilotage requirements:

- Mandatory pilot services for tankers at Sulzheim and Ettlingen
- Mandatory pilotage for vessels over certain draft at other Rhine terminals
- Mandatory for vessels without canal-certified ship masters

EUROTUG's minimum towage rates apply to short draft vessels, though rates may vary based on specific circumstances.

Regarding same-day operations between Gdynia and Liverpool, this would not be feasible due to the transit time required.

Please let us know if you need any additional information.

Best regards,
EUROTUG Operations

Warmly,                    Nicoletta

Since then, Nicolas has been waiting for an answer. When should he send a follow-up email?

## What the Social Norms Suggest

I asked 100 people the following question: Is it acceptable to wait for more than 10 days after an email is sent and not hear back? 35% of people said yes, 65% said no. So, what should he do?

## What the Stats Show

The text analysis service I use, Linguamatics, returned
Email 3:
At a first glance the email looks like the perfect email to send for this scenario; however, this is not the case as it is not very friendly. This could lead to someone feeling undermined, which could lead to the email recipient ignoring this email in hopes of less negativity from the sender. Which is the opposite of what we want. If we were to send this email to a sales person in hopes of securing the sale we would be sabotaging our chances of getting the sale because the person we are sending this to, may feel undermined and will respond less happily than if we had sent the second email. As well as providing a better response, the second email provides all of the information needed to complete the transaction and then asks for the decision. This shows professionalism and a desire to complete the transaction on both ends. In both cases the email offers the promise of a future reply, this may be the
Email 4:
I have been wondering when I will hear back about the shipment of latex for Valencia. August 12 is the deadline, so we need to make a decision soon. Please let me know if the August 18 date for departure is acceptable, and then we can close the deal.                    Warmly,                    Nicolas
@source_envisage: How long would you wait to get a response to an email?

Another example:

<Email 2>:

And still another:

Email 1:
Hi, could you please provide your best rate for shipment of 2,000 MT of 2,2,4-Trimethylpentane from Singapore to Hamburg, and can you provide vessel
Email 3:
That price is the only price I have, I will not go lower.
Could you please provide the vessel details for the voyage? Best,                  Ella
Email 4:
I would like to have the vessel details for the voyage. How about FOB and CFR? Best,                  Ella

If you look at the exchanges above, you’ll note the common themes. Firstly, each of these sets of emails contains the same issue: a cargo shipment price inquiry with vessel and shipping details requested. Secondly, we see, in nearly every single instance, the respondent adding a short and terse phrase at the end of the first reply, as follows:
“I would like to have the vessel details for the voyage. How about FOB and CFR? Best,                  Ella”

There is another small issue: the unvarying second email address (ella(@)marketmanager.de). Using the email header information, this address is seen to have been used by the same person to send all emails to the parties in the test sample. There is also a strong suspicion that this address is a
Email 5:
How about FOB and CFR? Best,                  Ella

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Ms. Patel,                    I need to send 1,000MT of maize from Poti to Zelenodolsk before the end of this week. What is your earliest loading date? And what kind of dispatch incentives do you offer?                    Best regards,                    Rudolf
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Tofts,                I can offer you the cheapest shipping options from Poti to Zelenodolsk: the transit time is only 5 days. Please check our webpage: https://baltshipping.net/en/shipping-port-poti/                    I will be very glad to see you soon in Poti!                    Best regards,                    Rudolf

The first email describes a negotiation for the sale of a commodity (in this case, maize). This kind of email, which we refer to as a negotiation email, is an important genre for a business that engages in negotiation with potential buyers and sellers. 

You can use such a negotiation email as an inspiration for your own, when you negotiate with a partner company. In the following paragraphs, I will discuss the parts of the above example email, showing you how they were composed, why they are important, and what the pros and
Email 3:
Dear Ms. Bellichi,                Please take a look at our offers and choose a suitable one. The earlier you confirm, the better discount we can offer. Thanks for your attention.                    Best regards,                    Antanina

This is the reply to an inquiry email, i.e. an email that responds to a potential customer's inquiry about the products and services offered by a company. It contains all the information the recipient needs and provides enough context for her to make a decision, including the pricing and the delivery terms.
Email 4:
Dear Ms. Samsya,                     We will send you a quote shortly. Have a nice day.                    Best regards,                    Ido

Hello!
Thank you for your request!
Your quote will be with you very soon.
Have a nice day.
Yours,
The Fones team

This is the end of the email, which is as important as its beginning. If the body of an email ends with a formality, it feels nice and appropriate to the recipient. However, if the ending part of the email contains information that does not pertain to the topic of the email, it may be confusing.
Email 5:
Hello!
Thank you for your request!
Your quote will be with you very soon.
Have a nice day.
Yours,
The Fones team

input_text:
Email 1:
We are looking for a voyage from October 25th to 28th for 26,000MT.                    Best regards,                    Gavin
Email 2:
We are looking for a voyage from October 25th to 28th for 26,000MT.                   Best regards,                   Gavin


## Reference number

Not present

## Vocabulary (1)

- **10k** 10,000
- **.5** 1/2, half

## Adverbs

**On** **October 25th**
Email 3:
Dear Madame/Sir
We are looking for a voyage from October 25th to 28th for 26,000MT.

To **be looking** **for** a voyage

To **do** something, the subject is doing, the action. 

Compare:
To **be** waiting for a friend.

We are looking for a voyage means that they need someone to buy their product.  

One must use the passive for this sentence. 
We have the object in the sentence - voyage.  This can be changed to object of the preposition **for** - voyage **for**.  
This change turns the whole sentence into the passive sentence.

The subject will be the preposition. 
We know this because the preposition **for** comes before the subject.  We can make it **a voyage**.

We are **looking** for **a voyage**

The question is
Email 4:
**Who** are **looking** **for** **a voyage**

Answer **They** are looking for a voyage. 

## Common mistake in student papers

1. Using the active form for these sentences.  

We do not use the active form when there is a preposition after the subject.  
It should be  
**He** is looking **for** a house. 
We have the active form **He** is looking, but **for** comes after it.
We change the active form to the passive form, thus creating the passive form.

**There** is looking **for** a house.

2. Removing the article. 

The article **a** is required to make the sentence active.  
**He** is looking **for** a house.  
If you remove **a**, you have created a passive sentence.

<Email 4>:
**Who** is looking

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi,                    We require a shipment of 4,000mt of maize from Mombasa to Mogadishu. Can you please confirm rate and availability.                    Kind Regards,                    Joe
Email 2:
Hi there,                    I have some seed crops that i want to export to Mombasa, Can you please advise on your charges and how best i can deliver it to your warehouse?                    Thank you                    Ali

There is an obvious difference in intent of these two emails, despite their similar opening lines.

Email 1 is making a clear request, and they go on to add an additional question ("Can you please confirm rate and availability?").

Email 2 is vague. They want to "advice" on shipping charges and how best to deliver to the Mombasa warehouse, but without specifying what the item they want to ship is, or what the conditions are.

They say they have some "seed crops", but how can we determine whether this is a valid offer or not without further information?

For my project, I need to identify emails like email 2 where the sender has not

From: yi-shen.liu@logisticsco.com
To: terry.pal@supplier.com
Subject: Import Delivery Terms and Documentation Requirements
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Hi Mr. Pal,

Could you please advise if we can deliver your import under EXW terms?

If so, could you provide a copy of the bill of lading as soon as it is available, and make sure you've sent a pre-arrival notification of the cargo and owner's details, so that we can facilitate berth preparations and other documentation.

Looking forward to hearing from you,
Yi-shen

---

From: terry.pal@supplier.com
To: yi-shen.liu@logisticsco.com
Subject: Re: Import Delivery Terms and Documentation Requirements
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:45
Body: Hi Yi-shen,

We can deliver your import cargo under EXW terms. While our suppliers can sell our product under CIF terms, our cargo is already loaded, and I believe our transportation cost under CIF may be higher than ex-works.

Regarding the B/L copy before arrival, could you confirm if this will be acceptable?

As for other documentation, we are not sure how to fill it in, as we only supply high technology components, and your export will be the final user.

Many thanks for your kind assistance.

Regards,
Terry

---

From: yi-shen.liu@logisticsco.com
To: terry.pal@supplier.com
Subject: Re: Import Delivery Terms and Documentation Requirements
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 08:15
Body: Hi Terry,

We do require a copy of the bill of lading to be sent to us before arrival. As for the final user, we don't mind, but we will need the information on the final user on the bill of lading, and we would like to know the manufacturer of the products as well, which I will need you to provide us with.

Regards,
Yi-shen

---

From: terry.pal@supplier.com
To: yi-shen.liu@logisticsco.com
Subject: Re: Import Delivery Terms and Documentation Requirements
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 11:30
Body: Hi Yi-shen,

Thanks for your reply.

We are very sorry, but I am afraid we are unable to provide you with the final user information, because the purchase of our product is for internal use only.

As for the name of the manufacturer, we are afraid that we are not allowed to disclose such information due to confidentiality reasons.

We are very sorry that we cannot help you with these details.

Best Regards,
Terry

Lloyd

Wanjia

1)         Determine whether the charter is open.

3)         Determine if buyer is legitimate. If not, waste time with Alice.

Email 1:
Dear sir,                    My colleague and I just picked the owners of 3 steel vessels from Guangzhou to Ulsan. Can you confirm the cargo space, and if you've already paid the berth dues?                    Cheers,                    Ramón
Email 2:
Dear Mrs. Carter,
                    I am confused about the sea cargo volume of my vessel. The agreement said 3,000 tons of Liquefied Petroleum Gas, with a total of 5,000 tons of oil. I'm looking at the cargo space of the GDDT-101 vessel for 7,800 tons. How come you've shipped so much cargo? The remaining space should have been filled with some rice, but I see none in the photos you sent.
                    Weigh the hull and contact me right away. Do you have any idea what your vessel will be rated? Do you want to remove some of the oil? Your vessel is large, the last time I was in an all-oil ship was in 2003.
                    Best regards,                    Camille
output_text:
From: ramon.garcia@seabrokers.com
To: camille.chen@pacific-shipping.com
Subject: Vessel Loading Status - Guangzhou to Ulsan
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 09:30
Body: Dear Camille,

My colleague and I have just completed pickup arrangements with the owners of three steel vessels from Guangzhou to Ulsan. Could you please confirm the available cargo space and verify if the berth dues have been paid?

Best regards,
Ramón

---

From: camille.chen@pacific-shipping.com
To: ramon.garcia@seabrokers.com
Subject: Re: Vessel Loading Status - Guangzhou to Ulsan
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 11:45
Body: Dear Ramón,

There seems to be a discrepancy with the cargo volumes on vessel GDDT-101. The agreement specified 3,000 tons of LPG and 5,000 tons of oil (total 8,000 tons), but the vessel has a cargo space of 7,800 tons. Additionally, the planned rice shipment appears to be missing from the cargo manifest.

Please have the hull weighed and advise on the vessel rating urgently. Would you like to adjust the oil quantity? Given the vessel's size and the full oil cargo, we need to ensure compliance with regulations.

Best regards,
Camille

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Janet,                    We are considering scheduling 800MT of crude oil from Daesan to Aberdeen mid-April. What can you do to expedite this process?                    Sincerely,                    Jeremy
Email 2:
Dear Jeremy,                    Just to say that I am concerned that the trip was not completed on time. The weather seems to have been the issue.                    If the next trip is too late, please consider the Tuna/Excelsior/Metal which are not ideal but are at least 3/4 capacity as we have yet to book Africa with Metocean.                    Regards,                    Tim
                    
This email was handed to me on my second day working in the Middle East. It was by far the biggest amount of confusion and annoyance that I had to deal with. I was originally meant to receive the request and push the execution to the Trade desk. However, I thought this was a time sensitive request and without any knowledge of weather and Middle Eastern conditions, I decided to respond via email. This was my first mistake.
            Considering that the deadline was mid-April, 6 weeks away
output_text:

To: jeremy.smith@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Crude Oil Shipment - Daesan to Aberdeen

Just to say that I am concerned about our previous shipment not being completed on time due to weather conditions.

For the upcoming mid-April shipment, please consider the vessels Tuna, Excelsior, or Metal. While not ideal, they are operating at least 75% capacity as we haven't yet confirmed our African routes with Metocean.

Regards,
Tim

The credit note is for one of your jobs to Red Star Logistics in January 2013. As you will see from my attached email, you will note that you did not pay the correct amount at the time, although you have now completed payment.                The reason that I have raised the credit note is that I was unable to obtain full payment of the correct amount from your company at the time. The customer service representatives for your company at the time have not been able to offer a full explanation as to why this was so.                In my personal view, a credit note would have been acceptable at the time, but our

Mark

Email 1:
Hi Jackie,                    I'd like to propose using your shipment of 1,500MT of fcc-grade naphtha from Rotterdam to Singapore with ETA 29th March. Do you have any vessel confirmations in hand for the last week of March?                    Best regards,                    Leah
Email 2:
Hi Leah,                    Thank you for your proposal. Kindly see the attached sailing sheet for my availability. Looking forward to hearing from you soon.                    Best regards,                    Becky
Email 3:
Dear Leah,                    It is a pleasure to work with you. Let me introduce our group as a leading supplier and trader of chemicals, offering a wide range of products, including naphtha, aromatics and organic acids, which have always been in high demand. We can offer you long-term cooperation at the most reasonable prices and are highly competitive.                    Here is our actual naphtha product with details, some of them are in stock. Looking forward to your inquiry and establishing a long term cooperation.                    Sincerely,                    George

<Email 4>:
Hi George,                    Thank you for your email. I would like to know the price terms of your proposal.                    Best regards,                    Leah

<Email 5>:
Dear Leah,                    Thank you for your email. Could you please confirm you require FOB Rotterdam or CIF Singapore?                    Best regards,                    George

Email 1:
To: Ito Yuko, Junseki Shoji Co Ltd, Tokyo, Japan                    CC: Teo, Lana, Praesepe Co, London, UK                    Hi Yuko,                    I heard that you will have several tankers in your fleet in the next few months. Could you take 6,500MT of soybean oil in Bangkok around the end of this month?                    Any answers?                                        Thanks,                    Takashi
Email 2:
From: Takashi Atsumi,  Teo, Praesepe Co, London, UK         To: Ito Yuko, Junseki Shoji Co Ltd, Tokyo, Japan             CC: Teo, Lana, Praesepe Co, London, UK             Hi Yuko,             Thank you for answering. We will not have any chance to take soybean oil. But we are always interested in having soybean oil for our transshipment at Thailand or Vietnam.             If you have any chance for us, please let me know.            Best regards,            Takashi
output_text:
From: takashi.atsumi@praesepe.co.uk
To: y.ito@junseki-shoji.co.jp
Subject: Soybean Oil Cargo Inquiry - Bangkok End of Month
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Hi Yuko,

I heard that you will have several tankers in your fleet in the next few months. Could you take 6,500MT of soybean oil in Bangkok around the end of this month?

Looking forward to your response.

Thanks,
Takashi

---

From: y.ito@junseki-shoji.co.jp
To: takashi.atsumi@praesepe.co.uk
Subject: Re: Soybean Oil Cargo Inquiry - Bangkok End of Month
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Hi Takashi,

Thank you for your inquiry. Unfortunately, we will not have any vessels available to take the soybean oil cargo at this time. However, we are always interested in future opportunities for soybean oil transshipment at Thailand or Vietnam.

Please keep us informed of any future opportunities.

Best regards,
Yuko

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Mr. Happy,                    I would like to place an order for 12,000MT of sugar from Asia to Europe. Please advise on available vessels, and I will get back to you.                    Best regards,                    Tanisha
Email 2:
Dear Tanisha,

I have an available vessel which will be ready on 19th October. Loading is ready at Singapore and discharge is ready at an Amsterdam port.

Please see my terms for this shipment. 40% of the price is payable at the time of signing the agreement and the balance upon delivery. I will wait for your kind confirmation.

Best Regards,
Rami

<Email 3>:
Dear Rami,

I will like to receive an official offer.  What are the details of this offer?

Best regards,
Tanisha
Email 3:
Dear Rami,

I will like to receive an official offer.  What are the details of this offer?

Best regards,
Tanisha

<Email 3>:
 Dear Tanisha,

I would like to confirm the price is $840/MT for CIF Amsterdam and L/C will be issued on 1 November 2011. Payment will be made at the time of the agreement and the balance upon delivery. I would also like to know which vessel is available to move the cargo? Best Regards, Rami <Email 3> Dear Tanisha, If you would be sending me a signed copy of the agreement then I will give you all the details. The rest can be filled at the time of delivery. Payment will be made at the time of the agreement and the balance upon delivery. The vessel which will be available for your cargo is MV Eleftheria. Best Regards, Rami

Email 1:
Hello Ben,                    We’re looking to ship 20,000MT of steel from Paldock to Monrovia. Could you send us your fcl rate and ETA? Also, is it possible to do a post-dated bill of lading?                    Thanks,                    Grace
Email 2:
Hi Grace,                    Attached you will find our quotations for Paldock to Monrovia for your steel cargo.                    We will send your cargo within three days of receipt of your irrevocable letter of credit in our account in London.                    Could you confirm that the steel can be shipped in containers? If not, do you have other requirements (such as barge?); and do you have any requirements for the steel?                    We can carry the bill of lading either to bearer or to the order of your bank, as you require.                    If you would like us to carry the bill of lading to bearer, please let us know when to expect the irrevocable letter of credit in our London account.                    You will find our payment terms at the bottom of the quotations.                    Please confirm your requirements and send us a draft irrevocable letter of credit to enable
Email 3:
Thank you very much.                    The cargo will be shipped in 20 foot containers, with 400 pieces per container. The cargo will be steel bars.                    Please deliver the bill of lading to bearer.                    I have forwarded the irrevocable letter of credit.                    Best regards,                    Grace
Email 4:
Hello,                    We have received your request.                    We will charge you USD 700 per 20 foot container.                    We will deliver the bill of lading as follows:                    We will issue the bill of lading to bearer.                    We will send the bill of lading and the other shipping documents to you within five days of the date that we receive the irrevocable letter of credit in our account in London.                    Best regards,                    Ben
You will see that in the first two emails, Ben goes a little off track. In the first email he doesn’t send the fcl rate and ETA. In the second email, he starts to talk about letters of credit when Grace never asked about that.

Back to the example in Ben’s favour

If not, do you have other requirements (such as barge?); and do you have any requirements for the steel?                    We can carry the bill of lading either to bearer or to the order of your bank, as you require. input_text:
Email 1:
Hello X,                    We want to charter a vessel to transport 2k MT of petroleum coke from Baku to Qingdao, China. Do you have any ship open in November?                    Regards,                    [name]
Email 2:
Hello,                    Best Price on spot by sea transport:                0,19 $/MT + 0,05$/MT bunker.                Subject: bunker..................  1/5 charter party done on GLS 2/5 cargo -petroleum coke - 20k MT 3/5 B/L paid - 100 % 4/5 sailing November 5/5 From - Baku, Azerbaijan to - Qingdao, China                Best Regards, [name]

What is the task?                    The task is to find an empty container, go to China (pay 0.19$/MT + 0.05$/MT bunker) and bring petroleum coke to Azerbaijan (20k MT, 100% B/L paid, sailing in November).

The main question for this task is, does the company have a vessel available to take the cargo?

What technique(s)
Email 3:
The main trick is to make this task look like it is for open charter. This makes the victim pay attention to the price, believing it is actually lower than the price of the chartered ship (by the way, let's make it 0.19$). By saying that you will pay 0.05$/MT for bunker, the victim thinks you are buying bunker, while you are actually renting the vessel.

    Also note that the shipping cost (0.19$) is given to the nearest part of the fourth decimal place, which might look suspicious if the sender and receiver have different countries. It is a very good trick to make such mistakes, as I did in email 2, or even in email 1 if the victim is inexperienced. It makes the victim think he is comparing two similar offers, which they are not, and look bad for not noticing it. Finally
output_text:

To: broker@shipping-co.com
Subject: Vessel Inquiry - Petroleum Coke Shipment Baku-Qingdao

We are looking to charter a vessel for transporting 20,000 MT of petroleum coke from Baku to Qingdao, China. Do you have any vessels available in November?

Best regards,
John

From: broker@shipping-co.com

Subject: Re: Vessel Inquiry - Petroleum Coke Shipment Baku-Qingdao

Body: Hello,

Thank you for your inquiry. We can offer spot shipping at:

Rate: USD 0.19/MT + USD 0.05/MT bunker surcharge

Details:

- Cargo: Petroleum coke - 20,000 MT
- B/L: 100% prepaid
- Sailing: November 2023
- Route: Baku, Azerbaijan to Qingdao, China

Best regards,
Mike

---

From: broker@shipping-co.com
To: internal@shipping-co.com
Subject: Internal Notes - Baku-Qingdao Charter
Timestamp: 2023-11-01 11:45
Body: Internal strategy notes:

Presenting as open charter to make rate appear competitive. Actual arrangement is vessel rental. Quote structure (0.19 + 0.05) designed to create impression of separate bunker costs while maintaining total desired rate.

Keeping decimal precision vague to discourage detailed rate comparison.

A proposal for CIF and FOB terms are as follows. For CIF and FOB we will not offer any competitive discount.
For terms CPT, CFR or FOB for Sea on board 19th August
Cash at Sight with T/T 100% to sellers account or irrevocable l/c confirmed by a prime ARA rated bank at 110% of c&f value.

For details on terms and conditions kindly see attachment

Have a good day !!!!

Love
Susan

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Dr. Nakamura,                    We have 5,000 metric tons of wheat in Ashdod and are looking to ship it to Karachi. Could you send us the full shipping schedule for May? Also could you give us your best quote to ship that date?                    Best,                    Gracie
Email 2:
Hi Gracie,
Thanks for your inquiry. Can you send me your complete address with postal codes?
<Email 3>:
Hi, our address is: Unilever Pakistan Limited, "OPP Tower", 
State Life Building No.1, 2nd Floor, Abdullah Haroon Road, 
M.A. Jinnah Road, Karachi, 74000 Pakistan.

Thank you very much!
Email 3:
Hi, our address is: Unilever Pakistan Limited, "OPP Tower", 
State Life Building No.1, 2nd Floor, Abdullah Haroon Road, 
M.A. Jinnah Road, Karachi, 74000 Pakistan.

Thank you very much!

<Email 3>:
 Hi, our address is: Unilever Pakistan Limited, "OPP Tower", 
State Life Building No.1, 2nd Floor, Abdullah Haroon Road, 
M.A. Jinnah Road, Karachi, 74000 Pakistan.

Thank you very much!

Hi Dr. Nakamura,
The shipping details we're looking at were for May. Are you looking at other dates?
Gracie

Hi Gracie,
Thank you for your email. I will wait for your reply.

This snippet represents two separate emails. The first emails are typical types of emails in any trade conversation. They represent the customer asking for the shipping schedule for May and for the best shipping quote for that date. In email 3, the customer sends the complete address.

The customer appears to have followed up again with an email to ask about a different date. Nakamura responds again by asking to wait for
Email 4:
Hi Gracie,
Thank you for your email. I will wait for your reply.

...[while Nakamura leaves for vacation. Nakamura's email box remains empty for a month, and she does not respond to Gracie's email.]

## 1 Answer

Nakamura would have followed up on the request as soon as possible; Nakamura was probably away on vacation for most of that time, so the email system was empty.

I think Nakamura could have sent an auto-responder or had her colleagues respond to email queries for her, while she was on vacation.

My job as a Process Safety Coordinator for a company operating in various Asian countries, I often have to send emails in Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Thai.  I’ve never needed to be away from my job for an extended period of time.

## Related questions

Why was the water not salinated in the aquarium

Email 2:
From: Marcus Eberhardt


Good afternoon Marcus,

Thank you for your prompt response.
As mentioned in my email, the 500MT of steel plates from Ulsan to Pusan would be ready for shipment on the 30th of August. Can you please confirm the following details of your company:
\* Your name and telephone number
\* I'm interested in receiving a quote, could you please quote for 500MT of steel plates on the 30th of August?
\* How often do you sail from Ulsan to Pusan?

Looking forward to hearing from you soon,
Irina

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Sir/Madam,                    We’d like to transport 2,900MT of cotton to Ghent from Huangpu. Could you let us know your best available rate, and do you work on a FCA basis?                    Thank you for your time,                    Henry
Email 2:
Dear Henry,                        Thanks for your mail. And I will try my best to find out the info from our cargo department. Best regards,                        Clark Chen
Email 3:
Dear Clark Chen,                     I am glad to hear from you. You could try any carrier please. If they have empty sailings, they would be happy to carry our goods, for our cargo is different from other goods, we transport it through containers instead of using trucks, so our goods are more sensitive.                     Let me know if you have questions or suggestions.                     Thank you!                     Henry
<Email 4>:
Dear Clark Chen,                     Thanks for your reply. Could you tell me which is the best choice? Our cargo usually transports at least 100,000 tons at a time. Is it better to transport by the whole container or shipper’s owned container?                     Please let me know if you have questions or suggestions.                     Thanks for your time!                     Henry
<Email 5>:
Dear Henry,                        Thanks for your mail. Sorry for my delay.                        By
output_text:
From: henry.smith@tradeco.com
To: clark.chen@freightservices.com
Subject: Cotton Shipment Quote Request - Huangpu to Ghent
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:15
Body: Dear Sir/Madam,

We'd like to transport 2,900MT of cotton to Ghent from Huangpu. Could you let us know your best available rate, and do you work on a FCA basis?

Thank you for your time,
Henry

---

From: clark.chen@freightservices.com
To: henry.smith@tradeco.com
Subject: Re: Cotton Shipment Quote Request - Huangpu to Ghent
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 10:30
Body: Dear Henry,

Thanks for your mail. I will try my best to find out the information from our cargo department.

Best regards,
Clark Chen

---

From: henry.smith@tradeco.com
To: clark.chen@freightservices.com
Subject: Re: Cotton Shipment Quote Request - Huangpu to Ghent
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 11:45
Body: Dear Clark Chen,

Thank you for your response. Please feel free to check with any carrier. Given that we transport via containers rather than trucks, and our cargo requires special handling, carriers with empty sailings might be interested.

Let me know if you have any questions or suggestions.

Thank you!
Henry

---

From: henry.smith@tradeco.com
To: clark.chen@freightservices.com
Subject: Re: Cotton Shipment Quote Request - Huangpu to Ghent
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:20
Body: Dear Clark Chen,

Thanks for looking into this. To provide more context, we typically transport around 100,000 tons per shipment. Could you advise whether using carrier-owned containers or shipper-owned containers would be more advantageous?

Please let me know if you need any clarification.

Thanks for your time!
Henry

<I’m looking for some help, and I was hoping you could point me in the right direction.
I work for a company that produces orthopedic shoes, and we’ve been getting a lot of complaints about our shoes falling apart.
It seems to happen whenever a patient uses our shoes to do a heavy activity, like basketball or soccer.
Our shoes are made with the same materials as the other brands that are out there, so I don’t understand why our shoes would be falling apart faster.
I’m wondering if there’s something wrong with our manufacturing process, or if there’s some other reason that our shoes would be breaking more easily.
Can you help me out?

Many thanks,
Jim>

<[email protected]>
<>

<[email protected]>
<>
output_text:
From: jim.peterson@orthocomfort.com
To: tech.support@shoeindustry.org
Subject: Technical Assistance Request - Shoe Durability Issues
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:23
Body: Dear Technical Support Team,

I'm looking for some help, and I was hoping you could point me in the right direction.

I work for OrthoComfort Manufacturing, and we've been getting a lot of complaints about our orthopedic shoes falling apart. It seems to happen whenever a patient uses our shoes to do a heavy activity, like basketball or soccer.

Our shoes are made with the same materials as the other brands that are out there, so I don't understand why our shoes would be falling apart faster. I'm wondering if there's something wrong with our manufacturing process, or if there's some other reason that our shoes would be breaking more easily.

Can you help me out?

Many thanks,
Jim Peterson
Quality Control Manager
OrthoComfort Manufacturing

output_text:

Dear M. Adam,                    We're looking for a drybulk vessel on the US Gulf to Marmara, and I was wondering if you could advise on your next open laycan?                    Best regards,                    Jhovany
Email 2:
Good afternoon Jonathan,          I would like to let you know that I have a general cargo vessel for sale.        The vessel is 2014 built, 8,639 DWT, 8,412 GT, 5,690 NT.        Built by United Engineering  Corp., Korea.        Her cargo gear is 2 x fixed 120T at 19m reach.        Her total cargo capacity is 12,750 m3.        For more details please find the ship's main particulars below:                ______________________________________________________                LOA: 138.00 m        MPP: 00:00:00        Date of Build: 05/2014        BW: 12,013 m3        Total Fittings: 12,750 m3        SWL of gear: 120 t, 20 m        LPP: 130.00 m
Email 3:
Dear Jonathan,         I am inquiring regarding my vessel's next laycan, that is what is her planned availability in August, in that sense if you can advise.                    Regards,
Email 4:
Great A.,        I have the vessel not available in August, it is my pleasure to inform that I have the vessel available from mid August onwards. Please let me know if you need more information.        Kind Regards,        JG

The course of the entire communication can be summarized as follows:
• After a first contact with Jonathan, M. Adam informed him about an open laycan for one of his vessels
• Jhovany said that he was looking for a vessel for USG to Marmara for August
• Adam did not have an availability for that period, but rather stated that his vessel would be open from mid-August onward
• This led Jhovany to ask whether Jonathan could inform him as to how he would rework his whole portfolio, but Jonathan did not answer this question

It is interesting to note that all throughout the exchange the intended relationship between
Email 5:
Dear Jhovany,        I have the vessel available from mid August onwards. Please let me know if you need more information.        Kind Regards,        JG

Email 2:
Hey Paul,                    got an offer from this guy who wants us to run a commission business between Pakistan and Jeddah. According to him this guy in Pakistan can get any commodities from Pakistan as they can buy them from factory (must be from buyer) and ship them to the middle east countries. My question is how safe is it for us to run a commission business as we don't know this person from Pakistan.                    You are more experienced than I am regarding that. I guess as long as we sign an agreement with the seller then we are covered.                    Can you advise me on that please?                    BTW, can you put me in touch with him as well so I can get to know him?                    He mentioned that they can ship fresh fruits, vegetables, meat and dairy products.                    Thank you,                    Fardos

<Email 3>
                            Hi Fardos
Email 3:
Hi Paul,

                            This person that is working with Mohammed is very professional, they can put you in touch with the person from Pakistan so you can come to terms with them and see if it is worth it or not.  Basically, they are looking to bring the fresh produce in from Pakistan to Jeddah and pay the charges to us.  They need it at a particular time of the year when Pakistan can supply the crops that are in season. The peak months would be April to September or so.  As you are in the meat business you may be able to get them deals and bring them in cheaply. The market is big there. I will contact you through Facebook as it will be better and you can find them in my friends list.

                            Do you have a suitable vessel for 5,000MT of DAP fertilizer from Karachi to Jeddah next week?

From: fardos.trading@gmail.com
To: paul.shipping@outlook.com
Subject: Re: Pakistan-Jeddah Trading Opportunity
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Hey Paul,

I got an offer from a contact regarding a commission business between Pakistan and Jeddah. They claim to have direct access to factory supplies for various commodities in Pakistan and can ship to Middle East countries.          _________________________

Email 3:
I would like to know that the distance between New York and London by water is around 4550 miles. From your blanks, you will need about 64 hours to reach London if the ship moves 100 miles per day. In this case, we can conclude that if the ship arrives in 65 hours, it will be one hour late.
Regards,
Mark

Best regards,
Shipping Line Cargo Desk

This was flagged by email as it was coming from an unknown sender. User profile was inspected and found to be empty. It was sent through Rapid Mailer (Mandrill)

However, it did contain a tracking number to an item that the sender said had been sent from the USA, which has led to this email. So this would likely come from some sort of automated mailer.

The files appear to be some sort of "GET mail spambot" or maybe a B2B mailer system. 
The zip contains a bunch of folders and files, and does not look executable. Likely some user data.

Please let us know the next steps. We should be able to collect it asap.


Sincerely,  
Joe Parr

Security scan completed for this email.

"sent a parcel from the USA that we delivered today"
"can you reply to this email with their next steps?"
"led to this email"

The sender in this email is outside of the comapny, and appears to be a client, so our client may have received the email, but it's probably not their problem.

The second

As requested, I am including a snapshot of our web portal as it appears today. It contains information about the markets in which Karen trades, and the freight rates for each trade. The portal also shows how certain factors, such as market volatility, can affect rates. Each sector displays a current snapshot of freight rates for each of the areas that Karen can trade, and a visual map indicating rate fluctuations. Also, freight rates appear in a moving graph which shows trends over the last 30 days. This is quite beneficial for traders who have to make decisions based on live market conditions. 

Another important function is the ship and route selector. When a ship trader selects a specific ship, the system shows in green or red the rates and savings for that specific ship on each route. This helps traders determine which ship and which route to select.

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Mr. García,                    Our customer is interested in chartering a medium-sized vessel to ship 6,000MT of rice from Manila to Lagos. Could you provide a sample contract with your typical terms and conditions?                    Thank you,                    Hector
Email 2:
Dear Sir,                    First of all, congratulations on your success and new position at Voyaca.com. I came across your profile on LinkedIn and found you very qualified to assist me in a very urgent matter.                    A few years ago, I employed a ship broker by the name of Brian Hopkin from Thomas Hopkin & Co to help charter a vessel to ship my company's produce from Panama to the West Coast of the USA.                    Unfortunately, a few days into the voyage, the vessel ran aground and was a total loss. Not only did Brian misrepresent his ship owner to be a reputable one, he went ahead and used me to sign up an insurance contract for his own personal benefit, under the influence of alcohol.                    He connived with the insurance company to release his profit after the ship sank but my company is still waiting for its share of the payout. Mr. Hopkin,
Email 3:
Dear Sir,                    At the time, I wasn't aware that he had so much experience in ship brokerage. I learned his dishonesty at the expense of my company. He had forged documents showing a photograph of the vessel to the owners before shipping and didn't tell me about his limited experience as an underwriter. Now I am having trouble recovering the costs of the cargo.                    Can you help me find a reliable ship broker to ship a product from Greece to Rotterdam? Can you advise on the best route, avoid legal and insurance mishaps, and ensure my company is protected against mishaps and liabilities?                    Thank you in advance for your assistance.
            Best regards,            Cieran
Response:
Hello Hector and Cieran,            Thank you for your enquiry.            Please find a draft of our Charter Party Terms & Conditions.            I would also like to suggest that Cieran contact a Ship Ins

To: garcia.j@pacificshipping.com
Subject: Urgent: Ship Broker Recommendation Needed
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 11:45
Body: Dear Mr. García,

I noticed your profile on LinkedIn and would appreciate your expertise on an urgent matter. I previously worked with a broker named Brian Hopkin from Thomas Hopkin & Co for a shipment from Panama to the US West Coast. Unfortunately, the vessel ran aground and became a total loss. Mr. Hopkin misrepresented the ship owner's credentials and manipulated the insurance arrangements for personal gain.

Given this experience, I'm seeking a reliable broker for a new shipment from Greece to Rotterdam. Could you advise on recommended routes and proper insurance coverage to protect our interests?

Best regards,
Cieran Sullivan

---

Best regards,
Javier García

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear <Receiver>,                    Could you please let me know if you have any space in July for 1,400MT of rice from Houston to New York? The actual ETA is open, so I can arrange it in July if there is a possibility.                    Kind regards,                    Sridhar
Email 2:
Dear Sridhar,                 Do you still have any cargo from Houston to New York for June? I know it has passed, but I need a schedule in case July space is not available.                 Kind regards,                 Martin 

The agents can respond to each other immediately as they have all the necessary details for the booking in their possession and do not need to go back to their customers.

Since the offers from buyers and sellers are decentralized, they will not be able to negotiate prices and they will have to agree to the market price and then move on to the next negotiation.

If both agents reply to the sender with the same message, there will be an error because a double response is not allowed in TPN. Thus, there is a restriction against these situations to facilitate the tracking of pending operations.

In the third case, it is possible to get a counter-offer or a quote by the other

output_text:
From: inquiries@shipping-co.com
To: operations@port-authority.ir
Subject: REQUEST FOR DEMURRAGE RATE
Timestamp: 2015-02-22 09:00
Body: Dear Sir/Madam,

I kindly request information regarding your demurrage rates for the period of 02/02/2015 to 08/02/2015 for the following vessel details:

Location: Suez Canal Area
Vessel Draft: 15.5m
Arrival Port: Bandar Mahshahr (400 KM from Tehran)
Estimated Arrival Time: Friday 06/02/2015

Please provide the applicable rates with navigation clearance requirements.

Best regards

---

From: operations@port-authority.ir
To: inquiries@shipping-co.com
Subject: RE: QUERY FOR DEMURRAGE DATE RATE
Timestamp: 2015-02-23 10:00
Body: Good morning,

Thank you for your inquiry. Please note that your request mentioned Bandar Abbas, while the vessel details indicate Bandar Mahshahr.

For reference, we have recorded the following details:

Date of Arrival: 8th February 2015
Position of Vessel: Offshore of Bandar Mahshahr, awaiting tug
Type of Vessel: 105,000 DWT Crude Oil Tanker
Draft of Vessel: 15.50 meters

Please note that no demurrage rates are applicable for vessels delayed while waiting for tug assistance.

Best regards

---

From: inquiries@shipping-co.com
To: operations@port-authority.ir
Subject: RE: QUERY FOR DEMURRAGE DATE RATE
Timestamp: 2015-02-23 14:00
Body: Dear Sir/Madam,

Regarding your response about demurrage rates at Bandar Mahshahr, Suez Canal area, we have been informed by the Iran Ministry of Maritime & Ports (Letter No. [redacted] dated 23/02/2015) that for vessels over 120,000 MT deadweight, when tugboat services fail to meet international standards, the local authority KOTTE is responsible for providing alternative services as per contract terms.

Best regards

input_text:
Email 1:
Hey Nick,                    We’re trying to move 8,000MT of EVA resin from India to Turkey. Would you have the space? What’s your freight rate?                    Best,                    Andreas
Email 2:
Email 1:
Nick,

In response to your email, 8,000MT of EVA resin from India to Turkey? No, no, no, we don't have the space, but we are talking about 15,000MT to Taiwan? Yes, yes, yes.

The freight rate? Maybe $10.5, definitely not$11.

<Email 3>:
Email 1:
Nick,

That's good news. 15,000MT of EVA resin from India to Taiwan. It sounds much better.

But we have a problem: I just learned that the customer in Turkey and the customer in Taiwan are the same. It's just a customer's secondary office. I don't think they will need that much EVA resin in both places at the same time. If it's like 15,000MT, I'm afraid they will cancel the order.
Email 3:
Email 1:
Nick,

That's good news. 15,000MT of EVA resin from India to Taiwan. It sounds much better.

But we have a problem: I just learned that the customer in Turkey and the customer in Taiwan are the same. It's just a customer's secondary office. I don't think they will need that much EVA resin in both places at the same time. If it's like 15,000MT, I'm afraid they will cancel the order.

<Email 3>:
 Email 1:
Nick,

I have talked to my customer and I was right: The secondary office is an independent operation. There is a limit of 10,000MT per office. We'll need to divide the shipment between the two offices. Can we split it? And can we lower the freight rate? This would help us get a better offer.

<Email 3>:
Email 1:
Nick,

Thank you for your response. I appreciate your ideas.

We're going to divide the shipment between the two offices. This means we'll need two ships and twice as many containers. I think it would be better to get a better freight rate. Is $10.5 per MT too much? <Email 3>:
Email 1: Nick,

That's a relief, the 10,000MT limit per office. I'm thinking 7,000MT to Taiwan
Email 4:
Email 1:
Hi Nick,

That sounds much better. We're going to change the quantity to 7,000MT. Let's see what your customer says. The last time, he wasn't convinced.

<Email 4>:
Email 1:
Nick,

Great! 7,000MT. But one more question. The buyer in Taiwan doesn't need to take the full 7,000MT. He has the room for just 6,000MT. Can we get a better rate with just 6,000MT?

<Email 4>:
 Email 1: Nick, Yes, let's talk about freight rate. We're on the same page. We're talking about 6,000MT of EVA resin from India to Taiwan. One more thing: Our shipper needs to know the port. <Email 4>:
Email 1:
output_text:
From: andreas@tradingco.com
To: nick@freightbroker.com
Subject: EVA Resin Shipment Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Hey Nick,

We're trying to move 8,000MT of EVA resin from India to Turkey. Would you have the space? What's your freight rate?

Best,
Andreas

---

From: nick@freightbroker.com
To: andreas@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: EVA Resin Shipment Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Hi Andreas,

8,000MT to Turkey isn't possible right now, but we do have space for 15,000MT to Taiwan. The freight rate would be around $10.50/MT, definitely not going above $11.

Regards,
Nick

---

From: andreas@tradingco.com
To: nick@freightbroker.com
Subject: Re: EVA Resin Shipment Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:20
Body: Nick,

I've discovered that the Turkey and Taiwan customers are actually the same company's offices. There's a 10,000MT limit per office. Could we split the shipment between the two locations? Also, is there any flexibility on the freight rate to help us make a better offer?

Best,
Andreas

---

From: andreas@tradingco.com
To: nick@freightbroker.com
Subject: Re: EVA Resin Shipment Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 16:45
Body: Nick,

Let's focus on Taiwan for now. The buyer there can actually only take 6,000MT. Would this smaller quantity help us get a better rate? Also, our shipper needs to know the specific port in Taiwan.

Best,
Andreas

Our payment will be by banker’s draft.                    Thanks in advance,                    Lorena
Email 2:
Write an email to your colleague. Explain that you would like the legal agreement to be added to the contract. Tell your colleague that you expect your cargo to be delivered to the same location on the specified date. Ask your colleague to provide the same level of service as previous shipments.

<Email 3>
Write an email to your colleague. Thank your colleague for her reply. Confirm that you have added the legal agreement to the contract. Tell your colleague that the shipment is to be delivered to Brisbane. Tell your colleague that the shipment is to be delivered on a specified date.

From: lorena.martinez@acmeshipping.com
To: suleman.khan@oceanfreight.com
Subject: Cargo Shipment Inquiry - Yokohama to Perth
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:15
Body: Dear Mr. Suleman,

Can you ship 2,800 metric tons of water from Yokohama to Perth? Our payment will be by banker's draft.

Thanks in advance,
Lorena

---

From: lorena.martinez@acmeshipping.com
To: suleman.khan@oceanfreight.com
Subject: Re: Cargo Shipment Inquiry - Legal Agreement Addition
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:30
Body: Dear Mr. Suleman,

I would like to request that the standard legal agreement be added to the contract for this shipment. Please ensure the cargo will be delivered as per our previous service standards.

Best regards,
Lorena

---

From: lorena.martinez@acmeshipping.com
To: suleman.khan@oceanfreight.com
Subject: Re: Change of Discharge Port to Brisbane
Timestamp: 2024-02-02 10:45
Body: Dear Mr. Suleman,

Thank you for your reply. I confirm that the legal agreement has been added to the contract. Please note that there has been a change in the discharge port - the shipment should now be delivered to Brisbane instead of Perth.

Best regards,
Lorena

Email 1:
Good morning Mr. Sardesai,                    We’re hoping to find a vessel to carry 2,000MT of ethylene dichloride from Karasburg to Salalah. Do you think that you can accommodate us on such a tight deadline, or should we look elsewhere?                    Yours truly,                    Karen
Email 2:
Good morning Ms. Klein,                    You made a valid point when you said that ships are very expensive to operate.  So, if we were to provide the food, would that drop the price?                    Your obedient servant,                    Karen
The letter writer is trying to establish the availability of a service from a potential supplier. To do so, she needs to ask questions.
If you choose the service, the supplier may not think that you are interested in the product.  That is why Ms. Klein tells you that ships are expensive to operate and, thus, puts you in a more interested position.  On the other hand, you may not think that the service is suitable for your product.  This is why Ms. Klein suggests that you could provide the food.  In this case, the product is the food.  The product is the basis for the discussion.
Either Ms. Klein
Email 3:
Dear Ms. Smith,
At the moment, our vessel is not ready for transport, and we’re afraid that it won’t be until the 10th of next month.  Of course, that will depend on how quickly repairs can be carried out.  Our most recent repairs were completed on the 1st of March.  Ms. Klein, my supervisor, says that we may be able to reschedule for the 12th of next month, but that you must let us know by the 7th of next month.
Yours truly, 
   Krishna
<Email 4>:
Dear Mr. Balasubramaniam,
Thank you for the speedy reply!  We’re hoping that repairs can be completed as soon as possible.  Unfortunately, we’re working with very tight deadlines and can’t afford to wait until March.
Please contact us when you have the next available

To: deepak.sardesai@oceanfreight.com
Subject: Ethylene Dichloride Shipment Inquiry - Karasburg to Salalah
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:15
Body: Good morning Mr. Sardesai,

We're hoping to find a vessel to carry 2,000MT of ethylene dichloride from Karasburg to Salalah. Our target loading date would be within the next two weeks. Could you please confirm if you have any suitable vessels available for this route?

Yours truly,
Karen Smith

---

From: linda.klein@oceanfreight.com
To: karen.smith@globalcargo.com
Subject: Re: Ethylene Dichloride Shipment Inquiry - Karasburg to Salalah
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 11:30
Body: Dear Ms. Smith,

Thank you for your inquiry. Given current vessel operating costs, we'd need to quote USD 85 per MT for this route. However, we might be able to adjust the rate if you can provide certain provisions for the crew.

Best regards,
Linda Klein
Operations Manager

---

From: krishna.balasubramaniam@oceanfreight.com
To: karen.smith@globalcargo.com
Subject: Re: Ethylene Dichloride Shipment Inquiry - Karasburg to Salalah
Timestamp: 2024-02-02 08:45
Body: Dear Ms. Smith,

I must inform you that our suitable vessel is currently undergoing repairs and won't be available until March 10th. Ms. Klein has authorized me to offer you a booking for March 12th, but we would need your confirmation by March 7th.

Yours truly,
Krishna Balasubramaniam

---

From: karen.smith@globalcargo.com
To: krishna.balasubramaniam@oceanfreight.com
Subject: Re: Ethylene Dichloride Shipment Inquiry - Karasburg to Salalah
Timestamp: 2024-02-02 09:30
Body: Dear Mr. Balasubramaniam,

Thank you for the prompt response. Unfortunately, we cannot accommodate such a late timeline as we need to complete this shipment before March. Please let us know if any earlier vessels become available.

Best regards,
Karen Smith

# @mentions
## Setup

We have the ability to mention people with @username. For example, mentioning @taylorotwell will notify Taylor Otwell that you mentioned them.

We use Laravel notifications internally, so if someone mentioned you and has their notification settings set up, they'll be notified of the mention.

To handle mentions in your own apps, simply listen for the Event:NotificationEvent which is sent when @mentions are posted.

See the Notifications documentation for more information.

# Text Formatting
#### Headers

##### Second Level Header
###### Third Level Header

###### Numbered List
```
This is my
Email 4:
Hi Fred, my name is Joe and I'm responsible for shipping for Rob's division. If you have a rate you'd be willing to send, I'd be happy to put the business your way.

  1. First item in the list
  2. Another item
```
```
1. First item in the list
2. Another item
```
##### Code

To format inline code, enclose it in backticks `like this`. To include a literal backtick, precede it with a backslash `like this`.

To format a block of code, indent it by four spaces (standard indentation in Markdown) or surround it with triple backticks ``` .

```javascript
var foo = 'bar';
```
                    ```ruby
class Foo
  def initialize(foo)
    @foo = foo
  end
end
```
# Syntax Highlighting
Email 5:
Hi Fred, here is a link to our Antwerp Sales Rep: http://bit.ly/Antwerp-Sales-Rep                    Feel free to contact him at 0031 (0)62776XXXX and he will help you with your rate.                    Thanks,                    Eric
```
@ 5: var foo = 'bar';
```
``` @ 5: var foo = 'bar';
```
```ruby @ 5: var foo = 'bar';
```
``` @ 5: var foo = 'bar';
```
@ 5: var foo = 'bar';

# Horizontal Rule
```
    ----
```
## Hard Break

Backslash escapes all HTML and Markdown formatting.

Text can be escaped by prefixing it with a backslash \ . It will not be converted.

# Images

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Alex,                    My buyer here in Oslo needs 600MT of MEG from Houston. Could you please give me a rate estimate for a spot voyage and advise on the signing of a charter party?                    Cheers,                    Kristina
Email 2:
Hi Kristina,                It's in the $90s/ton (FOB Nola) at the moment. Rates are firm at this level, since very few tonnage is being offered. Also, considering the port congestion in Houston, we would only sign a charter party once we have the deal in hand. Should the charter party contain a destination clause, then of course, it could be signed upon final confirmation.               Regards, Alex

Comment:
Notice the commercial terms are spoken in term of shipping industry currency: MT, t, per ton, etc.
Email 3:
Here in Norway, it's our currency, the Krone, that is used. So here goes our deal in the local currency:

3,300,000/MT (FOB Nola)

A charter party may be drawn up to cover our terms. But, if the MEG should arrive a bit early, we could store the cargo until we need it.

Best, Kris.

Comment:
Here we have the commercial terms expressed in terms of "3,300,000/MT" instead of "per ton". In our example, 3,300,000 is the same as $90. The reason for the discrepancy is that Kristina, the seller, is located in Oslo, Norway, and the selling price is denominated in Norwegian Krone (NOK). One NOK equals 0.16 USD.
Email 4:
Hello Mr. Harris,                    It's you again. I received a FOB quotation from a Singaporean trader today, but I am not sure how it compares to what you quoted.                12,000MT of MEG FOB Nola (delivery within 2 weeks).                3,300,000/MT                FOB                             USD 3,300,000                Estimated delivery cost: 20,000                Charter party fee: 200,000                Insurance: 350,000                Total: USD 3,890,000                The above price includes destination clause: "Bill of Lading to be issued 'Norwegian ports only'". So, how does your rate compare?                Best, Kristina                    Post Script: According to my friend who works in the shipping department at the big Norwegian oil company, the port congestion in Houston is due to Hurricane Gustav
output_text:
From: kristina.berg@nordictrading.no
To: alex.harris@shipbroker.com
Subject: MEG Shipment Inquiry - Houston to Oslo
Timestamp: 2008-09-10 09:15
Body: Hi Alex,

My buyer here in Oslo needs 600MT of MEG from Houston. Could you please give me a rate estimate for a spot voyage and advise on the signing of a charter party?

Cheers,
Kristina

---

From: alex.harris@shipbroker.com
To: kristina.berg@nordictrading.no
Subject: Re: MEG Shipment Inquiry - Houston to Oslo
Timestamp: 2008-09-10 14:30
Body: Hi Kristina,

It's in the $90s/ton (FOB NOLA) at the moment. Rates are firm at this level, since very few tonnage is being offered. Also, considering the port congestion in Houston, we would only sign a charter party once we have the deal in hand. Should the charter party contain a destination clause, then of course, it could be signed upon final confirmation.

Regards,
Alex

---

From: kristina.berg@nordictrading.no
To: alex.harris@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: MEG Shipment Inquiry - Houston to Oslo
Timestamp: 2008-09-11 08:45
Body: Hi Alex,

Here in Norway, it's our currency, the Krone, that is used. So here goes our deal in the local currency:

3,300,000 NOK/MT (FOB NOLA)

A charter party may be drawn up to cover our terms. But, if the MEG should arrive a bit early, we could store the cargo until we need it.

Best,
Kris

---

From: kristina.berg@nordictrading.no
To: alex.harris@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: MEG Shipment Inquiry - Houston to Oslo
Timestamp: 2008-09-11 15:20
Body: Hello Mr. Harris,

I received a FOB quotation from a Singaporean trader today, but I am not sure how it compares to what you quoted.

12,000MT of MEG FOB NOLA (delivery within 2 weeks)
3,300,000 NOK/MT
FOB                             USD 3,300,000
Estimated delivery cost: USD 20,000
Charter party fee: USD 200,000
Insurance: USD 350,000
Total: USD 3,890,000

The above price includes destination clause: "Bill of Lading to be issued 'Norwegian ports only'". So, how does your rate compare?

Best,
Kristina

P.S. According to my friend who works in the shipping department at the big Norwegian oil company, the port congestion in Houston is due to Hurricane Gustav

Hi Ms. Bridget,                    Could we use your bunker tankers for upcoming voyages of MSC Cristiana? We are looking for two times 5,000MT in August and September, but we are also open to 8,000MT voyages. Can you provide us with details on terms and conditions?                    Best regards,                    David
Email 2:
Hi Daniel,                    I'm the bunkering specialist at the shipping company Frachtintra GmbH. We currently have a tanker for sale in Weipa, Australia. The specifications of the tanker are:                    - 5,000 m3                    - LNG + LPG                    - Complies with IMO NOx Tier III/EU IV emissions standards                    - Can carry various liquid chemicals, such as crude oil, petrochemicals, chemicals for industrial uses and more                    The price is 15.5 million USD.                    Can you please let us know if you would be interested?                    Regards,

Hi Srdjan,

This week you and I spoke on the phone. You had asked about available destinations for bunkering services. Can you please confirm that you're interested in Bunker Fuel, Offshore, and Marine fuels? We also offer Low Sulphur Content fuels. What are your availability
Email 3:
Hey there!

We have two possible destinations for you to choose from. We can offer the following:

1.        5,000MT of High-Sulphur Fuel Oil (HSFO) at 3.5% - Can be available in 3-4 days in your destination.
2.        3,000MT of Marine Gas Oil (MGO) at 0.5% - Can be available in 4-5 days in your destination.

Could you please let us know your preference? We look forward to working with you!

Kind regards,
Bridget

Hi Ms. Li,                    We have a cargo of 6,000MT to be loaded in Malabo. It must be delivered in Cape Town by 11 May. Would your company be interested in tendering?                    Thanks,                    Kris
Email 2:
Subject: Re: (RE: TENDER FOR 6000MT MALABO TO CAPE TOWN)                    Thanks for your inquiry. Our rate for this shipment is USD1,500.                    Looking forward to your reply.

Answer 1:
Subject: RE: (RE: TENDER FOR 6000MT MALABO TO CAPE TOWN)                    The rate is okay with us, but there is a problem with the transit time. Could you check your ETA for my customer? We are willing to pay more, if it will arrive earlier. Thanks

Answer 2:
Dear Alice,                    Unfortunately, we are not sure if we can achieve the ETA. Our vessel has a good speed, but if it is ballast in Malabo, it will take at least 16 days. If the cargo is loaded in Malabo, it will have to wait for our ship

Mark

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Ms. Elsner,                    Could you provide a 1,500MT cargo of freight from Hamburg to Tehran before June 14th? Please share your typical demurrage and dispatch rates.                    Thanks,                    Serafina
Email 2:
Dear Serafina,                      We have available 1,500 MT freight capacity on the Hamburg to Tehran route. We have some cargo from Manila to Hamburg which is now arriving. We can ship to Istanbul with one stop on arrival and to go via Ahvaz to Tehran with one stop on arrival for Iran. It depends on which cargo we will have after landing on Istanbul on May 31st.          The rate is $750 per 20' container demurrage, $500 per 20' container dispatch. Please let me know if you can provide such cargo to us.  Thank you,                               Johann <Email 3>:
Dear Johann,                               Thank you for your offer, but this is not the route we are seeking. We'd like to ship from Hamburg to Tehran. Please let me know if you can do so. Thank you!                               Serafina
Email 3:
Dear Johann,                               Thank you for your offer, but this is not the route we are seeking. We'd like to ship from Hamburg to Tehran. Please let me know if you can do so. Thank you!                               Serafina

<Email 3>:
 Dear Serafina,                               We can take the cargo to Istanbul with one stop on arrival. We have space from Manila to Hamburg. We have one space from Hamburg to Istanbul on May 31st on our vessel ETERNAL DREAM. We can take your cargo from Istanbul to Ahvaz on our vessel METAPHYSICS and go via Ahvaz to Tehran with one stop on arrival.          Thank you,                               Johann

*Source: click here to view the original emails in the attachment
output_text:

To: j.elsner@shipping.com
Subject: Freight Inquiry: Hamburg to Tehran
Timestamp: 2024-05-25 09:30
Body: Hello Ms. Elsner,

Could you provide a 1,500MT cargo of freight from Hamburg to Tehran before June 14th? Please share your typical demurrage and dispatch rates.

Thanks,
Serafina

---

From: j.elsner@shipping.com
To: serafina.trade@company.com
Subject: Re: Freight Inquiry: Hamburg to Tehran
Timestamp: 2024-05-25 14:15
Body: Dear Serafina,

We have available 1,500 MT freight capacity on various routes. We can offer space on our vessel ETERNAL DREAM from Hamburg to Istanbul with one stop, and then transfer to our vessel METAPHYSICS for the journey from Istanbul via Ahvaz to Tehran.

The rate is $750 per 20' container demurrage, $500 per 20' container dispatch.

Please let me know if this arrangement works for you.

Thank you,
Johann

---

From: serafina.trade@company.com
To: j.elsner@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Freight Inquiry: Hamburg to Tehran
Timestamp: 2024-05-26 10:00
Body: Dear Johann,

Thank you for your offer, but this is not the route we are seeking. We'd like to ship directly from Hamburg to Tehran. Please let me know if you can accommodate this request.

Thank you!
Serafina

---

From: j.elsner@shipping.com
To: serafina.trade@company.com
Subject: Re: Freight Inquiry: Hamburg to Tehran
Timestamp: 2024-05-26 15:45
Body: Dear Serafina,

I must clarify that our current routing options are as previously stated. We can offer space on ETERNAL DREAM departing Hamburg for Istanbul on May 31st, followed by METAPHYSICS from Istanbul via Ahvaz to Tehran.

Thank you,
Johann

Nevens

Spectra is an Amman-based importer and distributor of mining chemicals. Some of the product names we supply are CŁpim™ 41 (75% Sodium Cyanide), Satyam M3, Kengal ® M, TMAA (Tris (Methylamine) Ammonium Amines), DCTA (Diethylene Triamine Pentaacetic Acid) and Hexamine.
Most of our products are imported from Europe and supplied in bulk drums ( 50kg or 125kg ) and in drums, jerry cans, and pouches, for various end-user industries.
We also supply chemicals in bulk or tanker loads to other businesses and institutions who require their own specialized packaging and blending.

Our warehouse and offices are situated in the Abdali area in Amman, within a 20 minutes drive of both Queen Alia International Airport and King Hussein

Zoe

Subject: Re: Freight Estimate Request - Ethanol Maceió/Houston

Thank you for all your help. You are a great addition to the company.

Best,
Aimee

Email 1:
Hello Mr. Zinder,                    We urgently need a supply of 5,000MT of biodiesel to get us through winter. Please could you confirm your availability, and if you can offer a derating?                    Best regards,                    William
Email 2:
Hello William,
We can supply the quantity of biodiesel as required. But unfortunately we do not have the facility to reduce the quantities you have specified.
                    Regards,
                    Maria
Email 3:
Dear Maria,                      Please could you try to supply half the quantities in your offer? We have yet to secure a contract for the balance and are very nervous about going into the winter with a stock of only half the quantity you can supply.                   I look forward to hearing from you.                   Best regards,                   William

<Email 4>:
Dear Mr Zinder,
We regret that due to constraints on our warehouse capacity, we are unable to supply only half the quantities of biodiesel you require.                   Yours sincerely,                   Maria


If there is a chance that William can secure a contract for the remaining biodiesel, what is the best thing for him to do?

Tez and Cengiz

---

From: justin.smith@email.com

Justin

---

From: tez.cengiz@university.edu
To: justin.smith@email.com
Subject: Re: Welcome back from London
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:30
Body: Dear Justin,

The University of Chicago does not currently admit graduate students for study abroad programs. However, I recommend first finding a good residential school and then inquiring about credit transfer options. I can send you links to some competitive residential programs that might suit your needs.

You can find a list of potential summer schools here: http://www.thegatewayus.com/Study/Subject/Summer-School.aspx

Regarding credit transfers, while it can be challenging, many universities offer flexible programs that allow summer course credits. The key is finding a suitable residential course first.

Best regards,
Cengiz

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Capt. Hu,                    We are organizing a 200,000mt cargo of MGO from Gijon, Spain, to Japan. As you know, it’s a big shipment. In your opinion, are all the suppliers out there able to supply such a big order?                    Also, how long will the loading time take?                    Many thanks,                    Timothy
Email 2:
Dear Tim,             I'm going to refer to my first email response and elaborate as requested.             We’ve never sold that quantity of MGO. Our company is a division of a larger company that has supplied 100,000mt+ to major trading companies in the last few years, so we can do this. The time frame can be negotiated between the supplier and buyer. We usually provide the shipping documents within 10-12 days of the shipment and request payment in cash 4 weeks later. The buyer needs to pay the bank documentary charges within 2 weeks of the shipment.             I think the real trick is to find a supplier who is able to supply this quantity. To find a supplier for 200,000mt who is able to deliver such a big order is quite challenging. The order should be split into two parts, each part being around 100,000mt.
Email 3:
I’ve just learned that the delivery vessel has a limit of 130,000mt and two big ships might be needed. So, 100,000mt of the order might be enough to fill one ship, and the other ship will have to be loaded with the other 100,000mt.             There are many shipping vessels available that can take this amount of cargo. The average delivery time for this kind of shipment is around 45 days, although it’s possible to shorten the delivery time. It depends on the cargo vessel’s available route.             The costs for this shipment can vary from USD 10 to USD 20 per mt, depending on the size of the cargo vessel, the route taken, and the distance the cargo will have to travel.             In conclusion, I think the best course of action is to ship the order in two parts, each part being around 100
