output_text:
From: timothy.wong@tradingco.com
To: captain.hu@maritime.com
Subject: MGO Cargo Shipment Query - Gijon to Japan
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:15
Body: Hello Capt. Hu,

We are organizing a 200,000mt cargo of MGO from Gijon, Spain, to Japan. As you know, it's a big shipment. In your opinion, are all the suppliers out there able to supply such a big order?

Also, how long will the loading time take?

Many thanks,
Timothy

---

From: captain.hu@maritime.com
To: timothy.wong@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: MGO Cargo Shipment Query - Gijon to Japan
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:30
Body: Dear Tim,

Regarding your query, we've never handled that quantity of MGO in a single shipment. However, our parent company has experience with 100,000mt+ shipments for major trading companies in recent years, so this is feasible.

The timeframe is typically negotiable between supplier and buyer. We normally provide shipping documents within 10-12 days of shipment, with payment terms of cash within 4 weeks. Bank documentary charges should be settled within 2 weeks of shipment.

However, finding a supplier capable of delivering 200,000mt at once would be challenging. I recommend splitting the order into two shipments of approximately 100,000mt each.

Best regards,
Capt. Hu

---

From: captain.hu@maritime.com
To: timothy.wong@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: MGO Cargo Shipment Query - Gijon to Japan
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 15:45
Body: Dear Tim,

I should add that vessel capacity is also a consideration. The maximum capacity for suitable vessels is around 130,000mt, so we would definitely need two ships for this order.

Typical delivery time is approximately 45 days, though this can be optimized depending on vessel availability and routing. Freight costs typically range from USD 10 to USD 20 per mt, varying with vessel size, route, and distance.

Best regards,
Capt. Hu

---

From: captain.hu@maritime.com
To: timothy.wong@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: MGO Cargo Shipment Query - Gijon to Japan
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 16:20
Body: Dear Tim,

To provide additional context, the Europe-Japan route is approximately 7,000 nautical miles, typically taking around 30 days depending on weather conditions and vessel speed.

For sourcing suppliers, I recommend reaching out to local trade associations or trade missions. They can connect you with suitable suppliers or refer you to relevant organizations in the destination country.

Various vessel types could handle this cargo, including bulk carriers and tankers, each with their specific advantages.

Best regards,
Capt. Hu

Dear Mr. Flores,                    According to your offer for naphtha, if you still have stock, we can negotiate based on your price.                    Susan

If the business person that you're trying to negotiate with sends an email that says, "Hello Susan," but it's really a spam bot that has auto-generated an email to look like it's from a human, the spam bot won't use your name in the reply.

According to your offer for naphtha

You can negotiate based on your price

We can begin negotiations based on your offer.

Therefore, if we see text in the email reply that doesn't match what we would expect a human to say in a negotiation reply, that's a good clue that it's a bot.

much more complex than most bots out there, which usually just randomly grab a word from your email and reply with it.
Email 4:
From: Dear Mr. Flores, According to your offer for naphtha, if you still have stock, we can negotiate based on your price. Susan

much more complex than most bots out there, which usually just randomly grab a word from your email and reply with it.

<Email 4>:
 From: Dear Mr. Flores, According to your offer for naphtha, if you still have stock, we can negotiate based on your price. Susan

This would be an easy detection system for anyone who was trying to determine if an email reply was generated by a human or by a bot. It's not perfect (or rather, it's not "perfectly perfect"), but it is a way to detect spam bots.

However, what we're looking for is not just whether an email reply is generated by a bot, but whether the person that sent the email actually wrote that reply. Or in other words: Is the email genuine? Does this person exist? Is it really my friend or colleague that's sending me these messages?

What you should do to test if the email is genuine

To test whether an email is genuine, you should check two things:

1. Does the email reply
Email 5:
From: Susan

According to your offer for naphtha, if you still have stock, we can negotiate based on your price. Susan

If you're sending emails back and forth with a bot, you're probably using some sort of reply template. A human would never send an email back and forth using exactly the same template.

2. Is there any other information in the email that could be used to validate that it's really the person sending it?

To start with, you should look for:

This is a topic that I cover in more detail in my article on spotting bots.

The key here is that you can't just rely on one factor to validate whether an email is genuine. You have to combine multiple factors together. You have to ask yourself: How strong is each of these factors? How confident am I that this email is genuine? Am I still worried that it might be a

The delivery address must be valid, and the documents must be sent to:                    Ms. Joan <email address hidden>                    I hope that is ok.                    Best regards,                    Patrick
Email 3:
Dear Patrick,             No problem, we will deliver it at the port.  It will be in the container.  It is 3 tonnes.             Please let us know when you expect the container to arrive.             Thanks             Stephen

In any dialogue it is important to state facts and not omit or conceal important information. This gives room for miscommunication as well as mistrust between the two sides. That’s why it is important to understand how to communicate professionally in business correspondence.

## What is Business Correspondence?

A message sent and received via a written form is known as a business correspondence. It is crucial as it provides information on the various activities of an organization. There are several forms of business correspondence. They include formal business letters, e-mails, and memos.

The letter types might be used to communicate with customers, clients, or employees. Some examples of business correspondence include application letters
Email 4:
Dear Mr. Kiriil,
We are very pleased to hear that you would like to become a regular customer of ours.  It is unfortunate that we have to turn down your offer due to the company policy.  We are not able to issue you with a regular customer card due to the fact that we do not use regular customer cards.  Our company has its own credit rating system which is used for the purpose of establishing customer loyalty.  In future, we would be able to offer you a credit line which we can tailor to your needs.  We would like to assure you of our continuing cooperation.
Yours sincerely,
Maria
</Email 4>
<Email 5>:
Dear Mr. Christopher,
We regret to inform you that we cannot continue to do business with your company.  We have been consistently dissatisfied with the quality of your products and the after-sales service provided

Email 1:
Hi,                    Do you have any spares of ... model batteries??? And, would you be willing to freight them from Hong Kong to Los Angeles???                    Let me know.                    Best,                    Amin                    A sample inquiry email may take several different forms depending upon the client???s objectives. Most inquiries to a shipping company are in respect of transporting goods. In most cases, this involves the movement of relatively high volumes of goods at low prices. Examples of products such as petrol and grains fit this description. For this type of inquiry, it is most likely that the client will have prepared an extensive set of formal requirements such as sailing schedule and conditions for carriage which will accompany the inquiry letter. In this case, the inquiry letter will be the equivalent of the written statement sent to the real client.                    Now, write an email to a potential client who is enquiring about your company???s
Email 2:
My reply.                    If a company were to open a trade account with us, then we could extend credit up to $500,000. However, if a company were to open a commercial account with us, we could offer them credit of$5 million. This account is for trading products between companies, not individuals.
                    We do provide this service from both Hong Kong and Los Angeles. Also, we have offices in Sydney and Auckland. Please see our websites for more details.
                    Please feel free to contact me if you have any further questions.
                    Regards,
Email 3:
Hi Rob,

                    Could you advise me of the approximate cost and timing of delivery. Could you also supply me with a copy of the relevant carriage conditions? Please also include a contact number, name and fax number.

                    The estimated cost for the shipment of 40,000 tons from Sydney to Seattle is as follows:

 Total: 60,000.00
                    This total is for the cost of the shipping as well as for the cost of insuring the goods.
                    For insurance purposes, we do need a complete list of the goods to be shipped, together with an approximate value of the goods and an approximate quantity. We can then insure these goods for a fixed price. To clarify, this does not include a freight charge; the freight charge is paid by you directly to the shipper.
                    The insurance company can then quote you for the insurance of the goods.

                    A Insurance

Mark Taylor

Hi Ms. Cheng,                    We have an urgent requirement for a tanker to carry 25,000MT of LNG from Lagos to Hong Kong. Would you be able to provide your best freight rate and do you allow re-instatement of laytime beyond 96 hours?                    Thank you,                    Damian
Email 2:
Hi Damian,                    The price is FOB USD540.00/MT, not including the lighering fee (max 5,000mt at $300/mt). Freight time of the vessel in and out of the ports is 4 days, transit time is 27 days.                    Reinstatement for both arrival and departure must be approved. After the vessel have left our port, it cannot get a reinstatement of 48hours, even after 96hours. Arrival time must be within 24 hours, if the vessel will not arrive on time, it can get reinstatement for up to 24 hours. If you want to sign the Charter Party with us, please send us the following documents as soon as possible:                    1. company profile, scope of operation, address, fax number, phone number.                    2. certification of insurance.                    3.
output_text:
From: damian.smith@tradingco.com
To: lisa.cheng@shipowners.com
Subject: LNG Cargo Inquiry - Lagos to Hong Kong
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 09:15
Body: Hi Ms. Cheng,

We have an urgent requirement for a tanker to carry 25,000MT of LNG from Lagos to Hong Kong. Would you be able to provide your best freight rate and do you allow re-instatement of laytime beyond 96 hours?

Thank you,
Damian

---

From: lisa.cheng@shipowners.com
To: damian.smith@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: LNG Cargo Inquiry - Lagos to Hong Kong
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 11:30
Body: Hi Damian,

The price is FOB USD540.00/MT, not including the lightering fee (max 5,000mt at $300/mt). Freight time of the vessel in and out of the ports is 4 days, transit time is 27 days.

Regarding reinstatement: For arrival, we can grant up to 24 hours if the vessel is delayed. For departure, no reinstatement is possible after the vessel has left port, even beyond 96 hours. 

If you wish to proceed with the Charter Party, please provide:
1. Company profile, scope of operation, address, fax number, phone number
2. Certificate of insurance

Best regards,
Lisa Cheng

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Mr. Jones,                    We are looking to ship 1,100MT of shoes from Rotterdam to Boston. Can you confirm your earliest available sail date, and can you let me know if you have a regular schedule?                    Kind regards,                    Anne
Email 2:
Anne,                    We would be happy to help with your shipment. Our regular weekly sailing is on the 23rd of the month. This shipment will sail on the 25th of March. Please confirm your delivery address and let me know if you have any further questions.                    Best regards,                    Don

Anne wrote back:
Hi Don,                    Yes, I think that works for us. The final destination for the goods will be Boston, MA. We will be clearing the goods through Port Newark, NJ.                    Thank you for your help!                    Anne

Later on, a similar conversation:
<Email 1>:
Hi Don,                    I’m following up about the shipping to Boston, MA. I spoke with our customs broker who said they will need to ship from NJ. Can you let me know if that will be a problem?                    Thanks,                    Anne

<Email 2
Email 3:
Hi Anne,                    NJ is not a problem. The vessel leaves from Rotterdam, then stops in Houston and NJ, before going to Boston. The final destination for the cargo is Boston, and you will clear the cargo in Boston, so that is fine.                    Please let me know if you have any further questions.                    Don

I personally hate being in this kind of situation.
- Does it matter if you clear your cargo in NJ or Boston?
- Is the stop in Houston worth including in the quote? If we talk about ports-of-call, does it mean we are talking about trans-shipments?
- What does it mean when Don said "final destination for cargo" was Boston?
In this kind of case, the shipper has spoken with their customs broker. They have consulted their maritime lawyer. They know the procedures to follow. That is why they ask you if you can handle the
Email 4:
Anne,                    The carrier for this shipment will be ZIM Lines. They will export from Rotterdam, and stop in Houston, before sailing to Boston. All shipments are delivered FCA (Free Carrier). This means the carrier will deliver the cargo at their warehouse in Rotterdam, from where you will be responsible for paying for the cargo and the customs duties. You will also be responsible for unloading the cargo, or arranging for that to be done.                    Please let me know if you have any further questions.                    Regards,                    Ed

<Email 5>
Anne,                    Can you please let me know if you have any questions about our quote? We’ve already run out of our weekly quota, so we will have to sell your cargo at market price.                    Regards,                    Don

Ethan

From: j.barlow@polishtrading.com
To: ethan.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Phosphate Cargo Inquiry - Casablanca to Lisbon
Timestamp: 2024-05-15 11:45
Body: Dear Ethan,

Thank you for your inquiry. For us to provide an accurate vessel quote, we need the following information:

1. Precise pickup and delivery locations
2. Container specifications
3. Stowed weight details
4. Nature of the cargo (hazard class if applicable)
5. Any special handling requirements

Once we receive these details, we can check availability with our fleet and affiliated vessels.

Best regards,
Julia Barlow
Administrative Director
Polish Trading LTD

---

- Cargo: 1,100 MT of Phosphates
- Loading Port: Casablanca
- Discharge Port: Lisbon
- Required laycan: June 15th
- Subsequent positioning: Vung Tau, Vietnam for July 1st

Ethan

input_text:
Email 1:
Good day Mr. Xing,                    I have a cargo of 4,000MT of methanol from Corpus Christi to Durban. Can you send a charter cost, and how much for commission?                    Many thanks,                    Fabio
Email 2:
Good day,                        I would like to know if your company has anything going to Asia to book a chartered vessel. I have 2500mt of steel.                    I am looking forward to hearing from you as soon as possible.                    Kind regards,                    Hennie
Email 3:
Dear Sirs,                         I am a buyer with a cargo of 12,500 MT of steel products from Vietnam. I would like to check your company’s capability in providing Vessel Charter.                    Best regards,                    Cindy

They show up in email. When you google “ur5 quickbooks” and “quickbooks error 176109”, you’ll find this email. They are low cost replicas of your computer’s typical shipping and air delivery errors. One reason why they’re so effective is because they’re 100% human-friendly, like “Q: When will the goods arrive? A: Today.”

When you send them back, they’ll respond. These two replies will let you know that someone from them (and not a computer, and certainly not an imposter) is in your inbox.

If you’re not going to send them a reply, or if you’re going to turn
Email 4:
Dear Sirs,                     I am a buyer with a cargo of 12,500 MT of steel products from Vietnam. I would like to check your company’s capability in providing Vessel Charter.                    Best regards,                    Cindy

Sarah:                    Hi, Ishaan.                    When will this cargo be arriving? 
                    Ishaan:                    The cargo should be arriving on October 6.                    Are you ready for it?

Sarah:                    Okay, we're all set!                    I'll be expecting the cargo on the 6th of October.                    Ishaan:                    Great! I'll let the ship know.                    Talk to you soon!

Answer: To confirm the cargo's arrival date and arrange for the cargo's reception.

6. What does "all set" mean in this context?
Answer

Email 1:
Hi Phil,                    Can you suggest any cargo in NY or NJ that we can ship to our Antwerp port this weekend? It’s for a client who is in a hurry.                    Regards,                    Sam
The way you are supposed to write a business email is completely different from the way a formal letter is written.
Business Emailing Etiquette:
Write business emails in a direct, concise and informal style
Maintain a formal, respectful tone
Address the recipient by name, never by using “Dear Mr.” or “Dear Ms.” or any such title
Always include a complimentary closing at the end of the email
Check spelling, grammar, punctuation and any errors in the content
Use appropriate salutations for various situations
Choose an appropriate email subject
Use an appropriate email signature
After writing the email, add a sender’s signature, which includes your name and contact details
Avoid

Sam

John’s first email to Sam:1. The 1st time, when there is no previous correspondence, you should always start with the sender’s name, followed by a comma and your own name and address. The whole point of the sender’s name is to emphasize the directness and friendliness of the e-mail.
2. Avoid first names in your introduction until you get to know the other party. In your subsequent emails, a simple “Hi Sam” will do.

YM - Yantian Wednesday (port stay two days)
YB - Yantian Thursday (port stay two days)
YS - Yantian Saturday (port stay two days)

YB - dep Yantian Thu 25/5 ETA Busan 01/6 ETA Vladivostok 05/06

Best regards

Email 2:
Dear Sir,                    We would like to advise that at this time, there is no space available on our tanker in Suez for transshipment into Vung Tau.  We will advise if this changes.
  
Bintang Sejahtera
Email 3:
Dear Shipping Executive,                    
    Please do you have space for 27,000MT of crude oil from Ashgabat to HCM for loading on Friday.

output_text:
From: saleem.trader@petrotrading.com
To: operations@bintangsejahtera.com
Subject: Cargo Space Inquiry - 27KMT Crude Oil Ashgabat/HCM
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Dear Shipping Executive,

Please advise if you have space available for 27,000MT of crude oil from Ashgabat to Ho Chi Minh City for loading this Friday.

Kindest Regards,
Saleem

---

From: operations@bintangsejahtera.com
To: saleem.trader@petrotrading.com
Subject: Re: Cargo Space Inquiry - 27KMT Crude Oil Ashgabat/HCM
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Dear Sir,

We regret to advise that at this time, there is no space available on our tanker in Suez for transshipment into Vung Tau. We will notify you if the situation changes.

Best regards,
Bintang Sejahtera Operations

---

From: saleem.trader@petrotrading.com
To: operations@bintangsejahtera.com
Subject: Re: Cargo Space Inquiry - 27KMT Crude Oil Ashgabat/HCM
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 13:20
Body: Dear Shipping Executive,

Thank you for your response. Please keep us informed if any space becomes available for our 27,000MT crude oil cargo from Ashgabat to HCM for loading this Friday.

Kind Regards,
Saleem

To: shipping.operations@vesselco.com
Subject: Cargo Capacity Inquiry
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Hello,

I would like to inquire about the cargo capacity of your vessel. What is the maximum tonnage that can be loaded?

Regards,
Yaqoub

---

From: shipping.operations@vesselco.com
To: yaqoub.shipping@example.com
Subject: Re: Cargo Capacity Inquiry

Body: Hello Mr. Yaqoub,

The vessel can accommodate up to 500 tons of cargo with a maximum height of 15 meters above sea level.

Best regards,
Operations Team

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Max,                    We’re looking to ship 700MT of pharmaceuticals from Riga to Dubai. How much time do you need to find a suitable vessel?                    Regards,                    Grace
Email 2:
Hello Grace,             I can give you an idea.  My colleague has shared you the shipping route from Riga to Dubai. But before I start my search, I would like to hear more about the shipment.                    - How will the goods be loaded? (lcl or fcl)                    - What is the nature of the cargo?                    - What will be the mode of shipment?                    - When do you expect to move the cargo?                    - Is it an urgent shipment? (please provide the documents)                    Regards,                    Max

<Email 3>:
Dear Max,                We want to ship it by sea with fcl and lcl. Please give me a quote.                  Regards,                  Grace

<Email 4>:
Hi Grace,              Thanks for the response. The goods will be packed as fcl or lcl at the destination warehouse in Riga.
output_text:
From: grace.smith@pharmalogistics.com
To: max.weber@shipbroker.com
Subject: Pharmaceutical Shipment Riga to Dubai
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:15
Body: Dear Max,

We're looking to ship 700MT of pharmaceuticals from Riga to Dubai. How much time do you need to find a suitable vessel?

Regards,
Grace

---

From: max.weber@shipbroker.com
To: grace.smith@pharmalogistics.com
Subject: Re: Pharmaceutical Shipment Riga to Dubai
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 10:30
Body: Hello Grace,

I can help you with this inquiry. My colleague has shared the shipping route from Riga to Dubai with you. However, before I start my search, I need some additional information:

- How will the goods be loaded? (LCL or FCL)
- What is the nature of the cargo?
- What will be the mode of shipment?
- When do you expect to move the cargo?
- Is it an urgent shipment? (please provide the documents)

Regards,
Max

---

From: grace.smith@pharmalogistics.com
To: max.weber@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: Pharmaceutical Shipment Riga to Dubai
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 11:45
Body: Dear Max,

We want to ship it by sea with both FCL and LCL options. Please give me a quote for both.

Regards,
Grace

---

From: max.weber@shipbroker.com
To: grace.smith@pharmalogistics.com
Subject: Re: Pharmaceutical Shipment Riga to Dubai
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 13:20
Body: Hi Grace,

Thank you for the response. I understand the goods will be packed as FCL or LCL at the destination warehouse in Riga. I'll work on getting you quotes for both options.

Regards,
Max

input_text:
Email 1:
Afternoon Ms. Olsen,                    Could you fix 2,600MT of adhesives from Antwerp to Liverpool for mid-month? Also, could you provide your typical demurrage and dispatch rates?                    Yours,                    Patrick
Email 2:
Subject: Re: adhesives out of Antwerp
Hi Patrick,

Yes, we can do the adhesives. It would be for your information, not committed yet.

The material will be in Antwerp at 2.400 MTC. From: It would be Antwerp 8th or 9th July to Liverpool 19th or 20th July.

- 10 days e.t.d. including bunkers
- Detention : 0,47 €/day

Please send your interests and provide me with destination and container. Make sure to indicate number of drums.

Kind regards,

Gilles
<Email 3>:
Subject: RE: adhesives out of Antwerp
Great.                   The cargo will be in 20’GP, no special equipment is required. A firm offer would be highly appreciated.                    Please provide a proforma invoice.
output_text:

To: gilles.olsen@shipping.com
Subject: Adhesives shipment - Antwerp to Liverpool
Timestamp: 2023-07-03 14:30
Body: Afternoon Ms. Olsen,

Could you fix 2,600MT of adhesives from Antwerp to Liverpool for mid-month? Also, could you provide your typical demurrage and dispatch rates?

Yours,
Patrick

---

From: gilles.olsen@shipping.com
To: patrick.smith@company.com
Subject: Re: Adhesives shipment - Antwerp to Liverpool
Timestamp: 2023-07-03 15:45
Body: Hi Patrick,

Yes, we can do the adhesives. This would be for your information, not committed yet.

The material will be 2,400 MTC in Antwerp. Schedule would be:
Antwerp: 8th or 9th July
Liverpool: 19th or 20th July

- 10 days estimated transit time including bunkers
- Detention rate: 0.47 €/day

Please confirm your interest and provide destination details and container specifications. Please also indicate the number of drums.

Kind regards,
Gilles

---

To: gilles.olsen@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Adhesives shipment - Antwerp to Liverpool

The cargo will be in 20'GP containers, no special equipment is required. A firm offer would be highly appreciated.

Please provide a proforma invoice.

Regards,
Patrick

 price list.                     RGO         425.00 USD/MT             DMA        440.00 USD/MT             HSFO        230.00 USD/MT             FOB        360.00 USD/MT             MGO       520.00 USD/MT             MGO FOB    530.00 USD/MT             (May 4, 2023, so if the buyers want to buy on LBS for 05-06 May, the prices will be updated. )                     With regards,                   Clara Liu

RGO         425.00 USD/MT             DMA        440.00 USD/MT             HSFO        230.00 USD/MT             FOB        360.00 USD/MT             MGO       520.00 USD/MT             MGO FOB    530.00 USD/MT             The purchase was made on an LBS and we want to receive the goods 05-06 May. input_text:
Email 1: What's the current status of the vessel? Any news you can share? Best, Nada Email 2: Welcome to Sada, Here are the latest developments on Almarakib.

Outward bound.

Two reasons. 1. Almarakib's Pakistani captain is low on funds and is able to transport items from our port to Pakistan and earn some quick cash. He's a freelancer by nature, and is more than happy to take on whatever job comes his way as long as he gets his money upfront.

2. He is asking for $30,000 upfront. We will take out a loan for the money. We cannot afford the loan. I must sell off my share of the ship to pay it back.

I am writing this email on my phone from the bank.

I have agreed to let the bank have your share of the ship and pay off the loan.
output_text:
From: nada.shipping@email.com
To: sada.maritime@email.com
Subject: Vessel Almarakib Status Update Request
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: What's the current status of the vessel? Any news you can share?

Best,
Nada

---

From: sada.maritime@email.com
To: nada.shipping@email.com
Subject: Re: Vessel Almarakib Status Update Request
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Dear Nada,

Here are the latest developments regarding the Almarakib:

The vessel is currently outward bound. There are two important updates:

1. The vessel's Pakistani captain is low on funds and has accepted a cargo transport job from our port to Pakistan to generate immediate income. As a freelancer, he's willing to take on this job with advance payment.

2. The captain is requesting $30,000 upfront for this voyage. We need to take out a bank loan for this amount. Unfortunately, due to our financial situation, I must sell my share of the ship to cover the loan. I'm currently at the bank finalizing arrangements where they will take your share of the vessel as collateral against the loan.

Regards,
Sada

Bryan

Kind regards,
Marvin

output_text:
From: olivia.chen@tradelink.com
To: anderson.j@pacificship.com
Subject: Quote Request - Wheat Shipment Dalian to Durban
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Mr. Anderson,

Would you please provide a quote for our shipment of 10,000MT of M.G. wheat from Dalian to Durban. Can you include any extra charges for overweight or additional services?

Thank you,
Olivia

---

From: olivia.chen@tradelink.com
To: martin.r@oceanfreight.com
Subject: Re: Wheat Shipment Quote
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 14:15
Body: Mr. Martin,

Thank you for your quote. Your quote of $7,350 is a great value for a premium wheat like our MG and we were hoping you would have enough of the stock to allow us to charter your vessel to Dalian to load. When is your next voyage to Dalian?

If we could charter your vessel directly from your current port, perhaps London, then that would greatly reduce our shipping costs and we would definitely prefer to charter with you. We will arrange for our vessel to load with your wheat and deliver it to Dalian where we will book a voyage to Durban.

We look forward to hearing from you,
Olivia

---

From: olivia.chen@tradelink.com
To: martin.r@oceanfreight.com
Subject: Re: Vessel Availability
Timestamp: 2024-01-17 10:45
Body: Mr. Martin,

Thank you for your reply. Although we understand that your vessel is heading to Australia, we would like to discuss alternative arrangements for the shipment.

Regards,
Olivia

---

From: james.wong@tradelink.com
To: anderson.j@pacificship.com
Subject: Re: Quote Acceptance
Timestamp: 2024-01-18 11:30
Body: Mr. Anderson,

We believe your quote for $6,500 is very attractive. We are holding the quote open until the end of the week to allow time for our enquiry to be approved.

Thank you,
James

---

From: olivia.chen@tradelink.com
To: martin.r@oceanfreight.com
Subject: Re: Revised Quote
Timestamp: 2024-01-19 09:00
Body: Mr. Martin,

Thank you for your reply. We look forward to hearing back from you by Thursday when we will be able to consider your revised quote.

Regards,
Olivia

---

From: olivia.chen@tradelink.com
To: martin.r@oceanfreight.com
Subject: Re: Quote Comparison
Timestamp: 2024-01-20 15:30
Body: Mr. Martin,

We note your revised quote is less competitive than your original quote of $7,350. As we stated in our first enquiry we are trying to obtain the best value for our shipment of wheat and it would be unwise to have a new agent. We still hold your initial quote of $7,350 open for the time being.

Regards,
Olivia

---

From: daniel.lee@tradelink.com
To: anderson.j@pacificship.com
Subject: Vessel Confirmation Request
Timestamp: 2024-01-21 13:45
Body: Mr. Anderson,

Please confirm the availability of a suitable vessel to load at Dalian to deliver to Durban. Can you provide us with your General Conditions of Charter and Charter Party for our approval?

Thank you,
Daniel

#Create a Chat Bot

A bot is an automated process that performs an action for you. You can send it a message and it will respond to your message and take action on your behalf. A Chat Bot is an example of a bot.

To create a chat bot we will be making a Github Repository, to use NodeJS, this is because:

• NodeJS is one of the most popular languages used in web development today.
• NodeJS allows you to run your code server-side, which means it can process data and respond to user interactions in real time.
• NodeJS also supports JavaScript, which is a great way to get started with programming. It's an easy language to learn, and many developers already know it.

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Sirs,                    I have the following samples ready for dispatch from Rotterdam. Could you please give me your earliest availability for transport to Karachi?                    Regards,                    Sandra
Email 2:
Dear Sirs,                    This is with reference to my email of 15 March 2010. Please note that we will be sending out the parcel on 23 March 2010. Can you please inform me the most convenient date for delivery in Karachi?                    Best regards,                    Tom 

Subject line: dOCUMENTA(13)

I think this type of conversation is a sign of a completely new kind of content. When many people read an email, they don't think too much about it. They just get the information they need to keep doing their jobs.

However, if you put the same information into a 'smartcard', suddenly it becomes very interesting. A Smartcard can contain information, documents, images, videos and even music. It can also include online links and information that can be downloaded from the Internet, as well as many other things. Smartcards can be sent as gifts

Email 1:
Good Morning Sir,                    I am just checking if your port is open. Are there any terminals or any ship agent out there to help?                    Could you please tell me more about the tanker port and the transportation there?                    Thank you for your reply,                    Andrew
Email 2:
Hi Andrew,I am able to send message with my full name, but not the account name.My port is open for business, but I do not have any ship agent, since I am building up the port, and I am still using foreign one since the harbour is not opened. But I think it will be done this year.                    Hope to get in touch with you.                    Ron Liang
output_text:
From: andrew.broker@shipmail.com
To: ron.liang@portops.com
Subject: Port Operation Inquiry
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 09:30
Body: Good Morning Mr. Liang,

I am writing to inquire about your port's operational status. Could you please confirm if your port is currently accepting vessels? I would also appreciate information about any available terminal facilities and if you have local shipping agents we could work with.

Additionally, could you provide details about tanker berthing capabilities and local transportation infrastructure?

Thank you for your time,
Andrew

---

From: ron.liang@portops.com
To: andrew.broker@shipmail.com
Subject: Re: Port Operation Inquiry
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 11:45
Body: Dear Andrew,

Thank you for your inquiry. While our port is technically open for business, we are still in the development phase. Currently, we are utilizing foreign shipping agents as our harbor infrastructure is not fully operational. We expect to complete the development and have our own local shipping operations established by the end of this year.

I would be happy to keep you updated on our progress.

Best regards,
Ron Liang

Email 1:
Hey Mom,                    It’s been 6 years since we saw each other. Are you still in Hong Kong? I am now a captain in the army. I can’t believe how fast the time has gone by.
Email 2:
Dear Captain Yang,
I was glad to get your email. Yes, I am still in Hong Kong, but I will be moving to Beijing soon. Please don’t worry. I am very well, and I hope you are as well. Now you can tell me about your life. Where are you stationed? And where are your wife and children? How old are they?

<Email 3>:
Hi, Mom,
I am glad that you are still doing well. My family is fine. My children are getting bigger. My oldest is almost 6 years old, and my youngest is 4. I will have to wait a little longer until I can send you pictures of them. I am stationed near Guangzhou. My wife and I don’t see each other very often, so I guess you could say that we are basically divorced.

<Email 4>:
Hi, Captain Yang

Look forward to hearing from you soon,

Tom

Waiting for your reply,

Eddie

Tom

<Email 4>:
 Please sign the document attached and email it to me as soon as possible so that I can proceed to make arrangements to send the cargo to Kingston Wharves. Regards, Charles Denton

Cannon

I concur with Mr. Detrick's decision to uphold the bankruptcy court's ruling with regards to the findings and sanctions, with an addition of noting the lack of cooperation with the trustee. I do not think it is appropriate that there was no interview done to this company and I have the utmost concern of how can one do a complete review on a company without speaking to that company. For that reason, I will advise to bring this matter up during the oral argument of Mr. Detrick. Since he is hearing the matter, I think it would be proper to ask if a quick interview with the representatives of Hartley Crane Company, Inc. will be a consideration for the trustee.

Email 1:
Dear Mr. Maier,                    Hope you’re well. Could you please tell me what the freight idea is for a cargo of palm oil from Calabar to Santa Marta, with a mid-June laycan?                    Thanks,                    Gary
Email 2:
Mr. Maier,                    Thanks for that. You should read the other section of the email.                    Gary
Email 3:
Mr. Maier,                    Thanks for the help, but that is incorrect. We are buying palm oil from Calabar not Brazil. Please read the email again.
Once again, my valued guest and the popular ‘humourous’ founder of the humour site Fuleminess  has raised a very important issue. With the growing influence of multinational business and the Internet, there is a danger of being misunderstood. Particularly when it comes to asking someone a question. With the ever growing number of emails and phonecalls being made globally every second of the day, it is important to ensure your request is heard. 

When sending an email with a question, it is also very important to include a sign off such as “Best Regards” or “Kind Regards” this is because at times a person can read the email very fast and can be assumed that the person sending the email is actually sending them
Email 4:

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Betsy,                    We’re expecting 6,600MT of household chemicals to leave Antwerp on Friday. If you could advise your final freight rate, we can accept it.                    Thank you,                    David
Email 2:
Hi David,                    I can confirm that the rate I quoted you earlier still stands: US$2.00 per ton FOB Antwerp, plus US$10 per package in case the packages are of different dimensions.                    Should you require additional details please let me know.                    Best wishes,                    Betsy

<Betsy to her husband, Dave>:
Here we go again! This is the third request for a quote in one day, and David seems to have given a full quote in his original email. Why do I have to explain this to him every time?
What are some reasons for replying to an email twice?
Paragraph 2 (this one) gives specific reasons in the writer’s first email. Her husband’s email serves to remind her that David is not as familiar with the company’s rates as she is.

Explain how this form of explanation might serve to establish greater rapport
Email 3:
Hi Dave,                    Why don’t you just offer the rate per ton and let David accept it or suggest alternatives?                    Do you remember in our training course, we learnt that the purpose of most email communications is not just to reply with ‘yes’ or ‘no’, but to help others make a decision?                    David’s just a little reluctant, but he will accept it and agree to it if you can help him to make a decision by making your rate specific enough.                    Best wishes,                    Betsy
<Betsy to her husband, Dave>:
Dave, I wrote you an email in the last section. Please tell me how you replied.

Timestamp: 2024-02-01 10:30
Body: Hi David,

I can confirm that the rate I quoted you earlier still stands: US$2.00 per ton FOB Antwerp, plus US$10 per package in case the packages are of different dimensions.

Should you require additional details please let me know.

Best wishes,
Betsy

---

From: betsy.wilson@freight.com
To: dave.wilson@freight.com
Subject: Re: Quote Response Strategy
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 10:45
Body: Hi Dave,

Why don't you just offer the rate per ton and let David accept it or suggest alternatives?

Do you remember in our training course, we learnt that the purpose of most email communications is not just to reply with 'yes' or 'no', but to help others make a decision?

David's just a little reluctant, but he will accept it and agree to it if you can help him to make a decision by making your rate specific enough.

Best wishes,
Betsy

From: kelly.martinez@trader.com
To: alasdair.bayuk@shipping.com
Subject: Sugar Vessel Inquiry - Nouakchott to Kotka
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 09:30
Body: Dear Mr. Bayuk,

I'm seeking a vessel for 9,600MT of sugar from Nouakchott to Kotka. Could you advise me if your vessel is available at the end of September, and if so, what your laytime terms would be?

Thank you,
Kelly

---

From: alasdair.bayuk@shipping.com
To: kelly.martinez@trader.com
Subject: Re: Sugar Vessel Inquiry - Nouakchott to Kotka
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 11:45
Body: Hi Kelly,

Regarding your Kotka sugar inquiry, I must inform you that we cannot accommodate a late September loading. The vessel must be in Nouakchott no later than August 25th due to port scheduling constraints.

Kind regards,
Alasdair

---

From: kelly.martinez@trader.com
To: alasdair.bayuk@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Sugar Vessel Inquiry - Nouakchott to Kotka
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 14:20
Body: Dear Alasdair,

1. Could you please confirm your current vessel position?
2. If loading can commence before August 25th, please indicate, as we are still arranging vessel options.
3. What is your estimated loading duration?

Best regards,
Kelly

---

From: alasdair.bayuk@shipping.com
To: kelly.martinez@trader.com
Subject: Re: Sugar Vessel Inquiry - Nouakchott to Kotka
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 16:05
Body: Dear Kelly,

1. To be clear, we cannot commence any sugar movements after August 25th. Your vessel must arrive before this date.
2. Please confirm your vessel nomination before August 25th, or you will need to arrange an alternative loading port.

Best regards,
Alasdair

From: mendoza.p@shipping.es
To: anne.marie@chartering.com
Subject: Re: Cargo Inquiry Barcelona-Puerto Madryn
Timestamp: 2024-03-10 14:30
Body: Hi Anne Marie,

The cargo you have quoted will fit comfortably on MV ACATENANGO.

This ship will load in Aviles, Spain on the 13th March and sail the following day to Madryn, Argentina.

On arrival in Madryn, the cargo will discharge in two weeks time, approximately on the 26th March. This will give you approximately two weeks transit time from Spain to Madryn.

- Laycan: 13th March
- Prelim D/D
- Report of Findings: 12th March
- First Week: 15th-22nd March
- Second Week: 22nd-29th March
- D/D (SPB form)
- Expected discharge: 26th March
- Invoice: 19th March

Please confirm the delivery to Madryn, Argentina.

Best regards

---

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear all,                    I’d like to charter a multipurpose vessel from Fujairah to Dar es Salaam, around 2,000MT. Can you advise availability and rates?                    Regards,                    Yanyan
Email 2:
Globmarine Chartering.
Dear Sirs,       We hereby wish to kindly remind you that after the info shared with you in your first inquiry, We informed you about the available vessel and some alternative vessels as well, after having the availability of both, we can’t get your approval for the vessel S & P. The reason is that the owner does not provide the Vessel’s P&I and therefore you will need to cover the cost. We can find an alternative vessel for you however, therefore please contact us for further details and your approval. We apologize for the inconvenience. Please note, the charterer may choose between TCE only or TCE+P&I that can also be offered to them. Thank you for your cooperation.      With Best Regards,      Amr El-Garhy      Sales Department      Company Information  Globmarine Chartering Limited is a Dubai based
output_text:
From: yanyan.liu@tradeco.com
To: chartering@globmarine.com
Subject: Vessel Inquiry: Fujairah to Dar es Salaam
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:15
Body: Dear all,

I'd like to charter a multipurpose vessel from Fujairah to Dar es Salaam for approximately 2,000MT of cargo. Could you please advise on vessel availability and rates?

Best regards,
Yanyan

---

From: amr.elgarhy@globmarine.com
To: yanyan.liu@tradeco.com
Subject: Re: Vessel Inquiry: Fujairah to Dar es Salaam
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:30
Body: Dear Yanyan,

Thank you for your inquiry. Following our previous communications regarding the vessel S & P, we regret to inform you that there is an issue with the vessel's P&I coverage. The owner does not provide the Vessel's P&I insurance, which would need to be covered by the charterer.

We can offer you two options:
1. TCE only
2. TCE + P&I coverage

Alternatively, we can source another suitable vessel for your requirements. Please let us know your preference so we can proceed accordingly.

We apologize for any inconvenience caused.

Best regards,
Amr El-Garhy
Sales Department
Globmarine Chartering Limited
Dubai, UAE

GEP Operations Team

Regards,
Team GEP

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Mr. Ferris,                    My name is Samuel. I’m currently the vessel broker of a Chinese bulk carrier currently in Chittagong, Bangladesh.                    We have 3,800MT of heavy plates to load. Destination is Port Louis, Mauritius. We have been given the following port dues and fees to be deducted from the cargo:                    * General Cargo Port Dues: USD 3,256.00                    * Coast Guard Charges: USD 164.00                    * MFAF (Mauritius Free Airport Fee): USD 112.80                    * Port Corporation: USD 159.84                    * Generator Rental: USD 0.16/ Hour * 12 Hours = USD 1.92                    * Empty Tank Cleaning: USD 10.00 * 2 Tanks = USD 20.00                    Could you kindly take this into account when submitting
Email 2:
Dear Samuel,
Thank you for your email. Unfortunately it is not appropriate for you to pass charges like this on to the cargo owners without their consent. If you are able to provide evidence that this is the owners’ responsibility (e.g. a bill of lading with a clause allowing the carrier to deduct port dues from the cargo), we might be able to discuss a rate increase to cover these expenses, but if you are just making up charges to pay your agency then it is unethical and we will not pay you.
Thank you,
Alain Ferris
PS: We also need a few more details on the cargo (origin, grade, product code), which will enable us to get a more accurate quote for the freight.
PPS: The more information you are able to provide in your emails, the faster we can give you an answer, and the less likely it is that you will have
output_text:
From: samuel.chen@vesselbroker.com
To: alain.ferris@maritime-trade.com
Subject: Port Charges Query - Heavy Plates Shipment to Port Louis
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 09:30
Body: Dear Mr. Ferris,

My name is Samuel. I'm currently the vessel broker of a Chinese bulk carrier currently in Chittagong, Bangladesh.

We have 3,800MT of heavy plates to load. Destination is Port Louis, Mauritius. We have been given the following port dues and fees to be deducted from the cargo:

* General Cargo Port Dues: USD 3,256.00
* Coast Guard Charges: USD 164.00
* MFAF (Mauritius Free Airport Fee): USD 112.80
* Port Corporation: USD 159.84
* Generator Rental: USD 0.16/Hour * 12 Hours = USD 1.92
* Empty Tank Cleaning: USD 10.00 * 2 Tanks = USD 20.00

Could you kindly take this into account when submitting your freight quote?

Best regards,
Samuel

---

From: alain.ferris@maritime-trade.com
To: samuel.chen@vesselbroker.com
Subject: Re: Port Charges Query - Heavy Plates Shipment to Port Louis
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 14:45
Body: Dear Samuel,

Thank you for your email. Unfortunately, it is not appropriate for you to pass charges like this on to the cargo owners without their consent. If you are able to provide evidence that this is the owners' responsibility (e.g. a bill of lading with a clause allowing the carrier to deduct port dues from the cargo), we might be able to discuss a rate increase to cover these expenses, but if you are just making up charges to pay your agency then it is unethical and we will not pay you.

We also need a few more details on the cargo (origin, grade, product code), which will enable us to get a more accurate quote for the freight.

The more information you are able to provide in your emails, the faster we can give you an answer.

Thank you,
Alain Ferris

Dear Captain X,                    Could you please provide a freight idea on 30,000MT of soybean meal for September delivery from Chongqing to Dalian.                    Regards,                    Sulek
Email 2:
Dear Suheki,                        Our cargo agent has confirmed for us the rates on 30,000MT soybean meal from Chongqing to Dalian, as follows:                        Blt Chongqing:                          Spot period 10,000USD;                          September delivery 9,750USD                        Bunkering for Chongqing:                          80USD                        F.O.B Dalian:                          Spot period 60USD;                          September delivery 75USD                        Bunkering for Dalian:                          30USD                        Our vessel is available for September delivery.                        As soon as you are ready, please let us know the details for your shipment, and we'll quote you accordingly.                        Thanks!                        Horeb Shipping Captain X

Forward to the second email: "How much is the shipping cost to the same spot, but the destination changed to Shantou?"                From X's
Email 3:
Dear Captain X,                        Thank you for your prompt reply.                        We would like to book cargo as you mentioned in your email 2.                        The information you need is as follows:                        Quantity: 30,000MT (weight)                        Type: Soybean meal                        Packed in 50kg jumbo bags                        Packed in 1,200 bags per 40'HC container                        Destination: Shantou                        Port of loading: Chongqing                        In the end of June this year, my company and a dealer made an agreement of selling and buying the above soybean meal at the agreed price of 1,300USD per MT.                        I'm wondering if I can still make the shipment at such price even now it's September.                        Thanks in advance.                        Sulek
<Email 4>:
Dear Suheki,                        I've checked with our freight
Email 4:
Dear Suheki,                        I've checked with our freight

<Email 4>:
 Dear Suheki,                        I've checked with our freight representative. I'm afraid the above rate is no longer available.                        It seems that after your July inquiry, the freight cost has been rising continuously. In September, the rate could be around 12,000USD/30,000MT. It's quite expensive compared with your original contract of 1,300USD per MT.                        I'm afraid your soybean meal could be sold at a lower price now.                        Regards,                        Captain X
Email 5:
Dear Captain X,                        That's terrible!                        It seems that we can't make it.                        At that time we agreed the contract price was only 1,300USD per MT. If we reduce the price further, we'll definitely lose some money.                        I don't know how to explain this to the client.                        I'd better tell him to take some other cargo.                        I will close this deal with the seller now.                        Thanks.                        Sulek
<Email 6>:
 Dear Suheki,                        It's a pity.                        I think that if we still insist to take the cargo, we can at least minimize the loss. We can fix the rate for the shipment.                        If we reduce the price further, we'll definitely lose some money.                        I'd better tell him to take some other cargo.                        I will close this deal with the seller now

Body: Dear Captain X,

Thank you for your prompt reply. We would like to book cargo with the following specifications:

Quantity: 30,000MT
Cargo: Soybean meal
Packing: 50kg jumbo bags (1,200 bags per 40'HC container)
Loading Port: Chongqing
Discharge Port: Shantou

For context, we agreed on a contract price of USD 1,300 per MT with our buyer in June. Can you please confirm if the same rates would apply for Shantou as the destination?

Best regards,
Sulek

---

From: captain.x@horebshipping.com
To: sulek@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Cargo Booking Details - Soybean Meal to Shantou
Timestamp: 2023-09-02 14:30
Body: Dear Sulek,

I regret to inform you that the previous rates are no longer available. Freight costs have increased significantly since July. The current rate for September delivery would be approximately USD 12,000 per 30,000MT to Shantou.

I understand this may impact your contract at USD 1,300 per MT significantly.

Best regards,
Captain X

---

From: sulek@tradingco.com
To: captain.x@horebshipping.com
Subject: Re: Cargo Booking Details - Soybean Meal to Shantou
Timestamp: 2023-09-02 16:45
Body: Dear Captain X,

This is very unfortunate news. Given the significant increase in freight costs, we cannot proceed with this shipment as it would result in considerable losses at our contracted price of USD 1,300 per MT.

I will have to cancel this deal with the seller and inform the client accordingly.

Thank you for your assistance.

Best regards,
Sulek

Email 3:
Can you tell me what is the status of the Ever Given ship that got stuck in the Suez Canal in March? Is it still there? Also, I've heard about the backlog of vessels in the canal. Do you know if that might affect my shipment?
Dear (Name),
I hope this message finds you well. I understand that you have some questions regarding the Ever Given ship and the backlog of vessels at the Suez Canal. Let me try to address your concerns.
Firstly, the Ever Given ship was successfully dislodged from the Suez Canal on March 29th, after being stuck for almost a week. However, it remains in the canal until it can be re-fueled and towed to another location for repairs. The process of refueling and repairing the ship is expected to take several weeks.
As for the backlog of vessels in the canal, the congestion has
output_text:
From: donald.smith@example.com
To: shipping.support@example.com
Subject: Suez Canal Delays Query
Timestamp: 2023-05-01 09:15
Body: Hi,

I have heard of some vessels taking longer than normal to make passage through locks at the Suez Canal. Do you know if this is correct and do you think it might delay my shipment from China to Long Beach?

Sincerely,
Donald

---

From: sarah.jones@example.com
To: shipping.support@example.com
Subject: RE: Suez Canal Delays Query
Timestamp: 2023-05-01 10:30
Body: Hi,

I've also heard about vessels taking longer than normal to make passage through the Suez Canal. How does that affect my shipments?

Sincerely,
Sarah

---

From: shipping.support@example.com
To: sarah.jones@example.com, donald.smith@example.com
Subject: RE: Suez Canal Delays Query
Timestamp: 2023-05-02 14:20
Body: Dear Valued Customers,

Thank you for your inquiries about the Suez Canal situation. Here are the current facts:

1. The Suez Canal is experiencing significant congestion with 67 vessels waiting to enter and 55 vessels waiting to exit as of May 2nd.

2. This congestion stems from the March incident involving the Ever Given vessel, which has created an ongoing backlog despite the canal's reopening.

3. The Ever Given has been successfully dislodged but remains in the canal pending refueling and repairs.

We recommend factoring in potential delays for any shipments routing through the Suez Canal during this period.

Best regards,
Shipping Support Team

input_text:
Email 1:
Good day Ms. Kelly,                    I’m inquiring about 3,400MT of sulphuric acid from Aqaba to Khor Fakkan. Could you handle a late-July laycan, and are you open to a short load window?                    Best,                    Aqaba
Email 2:
Hi J. Pye,                    I’m writing you about your question. However, due to some problems with confidentiality, I will have to address this email as being from someone other than me.                    I can handle a late July load date, but you must understand that it may take us a few weeks to secure the necessary permits. You can help speed things along by hiring a third party to find out who the permits are issued to, and to pay them for their services. Your cargo is a noxious substance that has been denied to others in the past, so this must be done delicately. The load window can be as short as 3-4 days, but we’ll have to include that in the permits, too.                    Yours,                    Aqaba

<Email 3>:
Dear Mr. Zhao,                    This is in response to your message about the grade of sulph
output_text:
From: j.pye@aqabatrading.com
To: m.kelly@freightservices.com
Subject: Sulphuric Acid Shipment Inquiry - Aqaba to Khor Fakkan
Timestamp: 2023-07-10 09:15
Body: Good day Ms. Kelly,

I'm inquiring about the possibility of shipping 3,400MT of sulphuric acid from Aqaba to Khor Fakkan. Could you handle a late-July laycan, and are you open to a short load window?

Best regards,
J. Pye

---

From: m.kelly@freightservices.com
To: j.pye@aqabatrading.com
Subject: Re: Sulphuric Acid Shipment Inquiry - Aqaba to Khor Fakkan
Timestamp: 2023-07-10 14:22
Body: Dear J. Pye,

Thank you for your inquiry. We can accommodate a late July load date, however please note that securing the necessary permits for hazardous cargo may take several weeks. A load window of 3-4 days is possible, but this will need to be specified in the permits.

We recommend engaging a local agent to expedite the permit process. Given the nature of the cargo, all documentation must be handled with appropriate care and attention.

Best regards,
M. Kelly

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Steve,                    Have a great week! My team and I are in Las Vegas this week for the NFPA Convention, but we'll be back on Monday.                    If you can please send us the routing information for your 5,500MT MGO shipment, we'll arrange for a broker to pick it up and make our arrangements to ship to Pusan.                    Thanks,                    Will
Email 2:
Hey All,                     Because I’m out of the office this week, I’m sending you some interesting projects and news to check out while I’m away!  Here are a few highlights:
* Click here to learn about the Fertilizer Institute’s new Code of Conduct, which includes nine guiding principles for good behavior, including the encouragement of a culture of safety and compliance with the law. "Anyone who works with anhydrous ammonia or other fertilizers must read this, and they must share it with their teams," says Director of Regulatory Affairs Brian Jennings.
* When a group of California manufacturers and distributors went before the California Air Resources Board (CARB) to discuss the 2013 Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) proposed by the U.S. EPA, they did not leave empty-handed. A bill was introduced in the state legislature that would provide a tax incentive to encourage renewable fuel blending
Email 3:
It’s been busy around the warehouses. We are in the process of getting our Fall products ready. We have had some order cancellations so we will have a few spots open. We are reevaluating our shipping schedules. We are now shipping later than we did last year. It appears that the weather is not cooperating. We will keep you informed as we get better weather conditions. Some 20-inch rocks have not made it to the Southeastern states due to weather conditions and we are not sure when we will get them in.

To: steve.bennett@tradingco.com
Subject: MGO Shipment to Pusan - Routing Information Needed
Timestamp: 2024-02-05 09:30
Body: Hello Steve,

Have a great week! My team and I are in Las Vegas this week for the NFPA Convention, but we'll be back on Monday.

If you can please send us the routing information for your 5,500MT MGO shipment, we'll arrange for a broker to pick it up and make our arrangements to ship to Pusan.

Thanks,
Will

---

From: brian.jennings@fertilizerinsitute.org
To: industry.members@fertilizerinsitute.org
Subject: Weekly Updates - New Code of Conduct and RFS News
Timestamp: 2024-02-05 14:45
Body: Hey All,

Because I'm out of the office this week, I'm sending you some important updates:

1. The Fertilizer Institute has released a new Code of Conduct, featuring nine guiding principles for good behavior, including promoting a culture of safety and legal compliance. Anyone working with anhydrous ammonia or other fertilizers must review and share this with their teams.

2. Following discussions between California manufacturers/distributors and CARB regarding the 2013 RFS proposed by the EPA, new legislation has been introduced providing tax incentives for renewable fuel blending.

Best regards,
Brian Jennings
Director of Regulatory Affairs

---

Subject: Fall Product Updates and Shipping Delays

Body: Dear Valued Customers,

We are currently preparing our Fall products for distribution. Due to recent order cancellations, we have several spots available in our shipping schedule.

Please note that our shipping timeline has been pushed back compared to last year due to adverse weather conditions. This particularly affects our 20-inch rock deliveries to Southeastern states.

We will keep you updated as weather conditions improve.

Best regards,
Warehouse Operations Team

Email 2:
Good morning Caroline,

I have checked with my Bitumen supplier.

### Answer options

The correct answer is C.   We need 1,300MT of bitumen


  • A.  We need 1,300MT of bitumen to Chicago                    • B.  I have checked with my supplier                    • D.  Could you name some vessels and a laycan?                    • E.  I wanted to see if we could coordinate our movements to Lyon


The best thing to do when faced with answer options is to try and make as few assumptions as possible. Although the words "we need" in the original email suggests a second person, you shouldn't immediately assume that there is more than one person at SEEDOR Company.
Try and identify the people who are talking about the 1,300MT.
The correct answer is "we".  So, this 1

Email 1:
Dear Sven,                    We’d like to load 12,000MT of chemicals in Boston next week. Could you confirm the price and your vessel’s partial loading window?                    Kind regards,                    Jake
Email 2:
Dear Sven,                    Please confirm the price of 12,000MT of chemicals.                    Kind regards,                    Jake

In my previous post I introduced how the transformer can be used to set up a casual model using a combination of supervised and unsupervised learning. I wanted to apply this methodology to email correspondence analysis but had no good starting points to learn from. So, I decided to have a go at using a large email data set to set up an email correspondence model. In this post, I’ll describe my method and then evaluate it.
## Previous Work
I found two other email correspondence analyses:
Both papers claimed to have a small error rate (below 5%) but no error rate figures were provided. Their methods included analyzing only the destination of emails and ignoring the subjects and whether the email was replied to or not.
## Data
I got the dataset from Wikipedia and as the

Hello Scott,                    My name is Stewart and I’m reaching out from Reznor, one of the main vendors of equipment and services for drywall finishing. We’ve just discovered the worksite of the Sillington project on constructionobserver.com, and since this is right in our backyard, I’d love to get a quote for your finishing needs.                    Can you please send me an estimate for your next order of metal lath so we can stay on your radar for next time? Let me know if you have any other questions about our process and we’ll be happy to walk you through it.                    Thanks in advance for your time, and I look forward to speaking with you.                    Best regards,                    Stewart Vanderbloemen                    Reznor, LLC. (410) 455-2060
Email 2:
Hi Stewart!
This email is to let you know the company would like to move on with other bidding processes. As always, thank you for your interest in my business.

<Email 3>
Stewart Vanderbloemen <stewart.vanderbloemen@reznor.com>                 2:32 PM (0 minutes ago)
Sent from my iPhone

Hey Todd, just to follow up, did you ever receive a quote for your metal lath? I know you said you’d go with another vendor, but I wanted to get this completed for our records. Thanks!

From: Todd Sillington <todd.sillington@gmail.com>                 
To: Stewart Vanderbloemen <stewart.vanderbloemen@reznor.com>     
Sent: Thursday, April 16, 2020, 12:33 PM                     
Subject: RE: Metal Lath Purchase
Email 3:
It’s been a while since I’ve been on Construction observer. Do I have to be a subscriber to view pricing for the services? Thanks.

<Email 4>
I love that you and everyone else on the website have no idea what it takes to run a successful business. You think it’s as easy as going on constructionobserver and asking for bids. Just how much it costs for a quote and if there is a minimum number of products you have to buy.
I’d say it’s an education. Like how the Navy discovered it would lose too many crewmen if they started a major war without undergoing combat training first, so they decided to create such training so that every year they would lose fewer and fewer crews. Combat training also provided the Navy with the opportunity to evaluate newly created equipment and armaments.

In short, anyone can be an entrepreneur. You don’t need to be the richest

output_text:
From: ira.thompson@tradingco.com
To: ['rettig@hub.com', 'nogales@hub.com']
Subject: Potential Entity Formation and Volume Increase
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 09:23
Body: Dear Messrs Rettig and Nogales,

I hear that you are in talks to form a new entity, can you confirm this?

If true, this could be positive news for the industry, particularly if you can demonstrate a joint offering that provides real added value.

In light of this development, we would be interested in discussing the possibility of increasing our volume through HUB. However, this would necessitate improvements in your handling efficiency. I'd appreciate hearing your plans for any planned upgrades.

Best regards,
Ira

---

From: paul.rettig@hub.com
To: ira.thompson@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Potential Entity Formation and Volume Increase
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 14:45
Body: Dear Ira,

Thank you for your inquiry. I can confirm that we are indeed in discussions regarding the formation of a new entity.

We are confident that this consolidation will create significant synergies and enhance our service offering to clients like yourself.

Regarding handling efficiency, we have already initiated planning for major infrastructure upgrades that would support increased volumes. We would welcome the opportunity to discuss these plans with you in detail.

Best regards,
Paul

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Basil,                    Could you handle 5,400MT of vegetable oil from Aqaba to Mombasa, with full documentation? And how much is your storage fee?                    Regards,                    Sina
Email 2:
From: _Sina?_
To: _Ivan?_
Sent: _Thursday, August 19, 2010 9:17:08 AM_
Subject: RE: Storage

> How much is your storage fee? 


   _> And who will deliver this quantity to our factory?_ 

So, there was this corporation who asked about our storage and delivery cost. First question they asked was about storage cost. I made sure to talk about all different prices based on different quantities and then I explained the storage conditions. I never mentioned that in my price I included free delivery to the factory, in my opinion it is better to ask all questions before talking about details. You do not know what questions they can ask.

When I received the email below, I was a bit shocked about the question. However I managed to answer it quickly as follows:

Sina

From:
Email 3:
> _We can handle your storage in Mombasa. The price is 1.2$/MT on 1 month with total quantity of 5,400MTs. We can deliver the cargo by truck directly to your factory. But the price depends on the distance._ 


> _For example, from Mombasa port to Machakos it is 70 Km. The price is 40/MT. From Mombasa to Athi river it is 50KM. The price is 30/MT._


> _Regards, Basil_ 


Dear Sina, Thank you for your email. We can handle your storage in Mombasa. The price is 1.2$/MT on 1 month with total quantity of 5,400MTs. We can deliver the cargo by truck directly to your factory. But the price depends on the distance. For
output_text:
From: sina.trader@trading.com
To: basil.logistics@mombasa.com
Subject: Vegetable Oil Storage & Transport Query
Timestamp: 2010-08-19 09:00:00
Body: Hi Basil,

Could you handle 5,400MT of vegetable oil from Aqaba to Mombasa, with full documentation? And how much is your storage fee?

Regards,
Sina

---

From: basil.logistics@mombasa.com
To: sina.trader@trading.com
Subject: Re: Vegetable Oil Storage & Transport Query
Timestamp: 2010-08-19 09:17:08
Body: Dear Sina,

We can handle your storage in Mombasa. The price is 1.2$/MT per month for the total quantity of 5,400MTs.

We can deliver the cargo by truck directly to your factory. The delivery price depends on the distance:
- Mombasa port to Machakos (70 Km): 40$/MT
- Mombasa to Athi River (50 KM): 30$/MT

Please let me know your preferred delivery location so I can provide an exact quote.

Regards,
Basil

input_text:
Email 1:
Good Morning,                    We have a load of 150k MT of crude oil coming out of Vung Tau on 22nd September. The cargo should be shipped in Hapag Lloyd vessel, perhaps with the product name “XONE”.                    Can you advise us if your vessel is available for this cargo?                    We’re grateful for your help.                    Best regards,                    Natalie                    [Your address]
Email 2:
Dear [Your name],                    Our cargo of crude oil “XONE” will come out of Vung Tau in Vietnam on the 20th of September on board the Hapag Lloyd vessel “Venezuela”.                    How can we send you this cargo?                    We are looking forward to hearing from you.                    Best regards,                    [Your name]                    [Your address]

I would like to share with you a couple of situations I have recently experienced regarding sales. The main factor here is that every port of origin in this region has its own cargo’s name that differs from one port to another. Let me give you an example. Vung Tau’s oil is usually known as “XONE”, for example. If the cargo’s origin was not Vung Tau, it would be known as something different. In the first email, the seller is probably from Vung Tau, the port
Email 3:
<3>
Thanks for your email.                    We have an available vessel. Could you please share the port of origin?                    Thanks.                    Best regards,                    [Your name]                    [Your address]

so he doesn’t want to use the common port of origin name, but he wants to use the name of the port where his product originates from.

We have, however, to be cautious when receiving information from an agent, because often it is not completely correct. If the agent wants to sell his cargo by using an incorrect cargo name, it is much easier for him to trick the buyer by giving a name that has a higher profit for him, or a name that is more familiar for the potential buyer. This issue is something that we have to be aware of. We have to make sure that the cargo is what we think it is, and if we’re sure that we know the exact

Email 3:
We need to ship 4,000MT of HFO from Fujairah to Dar es Salaam. Are you in the market, and are these port dues included in your rate?                     Best regards,                     Donald


They get a reply to only the last email. There are reasons why they could be having difficulty in getting through to their target. This happens frequently when it comes to end-user targets in emerging markets.
I always leave two days in my inbox to send another follow up email after the first one is sent and then at the end of the day send another one. This seems to work better than the more traditional 3-day/3-email rule.

While we see high open rates, it’s possible that the real target isn’t looking for the product at this time and may not have read the email. You don’t really know for sure unless you get a reply from the target

<Email 4>:
 On Mon, May 20, 2019 at 05:54 PM,  wrote:

* Why the captain and other crew leave the bridge, walk away from the wheel, and forget where the wheel is? Is this typical, or is it just human nature?

 It is not typical. Any crew that is leaving the bridge for more than a few minutes will usually assign a watchkeeper and/or specify exactly where the wheel is. If the owner insists on an automatic pilot watchkeeper, it is up to the captain to comply. But that would not be my recommendation.

* If the vessel is in or near a harbor or channel where there are many vessels and navigating is a challenge, why do the ships leave the bridge and let the ship just drift out of control? Would not knowing exactly where the wheel is be a problem? I am talking about not having a person at the helm ready

<Email 4>:

Dear Gerry,                   Thanks.                   Kind regards,                    Paula

Email 1:
To all Freight Forwarders,                    Can you send me a quote for 3,000MT of coal from Jeddah to Kaohsiung for shipment in early July?                    Thank you!                    Jason
Email 2:
Dear Jason,
Thank you for your email and for the opportunity to quote for this shipment of coal. Our quotation is USD260/MT CIF Kaohsiung.                Can you please confirm that this price is acceptable to you?                    Kind regards,                    Greg

<Email 3>:
Dear Jason,
Unfortunately, my offer is not accepted by my client. My client offers to you an FOB Jeddah price of USD210/MT and the rest USD20/MT will be added as demurrage charge at terminal.                Please let me know if this offer is acceptable to you or if you wish to negotiate further.                Kind regards,                    Greg

Email 4:
Dear Greg,
Thank you for your email.                It is acceptable for our side to receive the cargo under such conditions.                Thanks for your effort and cooperation, I look forward to receiving the detail.

input_text:
Email 1:
<WRITE EMAIL C>                    Now email yourself the three emails and compare them. How are they the same? How are they different? Why does it matter?
                                    Write a draft of a short letter you would send to an expert in the field of your career interest. The letter should explain your interest and describe your academic background and experience. Introduce an area of inquiry about the field in which you are interested, and end with a request to speak with this expert about career possibilities in the field. Draft this letter to this week’s guest speaker, Dr.
Email 2:
Dear <NAME>,
I am writing to you because I am highly interested in computer engineering and in designing advanced technology, and I want to know what steps I can take to reach my goal. I want to know what work and learning opportunities are available in computer engineering. I have found out a lot about computer engineering and I have done the research. I want to know what path I need to take to become successful in computer engineering. I have taken a number of classes and learned about the core material that I need for computer engineering.
I want to have more information about computer engineering and what experiences you had in this field. I want to know what steps you took to get to where you are now, and what I need to do to get there. I have done some research, but I do not know what my next step is.
I want to know what classes I should take and what organizations
Email 3:
Dear <NAME>,
My name is <NAME>. I would like to write to you for a few questions that have been bugging me. I have heard of many stories about how to get into a career path I am interested in, and I am wondering which one to follow. I’m interested in psychology as a career and have tried to look into what steps I need to take to get where I want to be.
I would like to know what steps I should take to become successful in psychology. I know that I need to major in psychology and complete my requirements. I also know that there are many other requirements to become successful, like doing internships and taking many more classes. I want to know what your experience was, and what I need to do to get where you are now.
Thank you for your time,

MAIZE            PURCHASE PRICE: CIF MYR (Malaysian Ringgit) USD 118 per MT MYR 4,410.00 per MT                FREIGHT COST: FCL BASIS MYR 1.75 per 1,000 KGS MYR 17,500.00 per 10,000 MT (10,000 MT = 10 TONS)                TOTAL: MYR 4,427.50 per MT                    TRANSPORTING VESSEL : MV MING SHENG HAI (CRUISE 0301), 2005 BUILT, IMO 9301712                VESSEL'S STOWAGE CAPACITY : 50,000 MT                CONSIGNMENT : 10,000 MT

Calvin

2) How much per ton? Thanks in advance                    [Jared]                    FYI.  Comment from J with an IPA trader in Houston about the tonnage.  He says no way.  He's heard of a 10,000 tonne load, but never 80 tonnes.                       Original sender from Anna
output_text:
From: anna.smith@tradingco.com
To: jared.wilson@brokers.com
Subject: IPA Shipment Quote Request - Houston to Tuxpan
Timestamp: 2024-02-14 09:23
Body: Can you give me a CFR and an FOB rate for 80t shipment of 94% isopropanol from Houston to Tuxpan?

Many thanks,
Anna

---

From: jared.wilson@brokers.com
To: anna.smith@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: IPA Shipment Quote Request - Houston to Tuxpan
Timestamp: 2024-02-14 11:45
Body: Hi Anna,

I've checked with our IPA trader in Houston regarding your inquiry. They've flagged a concern about the shipment size. Apparently, 80 tonnes is unusually small - they typically deal with much larger volumes (around 10,000 tonnes).

Two questions:
1) Would you have interest in arranging ISCO from Tuxpan to Veracruz?
2) What's your target price per ton?

Regards,
Jared
