input_text:
Email 1:
Good evening Mr. Menéndez,                    We’ll need a calculation for 3,000MT of diesel from Rotterdam to the 13 docks at Aarhus. Does the 24/7 service you provide include all seasonal holidays?                    Kind regards,                    Abbie
Email 2:
Thanks, Abbie,        Here are some details.        Please do your calculations assuming a spread of 5 to 15 days for loading. If you use 10 days, please note that it will make your calculation more conservative.        These are some other terms you need to consider:        – guaranteed loading window 5 days (as a rule, we do 10% out of this time if the barge is ready at the quay or 10% per day extra from our client’s terminal if the barge is not ready at the quay).        – rotation time: 24h maximum        – unloading time: 24h maximum        – total transit time: 48h        – all statutory holidays are considered normal workdays for shippers.        – routing: Oslo-Fredericia-Middelfart-Harsholm-Portland-Jakobsen        –
output_text:

To: j.menendez@logisticspro.com
Subject: Diesel Shipment Calculation Request - Rotterdam to Aarhus
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 18:45
Body: Good evening Mr. Menéndez,

We'll need a calculation for 3,000MT of diesel from Rotterdam to the 13 docks at Aarhus. Does the 24/7 service you provide include all seasonal holidays?

Kind regards,
Abbie

---

From: j.menendez@logisticspro.com
To: abbie.thompson@freightco.com
Subject: Re: Diesel Shipment Calculation Request - Rotterdam to Aarhus
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 19:23
Body: Thanks, Abbie,

Here are the key details for your calculation:

- Loading window: 5-15 days (recommend using 10 days for conservative estimate)
- Guaranteed loading window: 5 days (10% penalty applies if barge ready/not ready at quay)
- Rotation time: 24h maximum
- Unloading time: 24h maximum
- Total transit time: 48h
- All statutory holidays are considered normal workdays
- Routing: Oslo-Fredericia-Middelfart-Harsholm-Portland-Jakobsen

Let me know if you need any clarification.

Best regards,
Javier Menéndez

input_text:
Email 1:
Mr. Regan,                    Our provider M&N sent us a price of 16.74US/MT to ship jet fuel from Kaohsiung to Daesan via m/v. Do you think this is acceptable?                    Thank you,                    David
Email 2:
David,                         We need to add the price of bunker to shipowners is more expensive than selling bunker, since our agent will pay for all bunker in VETSA trades.                    Also please consider the fact that our ship is selling product from Daesan to India before load jet to Daesan.                    So it will be 16.74 US/MT with bunker at VETSA trades.                    Hope this helps.                    Let me know what you think.                    Eddie
                    
<Email 3>:                      If I understand you correctly you need to make an estimate at load (in this case Daesan) about how much bunker will be consumed until the vessel arrives in discharge port. However, in reality most of the bunker will be consumed when the vessel travels from load to discharge port and you should pay to us the bunker consumed only from discharge port to load. In this case as we see from the
output_text:
From: david.chen@company.com
To: eddie.regan@company.com
Subject: Freight Quote Review - Kaohsiung/Daesan Jet Fuel Shipment
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 09:30
Body: Mr. Regan,

Our provider M&N has quoted us 16.74 USD/MT to ship jet fuel from Kaohsiung to Daesan via m/v. Could you please review if this rate is acceptable?

Thank you,
David

---

From: eddie.regan@company.com
To: david.chen@company.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Review - Kaohsiung/Daesan Jet Fuel Shipment
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 10:15
Body: David,

We need to consider that the bunker price being charged to shipowners is higher than our selling price for VETSA trades, where our agent covers all bunker costs.

Additionally, please note that the vessel will be delivering product from Daesan to India before loading jet fuel to Daesan.

Therefore, the rate will be 16.74 USD/MT including bunker for VETSA trades.

Let me know your thoughts.

Regards,
Eddie

---

From: david.chen@company.com
To: eddie.regan@company.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Review - Kaohsiung/Daesan Jet Fuel Shipment
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 11:00
Body: Eddie,

I understand we need to estimate bunker consumption at loading port (Daesan). However, most bunker will be consumed during the voyage from loading to discharge port, and we should only be responsible for bunker consumed from discharge port back to loading port.

Could you please clarify the final calculation based on this?

Regards,
David

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Carlos,                    Could you take on 11,400MT of kerosene from New Orleans to Jacksonville? Any ideas on extra insurance premiums for weeknd deliveries?                    Thanks,                    Vitoria
Email 2:
dave,                    look at the surface tanker jet fuel route chart on the www and do the calculations. The distance is only 275 miles and if you cut through the shallows then it's maybe only 250 miles.                    With the shallowest part 43 feet, a 35,000 ton tanker would only use about 16' of water to float. If a tanker could travel through the route, I'm sure that the insurance premiums wouldn't be a major problem.                    I could not find any such tanker out there right now so it's not a matter of just connecting the dots.                    The insurance companies would calculate that if there is a loss, there is no place for the ship to refuel on the route, so the insurance rates might be higher.                    Bob

---

From: bob.smith@maritime.com
To: dave.wilson@tankers.com
Subject: Re: Kerosene Shipment NOLA-JAX
Timestamp: 2005-04-05 15:15
Body: Dave,

I checked the surface tanker jet fuel route chart. The distance is only 275 miles, potentially 250 if cutting through the shallows. With the shallowest part at 43 feet, a 35,000 ton tanker would only need about 16' of water draft.

While vessel passage shouldn't be an issue, insurance premiums might be higher due to limited refueling options along the route. However, I'm not seeing any suitable tankers available at the moment.

Regards,
Bob

---

Thanks!
Bob Loeschcke

Subject: RE: IN/OUT service of 250K+ Tankers between Miami and Rio de Janeiro
Timestamp: 2005-04-05 18:43
Body: Found the Ghyben-Herzberg limited water zone map on surfacetankers.info - exactly what we needed!

By the way, if anyone knows of a 250K bbl tanker (approx. 12M gallons) available for Brazil route, please connect us. Looking to arrange offloading in the Bahamas.
